column10: BRING BACK TOTAL WAR ARENA

Roughly 30 minutes into playing this game, I had a epiphany... Any potential that I have as an individual is being pissed away by the minute by this shallow escapism. The countless hours studying, working, and struggling are all for naught thanks to my knuckle-dragging impulsivity to boot up Steam once more and rot in a chair instead of: furthering my career, starting my own business, making sound investment decisions, or mastering an instrument. The waste is truly criminal and evidence that no one should have invested a single minute or dime into my future. 

Now with all that being said... It's a solid RTS with iconic factions, smooth gameplay, and fun maps to battle on. Buy it now and waste your life and potential with me.

Great game, don't buy it, go for Warhammer 2 and this one only on sale. A heavy sale. It's not even 'that' good when you look at 2. However it is basically a DLC for 2 as you need it for the Mortal Empires campaign. Which is basically the 'whole world' campaign in Warhammer 2.

BLUF: Fascinating fantasy world that is worth your investment, with solid game play mechanics that will leave you wanting to explore Warhammer even more!

Newcomer here, not to the Total War franchise but certainly to Warhammer. My only other experience with Warhammer was Vermintide, briefly, which was interesting but I did not really understand the universe. Total War: Warhammer is a MUCH smoother introduction to this fantasy world, as it leaves you wanting to know more about the factions you are leading and the rivalries therein. Enough of the lore is written into the characters, units, buildings, etc. that you understand what's generally going on in the game, both from a story perspective and (perhaps more importantly) a game play perspective.  It's not totally comprehensive, and you will still need to read up on the lore outside of the game if you want to understand what's going on, but if you have been hesitating about buying the game up till now because you have been intimidated by the lore, then this is the game to start with.

Game play wise, I am the wrong person to ask. I love the game play, personally, but I am someone who still thinks Mount and Blade: Warband looks good, and who just finished Rome Remastered after playing the original a year ago. 

TLDR: Fascinating fantasy world that is worth your investment, with solid game play mechanics that will leave you wanting to explore Warhammer even more!

I have played 100 hours in warhammer II. And i must say, it is actually a mistake that i played the 2nd before the first game. There is a bit more soul to this first installment, and a lot less overwhelming when it comes to learning all the features of the campaign. only an hour in and i feel like i grasp the concept and purpose of the campaign better than i did in the second which i mainly only played mortal empires on as the empire. Warhammer I is a lot more cozy with a smaller map and clear outlines with which provinces you can capture and the impending chaos invasion during the end game. And it seems much more effort was put into each faction since there are so few. This is a great starting point for anyone interested in getting into the warhammer total war series. This also will set you up properly for warhammer II since you will eventually be buying all the DLC for this first installment that will then carry over into the later titles. Pick this game up and take it slow as you learn your way around the controls and movement of your troops. You will have an absolute blast. I also noticed that the map environments in this game have a lot more variation in elevation and movement if you like that sort of thing. I would say if you have the money and have a friend that desperately wants you to play the later installments then just grab everything in WH I ( not all DLC is on the steam store, you will need a total war account for the free extra lords and units. Look up a guide if need be since this can get confusing) and WH II on a steam sale and purchase only the base game for WH III atm. Then when you and your friend are done playing the one he or she wants you to play come back to the first game to get your bearings in the single player campaign. This is if it is your first foray into total war games and the war hammer universe itself. If you have performance issues you must seek out fixes and mods that will help and i cannot say i have run into any problems that i noticed so far. Seriously you will not regret starting your journey from the beginning.
Only Purchased the game as DLC for TWWH III, not worth the price.

This game has one of the worst Campaign's I have ever seen out of the numerous total war games I've owned. Here are 10 reasons why:

1. Literally 80% of the factions in Brettonia or Empire make it IMPOSSIBLE to get past 30 min of gameplay.
You will literally encounter a rank 1 enemy bot who literally has units that outperforms yours by times 100; literally NO ONE wants to make peace or make an allince, and if they do they always break it, or don't offer support when attacked by that rank 1 enemy. 

2. The BOTS literally play like god it is ridicolous even on easy/normal mode. They literally seem to attack the minute you make a turn moving your units away or declare war on another nation. The moves are near "perfect" and no the exact moment to strike

3. You will spend 80% of your turns under siege with 30k gold trying to make peace or a damn trade-aggrement with any factions possible offering up to 15k gold yet they'll still decline your offer!

THE CAMPAIGN IS LITERALLY RIGGED PLZ FIX! How am I suppose to enjoy this game when since turn one, the nearest enemy seems to have troops that take a minimum of 100 turns, AND seems to be hostille for no reason!

Ladies and Gentlemen, today we delve into the captivating realms of Total War: Warhammer, a captivating fusion of Creative Assembly's renowned Total War franchise with the rich tapestry of Games Workshop's Warhammer Fantasy Battles. Now, I've seen my fair share of strategy games, but this one, oh, this one, it's a magnum opus that strikes a chord with fans of both genres, delivering a strategic experience that is as engaging as it is immersive.
Let's talk about the world first. The Old World, a rich and diverse tapestry of landscapes and factions, is brought to life with meticulous detail by Creative Assembly. From the grand fortresses of the Empire to the sinister lairs of Chaos, each faction is brimming with character and depth, bringing the Warhammer lore to life in ways that fans could only dream of. The attention to detail in capturing the essence of each faction is a testament to the love and respect the developers hold for the source material.
The gameplay, my friends, is where Total War: Warhammer truly shines. It seamlessly blends the deep, strategic gameplay of the Total War series with the unique abilities and units of the Warhammer universe. Whether you're commanding the stalwart defenders of the Dwarfs, or unleashing the raw power of Chaos upon the world, each faction provides a distinct and engaging playstyle that ensures no two campaigns ever feel the same. The battles are grand, the tactics intricate, and the strategic possibilities near endless.
But let's not overlook the DLCs, the lifeblood of the game's evolution. Each DLC brings with it new factions, units, and campaigns that breathe new life into the already sprawling universe of Total War: Warhammer. From the savage horde of the Beastmen to the enigmatic forces of the Wood Elves, the DLCs expand the horizons of the game, adding depth and variety that keeps the gameplay experience fresh and exciting for veterans and newcomers alike.
Total War: Warhammer is a testament to the creative synergy between two esteemed franchises, a game that appeals to both the strategic masterminds and the fantasy enthusiasts. The Old World is a stage set for conquest and glory, a world where the clash of swords and the chants of magic intertwine in a symphony of chaos and order. So rally your forces, sharpen your wits, and prepare to immerse yourself in a strategic fantasy experience unlike any other. Total War: Warhammer is a triumph that stands as a beacon in the annals of both strategy and fantasy gaming.

Title: Total War: Warhammer - A Comprehensive Review after 80 Hours of Gameplay

Rating: 4.5/5 Stars

After investing a significant 80 hours into Total War: Warhammer, I feel well-positioned to offer a thorough review of this captivating game. Total War: Warhammer excellently merges the grand strategy genre with a rich, fantasy world, creating an immersive and deep gameplay experience that is hard to put down.

What I Liked:

Diverse Factions: The diversity in factions and their unique playstyles is a major highlight. Whether you prefer the disciplined ranks of the Empire, the chaotic hordes of the Greenskins, or the enigmatic forces of the Vampire Counts, there's a style for every type of strategist.

Epic Battles: The battles are visually stunning and strategically deep. The way units interact, the importance of terrain, and the use of heroes and magic add layers of strategy that are both challenging and rewarding.

Engaging Campaigns: Each faction offers a distinct campaign experience with unique objectives, storytelling, and challenges. This variety ensures high replayability.

Beautiful Graphics and Sound Design: The game's visuals and sound design are top-notch, effectively bringing the Warhammer world to life.

What I Disliked:

Learning Curve: For newcomers to the Total War series or those not familiar with Warhammer lore, there's a steep learning curve that can be daunting.

Performance Issues: On lower-end systems, the game can suffer from performance issues, particularly during large battles.

DLC Content: While the DLCs add great content, the cost can add up, and some key factions are locked behind these additional purchases.

Recommendation:

Would I recommend Total War: Warhammer? Absolutely, but with a caveat. If you're a fan of strategy games and enjoy rich, fantasy settings, this game is a must-play. However, be prepared for a steep learning curve and potentially additional investment in DLCs for the full experience.

Overall, Total War: Warhammer brilliantly combines deep strategic gameplay with a rich fantasy world. It's a game that's easy to dive into but hard to master, offering endless hours of engagement for strategy enthusiasts.

1. A formal apology

You need this to play the Mortal Empires and Immortal Empires maps in Warhammer 2 and Warhammer 3 respectively.

Some things I've noticed instantly, as compared to my hundreds of hours of Warhammer 2 and the couple of hours I have on Warhammer 3;
1. Map size being smaller benefits the game significantly. Admittedly, it does feel quite a bit more lonely and the existence of diplomacy is barely functional, but there is nevertheless a sense of safety that you can get in this game that you will never experience in the other Warhammers, at least until way further down the line.
2. Battleground size being bigger is a huge improvement and I wish that this was still the case for the current Warhammer games. The larger map makes reinforcements have to crawl across the huge landscape, which is annoying, but it also gives way more opportunity to push landscape advantage and to control your units in a more strategic fashion. This also means you actually have to utilize the run/walk mechanic, which is a nice change of pace.
3. Cavalry works. Perhaps a little too well, admittedly, as they seem to significantly outclass most ground units. That being said, there's actually a reason to have charge defense in your army, as charges are actually an important part of the game now.
4. Missiles are way weaker, and it's not really that bad. Admittedly, missiles feel way more inaccurate and there's a considerable lack of satisfaction when unloading entire rounds of ammunition into on-coming enemy forces, but it's also not really that bad. Less missile units means more strategy, in my opinion.
5. Heroes are way overpowered, but maybe that's a good thing? I definitely notice the overwhelming strength of heroes in this game moreso than WH2 and WH3, though that may be by virtue of the missiles being far weaker (and relying on your infantry is just throwing wave after wave of them into an unstoppable force, so the only way to counter heroes is with heroes). They're also a lot rarer.
6. Some aspects of the U.I. are arguably better, and I like the option to choose multiple of different heroes in the same starting location. The other games have this too, but to an extremely limited extent. I don't really care that much about it though. It just feels like each faction is more self-contained.
7. Magical items are more rare, quest battles are more casual; why did this go away? Magical items SHOULD be rare by virtue of providing a stat boost to the strongest unit types in the game, and casual quest battles teach the player how to play the game or provide a unique gameplay scenario. They can't be that hard to set up.
8. No environment, just limited conquest; this is an interesting design choice and I'm not entirely sure how I feel about it. On one hand, it makes playing each faction especially different because they are bound to certain cities that they can colonize. On the other hand, you cannot guarantee the stop of a resurgence of your enemy due to the fact that razed ruins can still be colonized by them, and only them.

I might add more later as I go further into the game, but it's surprising how different this feels as compared to Warhammer 2.

[h3]Customer warning.

SEGA does not allow its customers to buy this game, own it, and play it offline at their own leisure. Total War Warhammer is, for all intents and purposes, an "Always-Online" service.[/h3]

That is because of DENUVO. Which is the Digital Rights Management (DRM) software that is bundled with this product.

DENUVO forces you to link the product that you purchased (which should rather be your own property, for you to do with as you please) to DENUVO's online servers. Then it forces the product that you purchased, and that you therefore should fully own, to "call home" regularly to that server. This, in perpetuity. Whenever DENUVO is not able to call home, you are not able to use nor access the product that you purchased anymore.

If you must go offline for any amount of time, you are not able to play a game you supposedly own (surprise. As it turns out, you were simply renting it to a landlord, as it were).

DENUVO serves no purpose to the customer. On the contrary, DENUVO weakens the customer's rights to own the products, any product, that they purchase. DENUVO effectively assumes control and ownership of any product it is associated with. That control and ownership should be the customer's.

SEGA is voluntarily selling its customers a defective product.

One which its customers cannot own, one which cannot be the property of SEGA's customers.

One which, once it has been legally purchased by the customer, nevertheless actually remains the property of SEGA and DENUVO.

Total War Warhammer is a defective product.

One which completely fails, right from the get go, to meet my own criterias for any sort of positive word of mouth or recommendation.

Edit 30/10/2023; Due to recent developments coming from Creative Assembly I no longer wish to leave positive feedback for their products. The venom they seem to have adopted against the community has left a foul taste in my mouth. I will leave the original review below, but be aware it no longer reflects how I feel about any of the games in this trilogy;

THIS REVIEW WAS MADE IN GOOD FAITH AT THE TIME IT WAS ORIGINALLY POSTED.

[Hey, remember when normal price tags for DLC were $20? Yeah, those were completely normal times.

Seriously, folks. $20 is actually THE price that DLC was for the yesteryears. Do you know why you only now ever see "DLC" for more or less $10?

Consumerism. Really, it's ruined all our minds.

Take Age of Mythology, for example. A prime game, one of the most iconic and loved RTS's for the early, or even late, 2000's. Still played to this day. The "DLC" for it, the Titans Expansion? $20.

Heck, even Blizzard's expansions for it's own games are full game prices.

This $20 DLC does not and should not dwarf TW:W's great gameplay, amazing world map (as well as the very detailed and wonderful battlefields), and the care put into the races that are currently out.

That care takes both time and money. For every hour they spent on the Beastmen, they had to pay a building full of people to develop, animate, voice act, translate (From English into the actual Beastman vocabulary), and ultimately test, tweak, and hotfix. That $20 per person pales in comparison to the money they spent on it. Would you like to pay the full amount of money the company put into it? Nope. And I bet if they tried to do that you wouldn't complain about this pittance then.

TW:W is an awesome game, CA, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise. Keep it up!]

I've been playing Total War since I was in middle school when it came out in 2004 and I was 11 years old.  Back then, my favorite past-time was just seeing how big of an army of peasants I could beat with 1 unit of roman elites.  I spent countless hours messing around in battles, listening to heroic speeches (and cheating at the game because I was 11 and didn't quite get the campaign).

I was pumped beyond belief when I heard Rome II got announced and bought it immediately (in my Freshman year of college, boy how time flies) only to not be able to play it because of how broken it was on launch.  But it got fixed and countless more hours were spent and finally some campaigns beaten.

In that time I've also played Shogun 2, Empire, Medieval 2, 3k, Thrones, Warhammer I & 2 & 3 (Check my steam library, they're all there).  I even bought the Remastered version just because I love Total War.

And now, I will never, ever, ever do that again due to their ridiculous downfall.  Stop releasing bad games and silencing dissent.  Absolutely ridiculous this even needs to be said.
A standalone game that, that now serves as paid DLC for Total War: Warhammer III, get that game instead as it has many needed quality of life updates this game now lacks.

This game is incredible. It's like all my Warhammer dreams come to life. Very engrossing campaign. So much complexity, this game truly is an epic experience. Each battle and war feels like a campaign in and of itself, I take down one enemy, and think, phew, but then another enemy arrives and it's another knockdown, drag out fight, and achieving victory is not a straightforward affair. I love it. Other strategy games have a certain way to achieve victory that can be narrow in scope. Not TWW, you need to be across, and balancing many different facets of the game. When victory is achieved it is very satisfying. This is the same feeling I had when I first played Dark Souls and Elden Ring. Not many games give me that feeling. 11 out of 10.

I cannot recommend any CA published game at this time due to the malicious way that the company and has treated its consumer base in recent years. CA has essentially banned criticism of them or their products within the steam forums for their games. They insist if one must be critical of the game that they provide a solution to fix the problem. This is nigh impossible for me as I am not a software developer or well-versed on how these games work under the hood. Therefore my advice on how to fix things must instead be focused on the need to engage constructively with the fan base, not alienate people who have spent hundreds of dollars on their games over the years, and been the base of the company's success over the last two decades. I also suggest that DLC prices moving forward be reduced to reflect the paucity of value they provide to the game. Additionally I would greatly appreciate new content to reflect what has been promised to consumers in the past (3k scrapped DLC). If anyone at CA or their parent company SEGA wants to discuss further suggestions I have I invite them to message me. I would be happy to have a constructive chat on why I have felt unwilling to purchase recent releases from what has historically been my favorite video game series.

If you know Mortal/immortal empires from later installments, this game functions a lot like that, but with story interwoven into it. A lot of the factions are very simple and straightforward, and are reworked in later games to be more complicated with tons of mechanics you have to constantly work around, but in this game, it really is simple, you build an army, you fight things, you manage resources, you do diplomacy. The best parts of total war, and nothing else. If, like me, you just want to fight things and not have to worry about generating prestige to keep the elector counts from declaring war on eachother for no reason at all, this is probably the total war warhammer experience for you.
Plus, if you decide you just want it for the factions, every faction in this game is chef's kiss excellent. Lots of variety, lots of free content, the empire probably still has the most strategy variance in the entire franchise.

Overly complicated tabletop army game with bad gameplay and a great world.

The world is outstanding. Decades of developed characters, locations and general flavor make for a place that is fun to experience and learn about. If you're familiar with the Warhammer world at all you know what I'm talking about. It's just so rich a setting.

The game is a drag though. The tutorial is virtually non-existent at the beginning of the game. I won the battle either completely by accident or because one's performance in it is incidental. Once the game really gets going, the tutorial aspects become more helpful, but remind me a lot of Navi from the N64 Zelda game. More a distraction than a helpful guide.

There are two modes: Battles, which is the deciding factor in the story and how you progress towards ultimate domination, and Kingdom Maintenance, which has a kind of Civilization flavor to it as you try to balance your budget and build improvements to make your slice of the political pie more effective.

The kingdom building aspect is the most fun. Trying to figure out what combinations of things like religious institutions, trade centers, military support structures, or bars to keep the peasants happy provides a lot of food for contemplation as to what makes a good place to live. In the context of the Warhammer world, its kind of cool to figure out what's best for Averland, or Ostland for their best life to live.

The battle aspect is pretty boring stuff though. Myth the Fallen Lords was more exciting than this. Lots of micromanaging of units with a finger always on the space bar to pause. Gotta do a lot of saves so you can walk your way out of dead ends, especially as the overall campaign starts to pass into months. Customizing the army is fun, and again the world makes it have a flavorful dressing to the gameplay. But honestly, if I wasn't dull thud Karl Franz on a Griffin I'd have dropped the game much sooner than I would have.

The problem is there's too many battles to undergo and the actual battlin' to be done is tedious and uninteresting. The game actually acknowledges this by allowing you to skip battles not related to the main story by just pressing a "roll the dice" button. If your army is "by the numbers" better you pretty much win and move on. I found myself pressing the easy button a lot, and avoiding the main story battles because the meaningless battles happen all the time, while the story-battles are hard even on easy street. You can always put it off and build a few more units or another improvement.

I lost interest and put this in the smolder pit.

It pains me to leave a negative review on one of my favorite entries in the franchise, but...

There is no music on the campaign map.

Apparently, this bug was introduced in 2021 along with the game's release on Epic. You used to be able to fix this by rolling back to a previous build but then CA removed that option altogether. Furthermore, CA has not provided modding tools for the music files for copyright reasons, so this issue cannot be fixed by the community.

If you intend to play the Warhammer 1 campaign, be advised that this is a full priced game sold in 2023 where the majority of the in-game music is simply gone, missing, no longer there.

I think the single player campaign is a nice change of pace from the second and third Warhammer games, but there is no way I can recommend this game when such a glaring issue has remained unaddressed for so long.

Also on a more personal note I think it's absolutely shameful that a game released on steam in 2016 cannot be enjoyed as it originally was. I realize CA is primarily selling this game as a Warhammer 3 DLC but the campaign is included in the price of the product and should be fit for purpose. I can digitally buy games released in the 90's that have no sound issues whatsoever. A game this recent being sold with over half the music missing is nothing short of shameful.

I've enjoyed most of the Total War titles from the beginning. This is from a newer generation of their games and takes a little getting used to for fans of the original titles. With that being said I'm enjoying what the game has to offer. The things that I like about the campaign and managing the battles remind of me the 'Medieval' Total War series, which is my personal favorite. The province management and campaign are much different than the original Total War games, just different enough to not be annoying to relearn. The battles themselves though still feel like all of the classic Total War titles always have.

The DLC feels a little overpriced, but even without it, this is a cool experience. The main event seems to be the "story" campaign, which offers a unique experience for every faction. There are specific missions given to you, but control is ultimately yours. 

I'm reminded of Civilization quite a bit on the world map, but you're given the opportunity to micromanage battles. Depending on map conditions and formations, there is room for wildly unexpected results.

Warhammer fan? Why are you reading this? Go play the game already.

Is the game good for everyone else? Yes, it's a solid game imho but bear in mind that my opinion is biased since I'm a huge fan of both Total War and Warhammer.

[h1]Technical and grapics[/h1]
First off, in regards to launch problems I'm aware there are some but I have not experienced any except for hanging during battles twice in 30 hours playtime. I'm playing on a 2 year old(top level at that time) gaming laptop and everything runs fine on medium/high settings. The grapics are great even on this settings and honestly I can't wait to get to play it on a non laptop 1080 GTX in Ultra setting later this summer when I'll be upgrading.

Be warned that there are technical problems for some people so you might want to check up on that before buying the game. If you're unsure you can try it for two hours(which is definitely sufficient) to determine if it works. If it doesnt simply refund the game.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
I like starting off with the bad and ending with the good. Of course there are bad things with the game and some of them are subjective while others might be objective. Many of these are subjective of course and people like playing the game differently.

[b]Agents on the map[/b] are fairly OP imo and agents cannot be specced properly into defensive roles when embedded into an army. I prefer running my agents in my armies but the enemy pretty much spam me with tons of agent actions every turn. There seems to be no defensive bonus for embedding your agents into armies which is wierd considering they take up a unit slot after all. The AI also never use the embedding feature at all. I never once faced a warrior priest on the actual field for instance, instead they run around like crazy on the campaign map. Somewhat immersion breaking. The same total war agent bullshit is still around where your agents got shitty chances and the enemies seems to cripple you a lot. 

[b]Balancing[/b] wise I felt like Orcs needed a heavy nerf when playing as the Empire, I basically lost to an army of 50% archers since they just ran away and I didnt even have access to cavalry yet so I had one unit of Empire Knights that actually lost to the archers after a while.(At least the AI seems competent) Archers is not a problem at all if you're playing Chaos though and only recruit shield units. Which is how I solved this since there is nothing on this earth I hate more than enemy archers(subjective opinion ;)). I have however heard more people confirming that Orks seem a bit OP in the campaign. Especially when playing on VH/Legendary. I also dislike Orks as a faction so bear in mind I may be biased here. 

There are tons of small things that go in here like how hard it actualy is to maintain chaos corruption in provinces that you moved way past and are at the top of the map. Corruption should not decrease in provinces that you already passed. Maybe a mechanic of it spreading from the Chaos Wastes and downward together with your lords as they move would be appropriate here.

[b]Diplomacy[/b] is as usual very badly done, they should have worked something better out between the various Empire factions and the Chaos-Norsca relation, where the AI of Norscans doesnt seem to know how to support you properly on the map even if you set coordination targets. 

Their idea of [b]underworld travel[/b] is a lazy prospect at best. I'd have expected a real underworld where the map shifts much alike Heroes of Might and Magic so this is a disappointement. What I'd like to see are select entrances to the underworld thus giving us more fun choke points as mountains either needs to be passed below or through sparsely places mountain passes. Currently, mountains do not feel like a hindrance or change of environment at all. Of course, non dwarves/skaven/goblins should have a penalty for traversing in this "real" underground I'm mentioning. 

Many obvious places for [b]DLC whoring[/b]. Hopefully some of this will be free. 

[h1]The Good[/h1]

[b]The AI[/b] is actually pretty solid this time around and I have not found them doing stupid stuff that were standard in previous games. Siege battle AI is solid when they are on the defense and they actually try and defend their walls properly. This is a huge plus. 

[b]Siege battles[/b] are remade and made less into a waiting game and more engaging which is good in my opinion. Towers now have range over the entirety of the map pretty much but with a limited fire angle making it possible to avoid them by moving past the small angle or getting in close. Towers are pretty strong as well so it actually feels like defenders have an advantage. Bear in mind I have not played a single defensive seige since I've been playing Chaos and only a small bit of Empire.

Both [b]battles and campaign[/b] are improved upon and I find myself fighting more battles than in previous games. The Campaign map is really nicely done. They actually put a lot of effort in improving the very core gameplay.

[b]Factions diversity[/b] is amazing and the factions feel as unique as they should. There are a fair variety of units and I hope more are added. I'd also like to see some more variants of Empire state troops. 

[h1]Matters of Taste[/h1]
It takes a very very long while to get the top tier units. I got Chaos Knights at around turn 160 and probably 25 hours played. I might just be bad though. ;)

[b]Siege battles[/b] as mentioned above. They also removed minor settlements completely and these battles now play out on the battle map. I like field engagement so for me this is in the green slightly but I still like the immersion of actually seeing the town close by. Would be cool if there was some town environments but the battle was still more in the shape of a field battle.

[b]Powerful Lords.[/b] For me this is a big plus since RP options are so massively expanded but for some of the more hardcore historical TW fans this will be an obvious negative since they dislike the fact of one man being as powerful as 100. I do wonder how it plays out with the lords on smaller unit sizes though, I am playing on Ultra unit size as a total war game should be played. 

Things seems to take time and the campaign pace seems slower than previous TW games, for me this is a good thing. 

[h1]Summary[/h1]
There are some good and some bad aspects with the game. It's a bit of an uncut gem at the moment but most problems with balancing can be solved with mods of course. 

The game is fun and I believe total war fans will like it since it plays like a TW game with some modifications. For Warhammer fans this is a must have, you need it! It's the Mark of Chaos game we all wanted. Even though I actually liked MoC this game is obviously a lot better. 

I personally enjoy the game despite some shortcomings. If you're looking for a perfect game and you're not really that interested in strategy games or fantasy you should probably just go buy the latest cash cow franchise FPS game(CoD). But if you're into fantasy and strategy games I'd highly recommend the game. I'm also very confident it will be improved upon as we see more factions and playability added into the game.

I love this game. It has the right amount of stimulation for me. I love setting up my cities, putting my armies in strategic positions and then engaging in real like battles where you control battalions of units and line them up against opposing army where positioning, flanking, army morale and your other tactics will decide who wins.

There are 4 races included with the base game:

the Empire: which are humans who use steampunk technology and magic. They are a jack of all trade army where you try to unite and defend your empire against a world with many enemies and dangers.

The dwarfs: you know short but stubborn people who prefer to live in the mountains. have strong infantry and ranged power but lack cavalry. Your campaign will revolve around reclaiming your lost cities and righting every wrong the other races did or will do to you.

The vampire counts: My personal favorite as you command legions of undead that don't flee from battle and try to dominate the world with them. They lack ranged units but rely on their infantry to anvil and cavalry and flying monsters to hammer.

The greenskins: consists of orcs, goblins and all sorts of other creatures who just love to fight and loot and destroy. They have decent infantry, monsters and some decent skirmishers. But it's the character and banter these races chant in battle that makes most of the fun with me and brings the full immersion of trying to pick a fight with my neighbors.

so yeah, the introduction of magic and fantasy elements made every race play different and for the first time made me play every faction in a total war game.. I can't go back to historical total wars except maybe when CA makes medieval 3.

If you're buying this, then it's probably to use it as DLC for Total War Warhammer 3.  At this point, pieces of it are broken, and CA [i]will not[/i] fix them.  If you're buying the game as DLC, I do [i]not[/i] recommend it.

*******************

This game is very good.
Obviously, if the Warhammer setting doesn't appeal, it's not a plus (or may even be a minus, depending on your preferences).
With regards to the game itself, it has advantages and disadvantages over previous games in the series.

On the strategic level, it's greatly simplified over many of the more recent games in the series.  A few of the most obvious changes are:
There are no faction politics.
Province management is minimal.
There are no province governors.
There are pretty much no choices regarding how to develop a province beyond whether you want it to be generating cash or generating armies.
Many factions cannot be negotiated with, only fought.

Which all seems pretty poor, but the battles are, quite simply the best Total War has ever managed (except Warhammer 2, which I'll mention below).  The principle two reasons why boil down to:
Variety -
There are genuinely different faction rosters; Vampire Count armies are different from Wood Elf armies, are different from Troll armies, are different from Dwarf armies, are different from Chaos armies, are different from Empire armies, are different from Brettonian armies (and so on) in ways that the historical titles simply cannot be.
Specifically, all the "regular" kinds of Total War units (shock/melee/light/missile cavalry, sword/armour-piercing/spear/polearm/direct-firing-ranged/indirect-firing-ranged foot soldiers, varied artillery) are present, but there are also monstrous units, flying units, chariots, war engines, spellcasters, ethereal troops, fearsome and terrifying units and so on.
There are nine playable races, each with numerous legendary lords to use.  These races play in significantly different ways, again, in ways that historical titles simply cannot do.  This is also true on the campaign map.
The inclusion of so many factors in the battles leads to an excellent variety of options being available to the player both in preparation (building armies and choosing skills for lords and heroes on the campaign map) and in the execution on the battle maps.

and Action -
There is a sweet spot for exciting action here; cavalry, monsters, pikes, artillery, and even sometimes the "regular" infantry all seem to be interesting and powerful in different ways.
The inclusion of terrifying units, magic and hero units make for a more interesting and exciting battlefield, again, in ways that a historical title probably couldn't.

Personally, having been playing these games since the original Shogun: Total War (pre-Mongol Invasion), I've always been of the opinion that the game truly shines on the battle map; the strategic map exists principally to make decisions that determine the circumstances of what battles you will fight.  Although the simplification on the strategic level are a shame in some ways, the vastly increased options and excitement on the battle map more than make up for it.

The final plus point is that whatever you buy here in terms of the base game and DLC is not simply lost by being made obsolete by Total War: Warhammer 2 (and #3 when it gets released).  Everything you buy here is available as content to play in the Mortal Empires campaign of TW:W2, which thus offers even more options for variety on and off the battlefield and probably manages to create even better action than this title.

tldr: Best Total War title up to its release because the battles are so awesome.  Warhammer 2 is better, but everything you buy for Warhammer 1 is playable in #2 as well, so nothing is lost.

I recommend this, but with a hell of a lot of qualifiers. It's a good game, but it's also hard to recommend at this point. It still costs $90AUD, despite having two sequels and coming out seven years ago. The DLC is also insanely priced.

If you're playing Warhammer Total War games on a 1080p monitor (like a gaming laptop for example), then this game actually looks better than 3 does. 3 is a blurry mess at 1080p thanks to the new AA system they've used, and you also can't scale the UI at that resolution and the default is far too large and blocks a lot of the screen. You can scale the UI in the first two games in the series however.

So honestly, 2 is probably the better game, but there's a lot to be said for the relative simplicity of 1, the graphical clarity, and the less bloated, videogamey minor siege battles and supply nonsense in 3. That all said, this game should NOT still be full price, nor should it's DLC. It should also NOT still have denuvo deactivating my game when I don't log on often enough (I travel a lot, and that horrendous program breaks my games constantly until I can get to an internet connection). Why they are still paying a denuvo licence on a seven year old game I have no idea.

Get this, but only on a deep sale. And know going in that Creative Assembly have an extremely predatory pricing model. Their latest DLC for WH3 costs $36AUD, which is obscene when you consider how little content it actually includes.

The game uses scripts.  Scripts create events that the player must respond to or ignore.  I was playing Chaos and thought I was doing well until the script for "Sarthorael the Over Watcher" triggered.  Sarthorael was a level 30 boss with dual hell cannon killer stacks. I am not going not mention the other three large stacks by other opponents. My hero was only level 12 and I had hoped to get hell cannons in my one stack in three turns.  I am not sure what triggers the events or scales their difficulty level, but they seem way overpowered.  I must be doing something wrong in that I am triggering these events incorrectly? I have also played as other races that were wiped out by script generated killer stacks? Like one stack of dwarves versus 6 stacks of green skins that came out of nowhere? I could have easily beat two, but the other 4 stacks razed by cities.

I was able to win at Total War games but these script events are hard to respond to?

This game is shit. It's not what games are supposed to be. It isn't fun, it's crushing. It chews up so much time and then destroys everything you built in about 2% of the time it took to build it. game over. If you can manage to slog through the first 10 turns on easy mode, well done. It's not easy. You start to spread... you clear all 16 of the heads up messages at the start of each turn, 10+ enemy heroes ruining everything, rebellion, ambushes fkn everywhere, diplomatic changes for god knows what reasons, civs destroyed across the map. Feel good kinda stuff. Early on you slog and slog with one good army, maybe 2 smaller. You try and train up heroes to go alongside but their development is slow and when something big comes into frame, they die and you start again... get to turn 50ish and you build up 2 armies, healthy plot of land and some semblance of control. Those 2 armies are all you can afford with this. You've got limited building options so army (stables and barracks => upgrades for those for unit types) and income (diplomatic trade and pottery/weaving houses) are your two choices. You cant handle anything else. These armies are great together and carry you over 100 turns and build/defend the empire. But you can't grow those armies, too expensive. You get 2 armies, quality, good unit types that you developed and all. Then sometime before turn 100, all your alliances get cancelled, trade cancelled. Everything gets cancelled. Out of the blue. You're slogging away with the common undead enemy and then, BAM! You're left with no-one. Not too bad, got like 15 settlements, good income, two big armies, lotta ground to cover but it ain't too bad. Then those old friends declare war with you, civs on the other side of the map declare war. Dwarves, Orc and Elves from the south who you haven't even seen yet declare war, the constant undead threat from the east and the flip of allies from the west and North. Mmkay, strange... everyone hates me. I'm surrounded. Loss of income but thank all hell I built those weaving houses. Wouldn't have any army. And then turn 100ish. Chaos... has entered the chat. 6 stacked armies of heavily armoured, magical, smash and bash armies roll down from the top of the map and down the middle wiping everything out. EVERYTHING. The game gives you a recap of your ass whooping, immediately post ass whooping. It's like someone takes an eraser from the top of the map straight to you and through your little homesteads in like 5 turns. Your 2 armies are spread of course. One army gets put over a fence post up near your northern border by the new 'chaos crew' and your emperor can't make it cuz he is getting cock blocked in the south by like 4 heroes from the elves, dwarves and dead preventing any movement. You can't get rid of those enemy heroes by the way. Assassination? That's a fancy way of wasting turns. Doesn't work. You can have a witch hunter from day dot (as i did), train this guy up to be a buffed master assassin and he will hit 2/15 in the field. anything higher level than him? Forget it, don't bother. In fact. The game won't let you try. Risk>reward or some shit. Game says no. But all g. My emperor can sit here in some attrition field in the my own borders cuz the influence of these enemy heroes and my 50 turns and 20k+ investment in buildings was wrong? maybe? I don't know. But now my homes are killing me and i can't leave or fix the problems. At this point you are the oxford English dictionary definition of 'useless'. There is nothing you can do. Lords/Heroes are blocked, attacks from everyone and sackings that you can't defend or afford to rebuild from. That Injustice Crew of 6 from before have left, they sacked everything north. You've got 3 regions still though. standing up to the undead wave that just keeps taking pot shots at you with this never ending pool of resources and legendary characters that pop-up. Fend of a couple hits from the dwarves that sack you a couple times while your back is turned as youre facing the undead. Holding on, might be on a comeback. turn 125ish. NOPE. Remember all those strange dwarves, orc and elven civs that declared war on you? well they just rolled in south. With huge armies. Against your atrophy'd army and beat-up, unsupported emperor who is averaging 200+ kills a fight. The dead that the emperor has been holding off are suddenly huge, the elves are huge and the dwarves are unbeatable tough. Even for your upgraded army. You're surrounded and unable to move. your army gets wiped. But here is the best bit. You keep hitting next turn to see what happens. You've been here a while, might as well look. Emperor keeps coming back every 4 turns, dies again and again. whatever. But these 4+ civs with nothing in common with each other, other than you, are taking turns besieging your last bit of real-estate. You can't recruit while being besieged so you can't even get your emperor out. You're just being hand balled around for like 20 turns before someone invades and then game over. like wtf? That wasn't fun. I just got donkey kicked outta nowhere after spending ages building a good diplomatic network, income and try to start building a lil something. The other civs were experts at making you chase tail and undo 30 mins of work in 1 turn. These beastmasters draw you away and get attacked on the other side of your pond by the undead. Pulling these draw 4 wild cards out of nowhere and expecting a rebuild after regressing almost all of your progress repeatedly. And then the overall game limits how far you can go and makes you limp for so long before ending it all and turning the entire map against you and send in the overpowered, unbecoming from the north. no warning, just "here you go, a hand grenade and also... the room is on fire". FUN!
Good game

[b] Achievements. Hard, grindy and a bit costly. [/b]

[h1] The Game [/h1]
The first turn-based strategy game in the series in the Warhammer Fantasy universe. A solid introduction to the games but lacks a bit in mechanics, limited races, map size and variety. 

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
If this is your first time playing a Warhammer strategy game (or any other titles in the same genre from Creative Assembly), then prepare for a difficult run. The achievements span over all of the available races plus additional races that are locked behind DLC where you must complete several objectives, which include winning on the higher difficulties. Due to lack of balancing and a very strong AI it can become very difficult and even require restarts of multiple campaigns to figure out the proper strategies. Luckily there are guides and tips available online that can point you in the right direction but ultimately it comes down to personal skill. Speaking as a seasoned veteran that spent 1000 hours in Warhammer 2 before jumping into Warhammer 1 it was vastly easier to learn and finish this game in comparison to others, which could very well be the same in your case. The time to complete could range from 100 hours or less to well above 300+ hours.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
At its core the game is a pretty good strategy game that is quite addictive and fun despite flaws in balance, mechanics and required DLC. I therefore strongly recommend to pick it up on sale as it does feel lackluster in comparison to Warhammer 2 and 3.

As someone who has been with the Total War series since the days of Rome 1 (original, not remastered), this game certainly has faults: auto-resolve armies being too strong, lot of the nuances in previous total wars gone, Warriors of Chaos being a boring faction to play. With that said, there is one thing that makes this game enjoyable: the playable races. Shogun 2 was most damning regarding this problem, but most total wars could have samey rosters/faction mechanics resulting in samey playthroughs once you figured out "the meta". Certainly some factions did stand out (Aztecs in Medieval 2, Steppe Tribes in Rome 2), but meta strategy tends to be the same across factions in a given game. In contrast, this game had truly unique rosters, and factions mechanic while bare-bones compared to earlier games, further made each race stand out leading to different metas (Balanced roster for Empire, supercharged Lord with supporting troops for Vampire Counts, etc.). Whether this was worth all the aforementioned downsides is something I haven't quite figured out, but I am looking forward to playing the sequel (as soon as I get a better computer, because I tend to not upgrade my PC for a long time and how well this game runs on it clearly shows its age).

I played WH II first, which is one of my favorite games. I picked up WH I on sale. Normally, I would think that the later version are better, including the latest tech developments, etc. It's true in this case in some minor ways. But what I like better with this game is that, playing as the Empire, one only needs to unite the empire with its fractured parts and defeat the several Chaos invasions. Done in under 20 hours. WH II is so vast and with only the story-driven Vortex campaign it takes much longer, over 100 hours longer. With the many more tribes, each turn can take quite some time to process. There are a few UI improvements, too, but basically the two games play the same. If you like one, you'll like the  other. Very replayable. 85/100

Back in the Stone Age of the early 90s, my cousins were addicted to a little known game called "Civilization". My family was really poor and couldn't afford a PC at the time so I missed a lot of big early games. Unfortunately, I eventually got my hands on CIvilization 2 Gold, which absolutely consumed my life for over a year. 4X games have always been one of my favorite genres; I knew going into this that it'd be dangerous for me and it too ended up consuming my life for a while. Warhammer-flavored Total War is a fantastic experience once you get past the learning curve, but it's not flawless (yet). 

Total War: Warhammer plays like a 4X game with slimmed down diplomacy (it's called Warhammer for a reason) but vastly expanded combat. In fact, battles are the real focus here and are part of why the series isn't considered a 4X game. Sure you could auto-resolve that deathball fight, but wouldn't it be more satisfying to slaughter that stack that just razed your city? That's what this game really boils down to: pure fun. There's no shame in dropping a boring campaign or auto-resolving those last few tedious fights. I've had several campaigns that I played for a few nights and just dropped to try out another faction or rerolled out of frustration. This honestly might be the most fun I've had with a strategy game ever and it's only the first game in the trilogy.

When I first tried playing this, I only got about two hours in before dropping it out of frustration and boredom. The difficulty curve here is more like mountain climbing, even with the handholding tutorial and in-game help system. Initially, the lore was a big turn-off too; on the surface, Warhammer Fantasy looks like knock-off Tolkien, but the more you dig, the better it gets. Dwarfs look like your cookie cutter stereotypical dwarves for example, but they're extremely petty and have a Great Book of Grudges to record every slight against them for vengeance. It's basically the inverse of W40k's lore quality, which gets dumber and edgier the deeper you dig (look up Angron and Perturabo for some real high school garbage). A lot of the lore is loosely based on a mishmash of Tolkien with the real world, but where else are you going to see goblins riding spiders into battle against Strigoi?

The main complaints I've seen against this game are about the AI but I rarely had issues with it. Enemies rarely declare obviously bad attacks, they position themselves smartly for group attacks and follow-ups, and know when to run from your deathstacks. They obviously cheat with free resources (especially Chaos's Heroes) but that's standard for the genre for decades now. The only AI complaint I have is how frustrating diplomacy can be: to put it simply, some factions just don't know when to raise the white flag. Diplomacy is the weakest point in this game (even worse than sieges), but it sounds like they eventually got some things right by the third game.

My only big issues with this game is that I wish there were more maps and more endgame options. Each race has wildly different victory conditions, with most factions of those races having specific conditions on top of that. However, they all require that the Big Bad of Chaos be put down, regardless of their position on the map. Human factions not allied with Chaos seem almost braindead against the invasion but it's hard to disparage their struggle; Chaos (and their allies) rely heavily on Large/Monster units, which require units with the Anti-Large trait to have a chance against them. Most other factions until Chaos comes knocking have few Large units, meaning you'll have to drastically reshape your armies in order to finish a campaign. This again brings me back to my earlier point: I quit several games when the Chaos invasion started just because I didn't feel like dealing with them again. 

Then again, if there were more maps and less Chaos, this would just be another 4X game with a colorful fantasy skin. TW:W is a fantastic game but I need to take a break from it because it just consumes my life. I might return to this later to try out some more factions or the additional two campaigns, but I'll probably move onto the sequel. After all this though, I don't know if I'd recommend actually playing this version of the game. The main reason to purchase this is to play the Mortal Empries map in 2 (the expanded map from this game). There's not much reason to play this version unless you specifically want to play on The Old World map (which is about a third of the actual world map). Both Total War and Warhammer games go on sale several times a year, so if you're interested in this, wait for a sale.

Pricing addendum: This game is massively overpriced, still sitting at $59.99 after almost seven years. There's a lot of expensive DLC, but you really only need to buy the factions you want to play. All of the factions are still in the game, but you just can't start as them or Confederate with them. I'd recommend watching gameplay walkthroughs or faction tutorials on YouTube before purchasing any of the DLC just because of how expensive it is.

It's a simpler game than its sequels, but still very complex compared to other games, and it has aged better than most people say. As much as I like TWW2, this one is the most cohesive in terms of visuals and design since it follows a single design philosophy and all of the assets and shaders were created for the same engine. The later games look and play well, but they also ported in assets from the previous game and had to rebalance the older races to match the power creep from the later ones with varying degrees of success. There's more to game balance than increasing stat buffs and these races all seem fit for the same purpose on a conceptual level. Also, unlike some of the small touches like the intro sequences that became simpler from game to game as the number of races increased, this one had full cutscenes for every race. While the later games have lots of quality of life changes and overall turned out very well, there's still something about this one that makes it my favorite.

As a fan of the Total War: WARHAMMER game series, I see the current recession as an opportunity to make the game even better. It's no secret that every game has its weaknesses and there is always room for improvement. But as a long-time fan, I also know that Creative Assembly is a company that works hard to hear feedback from players and improve the game experience.

One of the positive aspects of Total War: WARHAMMER is the depth of the game. The game offers a variety of races, units and strategies to explore. Each faction has its own strengths and weaknesses, which makes the game even more interesting and challenging. In addition, the game offers a fascinating background story that provides players with an unforgettable experience.

Another positive aspect of Total War: WARHAMMER is the graphics and gameplay. The game looks fantastic and draws players into the world of Warhammer. The battles are epic and fast-paced, offering a high level of excitement and challenge. The game is also very accessible and easy to learn, making it suitable for any type of gamer.

Overall, I think Total War: WARHAMMER is a great game and that the developers are working hard to make it even better. As a fan of the series, I am excited to see what the future holds and look forward to exploring more of this fantastic world.

I picked up this game last December as part of a Steam sell, and it is 'ok' for $40 (including all DLC). I have been a TW fan since Shogun 1, and I own, or have owned, Rome 1, Medieval 1 & 2 (MTW2 is my fave), Empire, Napoleon, and now Warhammer 1. I stopped buying TW games when I read bad reviews for Rome 2 AND heard that CA was restricting the possible mods. 

In ALL of the previous titles I would sink hundreds to thousands of hours playing and always want to come back for more. What makes the TW series is, IMHO, the mods. MTW2 & Rome 1 both had a plethora of mods (still do), and the MTW2 BOTET version of Warhammer is just superior to this game as far as my personal enjoyment goes.

There are a few things I like about Warhammer; leader/character leveling system, spells, flying units, corruption system, heroes, diplomacy improvements, army stances (raid, channel, etc) and the overhead strategic view. 

However... that is about it. Graphics was never a big thing for me, I am more focused on gameplay. The Campaign UI is just annoying. Sometimes when I try to select a Lord I will keep selecting a Hero or city instead, even when I am clicking directly on the Lord I want to select. I usually have to choose the Lord twice before I get his movement overlay. In MTW2 and Rome 1 there was an annoying army animation when sieging cities that sometimes caused problems, but in Warhammer you can get frustrated with almost any action.

The battles don't feel very good, just two blobs running into each other. In MTW2 BOTET I would get a feel for massive battles with battle lines clearly visible. In this game I pretty much just pick a spot I want to fight on, and then make a 'doomball' of units and throw them at the AI. Spells keeps things interesting (had fun moments with Mannfred on his Zombie Dragon flying around and spell-slinging). Ultimately, though, the battles are just lacking compared to earlier titles.

The map is also very empty compared to the BOTET mod for MTW2. Not being able to play all factions (even with DLC) was another reason I stayed away from this game for so long. But that is not new, CA has been trying to make playing all factions from the get go a chore since Empire.

The unit selection per faction is acceptable, and it is neat how different factions have to act differently in order to be successful. I usually pick 3 - 4 unit types I like and then only build those units for my armies, so I don't need 4 or 5 different cavalry options, or ten different infantry choices.  

The AI is kinda lacking, but that isnt new to the series. In fact, if you have units that can hide and there is sufficient concealing terrain, you will find it hard to lose any battles, no matter the odds. This is especially noticeable during defensive battles when one of your settlements is attacked. Just break your army up into 3+ sections, all hiding, and watch the AI struggle to find them all before the battle timer runs out.

Speaking of settlements.... I dont like the system used in this game. I like being able to build all structures in a single settlement and this game forces you to specialize your towns. Your basic towns also dont have walls, or even buildings, when attacked, so you can forget all about the glorious feeling of sending your army to fight block by block through an enemy town, or the heroic defensive battles on town walls. Provincial Capitals have walls and buildings, but the 'sieges' are very mediocre compared to previous titles (except maybe Empire & Napoleon, those games had ugly sieges also).

Overall, I don't hate this game, and for $40 it was acceptable. But it will never be a game I sink thousands of hours into, as I did Rome 1 or MTW 1 & 2. It is just does not have that good of a feel, overall - and the decision by CA to limit the modding options will severely limit how long this game remains on my hard drive.

If you could have Warhammer units fighting across historical Europe, Japan, or Middle-Earth, that would go very very far in extending the lifespan of this game (though the UI needs a fix AND the battles need to be tweaked so they are comparable to MTW2 or Rome 1).

The game feels like a cash grab, and I imagine WH2 won't be any different so I am probably not going to buy any more TW games. As a player I loath DLC most of the time (just give me the full game instead of charging me $50+ and *then* charging me $10 ten more times for access to features that really should be part of the basic game package (thus making the new series of TW games cost in excess of $100 (actually closer to $160 with all DLC). 

I understand I am in the minority on this matter *shrugs* to each his own. If you don't mind paying $100+ per title to get all the DLC then I suppose this system is for you.

EDIT SOME TIME LATER......

Just sunk another 50 hours into the game, tried out lots of the steam mods. Still cannot recommend it, and this will be my last TW game I purchase in all probability.

It just gets soooo boring. Beat the game (effectively, didnt bother grinding thru once victory was super obvious) with VC twice, Empire once, and Chaos twice. The mods helped ALOT, only reason I could keep going for 50 hours.

However, the mods are extremely limited in scope and ability compared to MTW2 (ie all the mods have to be in the Warhammer World, variant world map mods for other genres unavailable), and it is a pain to "self-mod" and "self-tweak" the game to make it more enjoyable for me.

Kudos to all the modders that powered thru it!

In BOTET mod for MTW2 I could, for example, completely change my starting location, army, income, and settlements in under an hour. My last project was to move the "Tzeentch Faction" into the heart of the Empire, start with one settlement, and establish a human-centric sorcerer kingdom with limited daemonic summons and help defend the Empire against outside forces.

Was alot of fun, and different. Good Luck doing all that in under an hour (or two, if you wanted to completely alter your unit and building trees).

Modding for this just required too much exertion; too many changes and not seeming to be worth the hassle given the fact that the Lords seem locked (cannot even rename them) and the world itself is a so limited to just this one map.

In MTW2, if I was so inclined, I could create my own custom faction without too much difficulty (I always just added units and textures from other MTW2 mods for ease of function). Time consuming? Yes, but only because it was so easy you had so many options.

I didnt even hate the BMDB; just save often and do things in the correct order and it worked fine.

This... just a mess IMHO. Needs two 3rd Party programs just to start. MTW2 was virtually all text-based. Even the scripting was easy, and even easier because most of the time you could copy/paste/tweak what you needed.

Now, all that being said, there are good things about this game. I like the spells, I like the skill trees. I like the graphics, I like the fact they finally seemed to fix that annoying moving flag animation that made it easy to misclick a stack you were sending to reinforce a besieging stack.

I dont like the fact all armies have to have generals, but I can live with that.

So... for $40.... yeah I guess I got a fair deal for 80 hours. I might even get around to pumping those numbers up to 100 or so. 

But, still, it is a terrible disappointment compared to its illustrious past. Ever since Empire CA has been going in this direction, so its goodbye TW for me. MTW2, Shogun 1, Rome 1, and even Empire will probably have a place on my HD for a long time to come. This game and (I presume) the rest of the "modern" TW series?

Whereas you previously needed all 3 games, Total War: WARHAMMER, Total War: WARHAMMER II and Total War: WARHAMMER III to play on the grand combined map, immortal empires, now you only need total war warhammer III to play on immortal empires.  Each is well worth the asking price of $60 and I am not even a big RTS fan. Luckily the games and DLC regularly go on sale, just pick up the base games and skip the DLC if you like a taste of what is on offer. You might feel daunted by the number of DLCs but most of them are extremely good value, especially compared to paradox's titles. You can still play AGAINST the DLC content even if you do not own said DLC, you merely cannot play AS the DLC content.

Each title has iterative quality of life features like being able to trade territories or to borrow an allied army or to recruit units from your military ally. The third game even fixes some very longstanding bugs like your cavalry unit running circles around routing units instead of finishing them off (while introducing some other new bugs)

I haven't played the other Total War Warhammer installments nor am I particularly knowledgeable in the finer details of Warhammer Lore. So I am reviewing this game as a stand alone fantasy total war for those that have played previous historic total wars in the past and are wondering if this game is worth it, specifically in 2023 and at this high price (but perhaps you're here because this installment is on sale and curiosity has gotten the better of you) 

The game is good

It's very good, imaginative, thematic and uniquely stylized. 

The faction diversity is where this game truly shines. Not only are factions wildly different aesthetically but mechanically as well, in ways only a fantasy total war can provide. For example, the vampire factions have armies made up of zombies and skeleton forces that won't route. Being undead they will fight until the last unholy abomination drops. The forest elves have monstrous tree creatures, The "Empire" has steam punk tanks and the Dwarfs have steam punk helicopters. The Norscans (should you get the DLC) have Willy Mammoths and the Greenskin races have..... globlin archers riding wolves into combat. But it's not only the battles, different factions have different economic layouts, resources and currencies as well as options of what to do with captured prisoners. Bretonnia has peasant economy which ties in the peasant population into the economy and military. So lots of peasant archers in your army means back home growths is significantly stiffed. Several factions have buffs and characteristics that make raiding/ pillaging the economic go-to. Dwarfs like to trade and mine etc. Some factions have providence wealth tied with population growth and more advanced economies that take massive hits should production centers get razed / sacked. 


This world diversity in the campaign leads to some very engaging and interesting battles, most factions field some form of artillery, melee/range infantry, cavalry. Some have the option to recruit flying units, huge monstrous creatures steampunk machines. Watching a tree God throw down with a giant Troll is a sight to behold. Now it's not perfectly balanced, some factions are more OP than others. The aforementioned vampire counts while having un-route-able units, doesn't help much when they all suck / are all killed off before the human foes succumb to their desire to flee the undead wastelands. There are also Chaos Warriors, basically death stacks of 4-6 full armies of unholy abominations that are a challenge to overcome. (Basically the Mongols / Huns from other games but unable to negotiate). 

On to the aesthetics, the factions by design and virtue of being in a fantasy game are unrecognizably different, even in similar races. The "Human Race" Includes the steam punk musket wielding Empire, feudal kingdoms with a medieval french flavor, Norsca, marauders  from the North, and a bunch of unplayble minor factions of vaguely Slavic inspired fiefdoms that get got by the aforementioned vampires, chaos warriors, a bunch of roaming hordes like the beastman etc about 30 turns in to any game. 

The game itself is a tad simpler as most factions don't necessary have to worry about food, just happiness, and "unholy corruption". The vampire and chaos corruption that if left unchecked will make seemingly happy Providences rebel with undead / chaos armies. (Also corrupted regions have huge attrition penalties). 

The AI can make intricate calculations and the difficulty does factor into how aggressive / defensive other factions will be towards you. The factions themselves also have vastly different goals. Which is nice as no faction can truly "conquer the world" the Dwarf cave settlements can't be occupied by non-dwarfs, the entire far north area of Nosca can't be settled by anyone other than the Norscan tribes, They themselves can only occupy/ colonize coastal settlements outside of Norsca. The death stacks of the Beastmen and chaos warriors can't occupy or colonize, so they just burn the world down. The humans and vampires and greenskins can all occupy the same settlements but to truly expand into them it's expensive / time consuming. So in many cases it's better to just raze everything. 

The world map isn't to large but is definitely diverse. Even with a medium map size, geographic elements make it feel much vaster than it is with mountains, forest and wastelands taking many turns to traverse. 

Multiplayer exists but no ones playing

The Game also runs exceptionally well of the Steam Deck, and is somehow the most optimized total war for this platform (Out of the 4-5 TW titles I tried) 

This is a solid installment that is worth your time should you give it a chance.

I played the sequel, Warhammer 2, for a "little while" - after 300 hours I had to delete it. The damn game was so addictive. It has its problems. However, this "hidden" gem aka. the original is in its own way even more fun than the sequel.

Sure, it doesn't have all the cool features of the sequel. For example, I really wish I could abandon settlements, but it makes me think more carefully who I'll confederate with or what I'll do to a settlement I conquered. There's much less content than in the sequel, the game could get boring if you rush through content like it's a race. However, there's still plenty of styles of playing and several races to pick up. I even enjoy the much-maligned pre-rework Chaos and Beastmen.

It took a while to get into the game. The endless amount of info boxes popping up are anti-fun for me, I want to play the game, not study it. However after several campaign defeats I got into the game and even the battles. I still struggle with tougher battles, especially when there's more than 20 units to control, but hey there's autoresolve for us smooth brains. I return to the missing features, you can't see what units you'll lose in autoresolve and once again the bright side is I have to pick my battles more carefully. 

It's a fun game. It's nearly not as addictive as the sequel, which I count as a plus. Not recommended because of the full price tag, buy this when it's on discount.

I've mostly played historical total war titles for years and never touched Warhammer but recently I gave it a shot and I gotta say I'M LOVING IT! And excited to try the 2nd and 3rd game as well. Generally it's all a matter of taste if you're going to like this setting. If you grew up loving high fantasy settings such as LOTR, Narnia, the Warhammer universe or any similar titles that encompasses Orcs, Dwarfs, Elves and other unique races then you're in for a good time.

Just some things to bring up when I was first coming into it:
If you've played Shogun 2, Rome 2, Atilla, Empire and Napoleon and are a fan of cinematic locked combat animations, you're not gonna see much of it here especially when it comes to infantry vs infantry. There are in fact some interesting animations with giants and other creatures when they fight smaller enemies but for the majority of the fights they're mostly bashing at each other but in terms of gameplay arguably this is a better system since individual fights won't be invulnerable during their animations.

There are no reload animations for guns and artillery, a lack of gunpowder smoke compared to what you'd see from Napoleon or Empire. The bullet projectiles from guns slightly have an arch which is unrealistic.

For sure there are many issues that others may mention especially with this total war engine but overall looking into bigger picture and appreciating the new mechanics from an epic high fantasy setting, I love it.

I also do not like the price of the Blood DLC which should be priced lower but I gotta say after getting these effects it adds so much weight to the soldiers duking it out.

Idk if it's just me but when you auto-resolve battles in Warhammer they seem to perform better with less casualties compared to other total war titles especially in normal difficulty. I suggest downloading a mod that buffs the the AIs auto-resolve in order to push you to fight battles manually since you experience the game better and it adds more meaning to your recruited troops rather than just being a number generator.

I have absolutely no clue why this game is so huge. 

The start of the game is a tsunami of information that makes no sense for someone just starting. 
The actual war is so boring, everyone moves so slowly, everyone dies so slowly, and artillery feels like it would take 10 min for them to kill anything. 

The story is far from gripping. 

I played on easy mode with the Empire since the game said that their start is easy as well since I have no experience in games like this. 

On easy mode, I got completely demolished by an AI that ambushed me 10 minutes into the game. 
Their army was triple the size of mine and yes I recruited MANY units early on, was actually getting worried about the upkeep costs. 

Despite playing on the suggested easy faction and easy difficulty I get defeated 10 min after the introduction to the game, quite unfairly. 
An AI with a much bigger army than you LEGIT pops out of the woods and attacks you when you barely even know whats going on. 

This game wasted my money and 18 hours of my time. Not one minute was enjoyable. 

The old Lord of the Rings strategy games were way more fun, and a lot easier to understand, the gameplay was actually thrilling and a lot more responsive than this modern Warhammer game. Please don't listen to the positive reviews, these people are massive fans of the Warhammer universe and the mechanics of this game. I really don't see the fun factor. 

I even saw a Reddit post where someone asked the Warhammer community why people even play the game because it literally isn't fun to play, people just love the story and the war mechanics.

This game was my entry into the Total War franchise and I am absolutely blown away by practically every aspect. The campaign map is simply incredible. The lore of Warhammer Fantasy is fascinating, surprising and compelling. Running a battle is wonderfully responsive and entertaining. Mechanically and thematically, this is a class act from campaign start to glorious campaign end.

Even the pricing, while egregious, isn't a major upset, as I got over 100 hours out of it, which works out to be less than an Australian dollar an hour. Yes, it's an older game and should be reduced in price, but it still delivers a premier product and I can't find it in myself to be annoyed.

Want a grand strategy game where a giant spider, unit of Pegasus and a magical cannon can fight each other? Then check out this Cheapness affordable gaming review of Total War: WARHAMMER!

This is the first Total War game that takes place in a fantasy setting with vampires, orcs etc. to kill each other in droves instead of an historic time period. So they had much larger creative freedom in unit design (making for some epic spectacles) and even the quotes they show during loading screens (Did the developers just make these up?). The game uses the less encumbered Total War style of the newer games in the franchise but it does have one or two nice design decisions that increase the validity of certain lesser used tactics such the inability of seemingly all the factions to conquer all cities... some are restricted to their folk type! Meaning being allies with them or burning it to the ground all of a sudden have merit because you can't occupy that territory. It looks nice (Even if some design elements remind you of fairy-tales). But it's not a cheap game really. It is indeed rather decadent! Comparatively short to other Total War titles (Eats into the value for money) and it isn't the easiest game in the world to run or download. But worthwhile nonetheless!

When this game came out, it is one of the best total war games if not the best ever.  The launch was flawless and the game was balanced.  After that the game starts to get more buggy and unbalanced.  After all the DLCs and all the new factions, the game is not balanced at all, and your game can easily get ruined by chaos tide / order tide, depending on randomness beyond your control.  So the developer just makes a bunch of DLCS and stick a new faction somewhere in the map.  When the new faction is put in the map, it always unbalances the game.  A lot of the time, all in a sudden, 60 turns in, you are facing a doomstack.  But if mods are installed, this is a good game nevertheless.

While it is generally consensus within the TWW community that each subsequent game may be the "superior" verson of the previous game, I nonetheless strongly suggest this game as a good starting point for the series, and the Total War franchise as a whole. The gameplay is solid and fun, with vast differences between factions, and puts you right into the lore of classic (pre-AoS) Warhammer.
