I was hesitant to get into this game. I have played a little of Total War in the past but I never really got the hang of it. Add on the fact that this game has all sorts of DLC and for a while I just didn't want to bother with it. 

On a whim I decided to try it. The game was on sale and I figured why not. Nearly 20 hours later and I just won my first campaign as the Empire! I struggled a bit at the start but by this point, I think I have a decent feel for the game. 

It's quite fun for what it is and is fantastic to just pass the time. Just load it up and play a few turns!
It's deep, fun, and it runs on my computer.  That's about all I need to recommend it!

Right now, this game offers endless replay-ability. so many factions and heroes to choose from and a huge campaign map to conquer. They fixed a lot of the performance issues too, it is a really solid game now and with mod enhancements, this total war title is going to have longevity like no other.

What stands out:
- Voice acting is really good
- Dinosaurs vs Undead
- Fully kitted lords is an army by itself
- Faction design oozes character, owing to the warhammer fantasy world it self
- Some units and heroes are over the top fun to use
A great start to the series, nowadays the only reason to buy this would be to own all the content, which gets "imported" in the later TW:WH games: races, lords, etc.

What the store page fails to mention is that you MUST have this game installed on a SSD ( solid state drive ) instead of a standard hard drive for it to be playable. If it's not on a solid state drive, then each battle takes several minutes to load, then several minutes to go back to the map screen. This happens despite my PC having  above the recommended specs and the graphics all turned to minimum settings. Apparently many other people have this issue and the only answer anyone has is that you MUST install this game on a SSD for it to run properly. Haven't yet decided if I'm going to try to push through the game or ask for a refund, but they really should on mention on the store page that a SSD IS NECESSARY FOR THE GAME TO RUN PROPERLY. 

Most of my play time so far has been loading screens. If they won't fix it, they should at least mention a SSD is necessary to play the game as not everyone has them.  By the way, all my other games in my account, some of which have higher requirements, run properly so it's just this particular game giving me the issue. If they won't fix the problem, they should change the recommended specs on the store page to reflect what IS necessary to play the game.

EDIT: I now have a SSD on my current PC so I can play this, and will start playing it. Doesn't seem like a bad game,  I just wish I knew beforehand that I needed a SSD to play this.
Its ok.

I usually don't like playing real-time strategy (RTS) games and prefer turn-based games with no time/turn limits because I like taking my time and thinking about what to do. This game appealed to me because of the large battles and fantasy theme, good reviews, and it was on sale for $15. This is my first Total War game.  I initially played normal and got my butt kicked. Then I played easy thinking it would be like a story mode--it wasn't: I got my butt kicked repeatedly, if not on the battlefield then in the campaign. But I watched videos and read sites and kept at it. At one point I questioned if I made a good decision buying this game, but what kept me coming back was the variety and complexity of the game: all of the factions are different, with different units, skill trees, game mechanics, and play styles. I tried different factions and kept losing, but was making incremental gains over time. After about 55 hours and many restarts, I finally won a campaign (on easy). I really like this game now (I still play on easy) and recommend it, but it has a steep learning curve and requires some persistence. If you're like me and generally don't like RTS, you can pause the battles and also put it into slow motion so that you can take your time and plan what to do. I also tend to play more for the campaign (which is turn-based) and auto-fight most battles (some of them require you to fight manually, which isn't bad, plus you can sometimes win a battle fighting manually when you would otherwise lose the auto-fight).

Oldie but Goldie. You can spend hours on this game, its a shame you have to buy the extra lords and races as dlc, but even without, the base game is massive. Cant wait to get my hands on II to try the Empires campaign. If you can, holding out for a price drop goes without saying, but i think this still holds up today as one of the best RTS games going. looks great with a few mods and it runs well even on my outdated system so having top end gear isn't a must as most of your time is zoomed out on the maps to see whats going on with troops. its a great time killer no mistake!

Now that this game has been out for a while, it has been polished to a perfect gem. This game is a masterpiece. Out of all the warhammers, this is my favorite. 

The graphics is smooth; the battles are glorious. Most importantly, compared to more recent warhammers, your fighters actually hit other fighters on the battlefield. More recent warhammers, for some reason, targeting is not that precise; and it looks like units are attacking thin air, while nearby enemies are registering a hit. Such little details are important for complete immersion. Otherwise, what's the point of a battle simulator. 

The game play itself is more focused than in subsequent games of the series. As time went on, additional races, abilities, etc. were added. If you ask me, I would say that many of the additions are unnecessary, fluff that sounds cool on paper and for moneymaking. I personally prefer a simpler world than a million shades of grey, the storytelling is more dramatic that way.

I also like the unpredictability of diplomacy. In the newer games of the series, the making offers/counter offers is easy, and the outcomes are very predictable. WH1 diplomacy always has this uncertainty about it, and element of risk. This older mechanic feels good; it makes you really pause and consider things before clicking the 'make offer/counter offer button.' 

WH1 world looks less cartoonny and more 'realistic,' both on the campaign map and on the battlefield. At first, I wasn't sure if I liked this realism. After all, the game is about magic. But then WH1 style grew on me, and now I love it. Somehow, WH1 art makes its fantasy world more believable. In my mind, I see WH1 world just like ours, only because of reasons, infused with the chaotic magic here and there. Basically, this makes it easier to connect with the WH1 world; I don't get tired of the world; one can easily imagine living in it without constantly trying to wake up.

Should you get this game or the newer ones? If you are new to the series, I would get this one to help you decide if WH is your cup of tea. If you like it, you will end up getting WH2 and WH3 most likely anyway. However, your WH1 purchase won't be wasted, as you will be able to use WH1 races in the newer games. I have all three games and all DLCs for them; and WH1 so far is my favorite. To recap, out of the three games, it has the most immersive battles that you can zoom in and watch, tight game play, simple and engaging setting; a world that is both magic and, at the same time, is kinda like ours.
A very fun strategy game, especially when modded. Without mods it can be a bit bland in comparison to the second or third in the row, but still worth a look!
Definitely one of the better more immersive games of its genre.

TLDR: Warhammer + Total War?  YES!  But not overmuch replay value.

Brilliant fusion of a classic table-top wargame with a classic virtual wargame.

Pros:
* Meaty combat - every charge feels like it packs punch and the importance of tactical manoeuvres is not lost.
* Mighty heroes - characters are tough and deadly, while this is contrary to the realism most Total War titles, the feel of epic, over-the-top heroism is not inappropriate in the Warhammer universe.
* Cool toys - undead monsters, dragons, wizards, and all manner of weird and wonderful units in the toolbox for you to play with

Cons:
* The existence of Beastmen when you're not playing Beastmen - while an important part of the Warhammer lore and a worthwhile inclusion in the game, their ability to appear at random, with overpowered units and capacity to out-pace your armies on the campaign map make them incredibly annoying.  More a distraction from the main game than a real addition to it.
* Only one way to play - the game focuses heavily around the story of the "Storm of Chaos", Archaon's great invasion of the Old World.  While a fun story, once you'e been through it a couple of times, there's no real way to play the game that doesn't result in your faction becoming a super-power, beating Archaon's hordes, and then just mopping up a largely ruined map.  You will fight world-wide Beastmen and Chaos invasions regardless of your own faction EVERY.  SINGLE.  TIME.

All in all, a very enjoyable and mechanically sound proof of concept, but a sore lack of variation in campaign play.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

Total War: Warhammer is a great game, that combines the classic Total War hybrid of turn-based and real-time-strategy with the Warhammer Fantasy universe. Anyone who likes the Total War Series and fantasy is going to like this game, even though, like all Total War games, it is not without its faults. 
The Total War typical gameplay is something I will not describe at length, because it should be well known at this point and even if not, it generally works very well and is always fun even for those who have never touched such a game before. There are quite a few additions to the classic gameplay in this game however, almost all of them based on the new setting, for example the addition of magic and flying units. 
Something that the Total War games have always been is visually impressive and this game is no exception. The game also suits the fantasy genre very well and there is a lot of lore and little details to find all over the world. 
There are however a few not so great things about it aswell, most of them have been faults of Total War games for a long time. One of them is the AI, which isn't very bright and to compensate that, it gets massive bonuses which makes it less fun to play on higher difficulties. Another problem is, that since Rome II: Total War you almost exclusively play siege battles. The only specific problem for this game is, that those siege battles are always the same and after some time are just no fun to play, because the enemies always have towers which shoot down half your army before it reaches the walls. You also have no other way of attacking walled settlements, because all the siege maps are basically the same and only the visuals differentiate them from each other. Where you had in previous Total War games, siege battles where you could attack from all sides and have some sort of strategy, you cannot do that here and that is my main point against this game, because you fight so many siege battles. 

Pros:
+ classic Total War gameplay
+ a lot of Fantasy lore 

Cons:
- AI
- siege battles

All in all still 8/10 points for me, since I am a huge fantasy fan, maybe not so much for people who are not that into it.

I'm not recommending not because the game is bad. Just to let this out of the way first, I'm new with the Total War franchise so this is mostly a problem that have occurred to me as a new player of the series.

With my PC, the game loads way too long to the point where the loading screen is longer than the battle itself. After doing some research it seemed like the problem is that I've downloaded the game on a Hard Drive Disk(HDD) instead of my Solid State Drive (SSD). I might be wrong on this one, but it seemed like this is pretty much every Total War games in general

For those who's not good with computer, go to documents and click to 'this pc', the Windows(C) is an SSD while the rest should be Hard Drive.

This becomes a problem for me since I don't have much storage for my SSD (it contains mostly personal work stuff and it helps makes softwares like Photoshop and ect to run faster for my personal gain), and since Total War games tend to be very heavy, I have no choice but to download it on Hard Drives which forces me to wait way too long to play. I wish I knew about this because the load time is infinitely faster with SSD.

My advice for you is that if you want to get a Total War game in general, make sure you have storage for SSD so you won't have to wait for really long load times like I did.

Total War: WARHAMMER
The Old World echoes to the clamour of ceaseless battle. The only constant is WAR!

A fantasy strategy game of legendary proportions, Total War: WARHAMMER combines an addictive turn-based campaign of epic empire-building with explosive, colossal, real-time battles. All set in the vivid and incredible world of Warhammer Fantasy Battles.

Command five wholly different races: Bretonnia, the Empire, the Dwarfs, the Vampire Counts and the Greenskins, each with their own unique characters, battlefield units and play style.

Lead your forces to war with powerful Legendary Lords from the Warhammer Fantasy Battles World, arming them with fabled weapons, armour and deadly battle magic; hard-won in individual quest chains.

For the first time in a Total War game, harness storms of magical power to aid you in battle and take to the skies with flying creatures, from ferocious dragons and wyverns to gigantic griffons.



Additional Free Content
Total War: WARHAMMER launched to critical acclaim in May 2016. Since then, a wealth of free content has been added, including the recent addition of Bretonnia as the fifth playable race in the Old World.
As well as this additional race, the rich world of Total War: WARHAMMER has been expanded since release with the inclusion of four new Legendary Lords, brand new units, new Lores of Magic and over 30 bespoke maps for single and multiplayer battle. These updates are available for free to all new and existing players.

Hundreds of hours of gameplay await you at the dawn of a new era. Total War: WARHAMMER brings to life a world of legendary heroes, towering monsters, flying creatures, storms of magical power and regiments of nightmarish warriors.
Lead Extraordinary Races
The Chivalrous knights of Bretonnia, the valiant men of the Empire, the vengeful Dwarfs, the murderous Vampire Counts and the brutal Orcs and Goblins of the Greenskin tribes. Each Race is wholly different with their own unique characters, campaign mechanics, battlefield units and play style.
Command Legendary Characters
March your forces to war as one of 12 Legendary Lords from the Warhammer Fantasy Battles World, arming them with fabled weapons, armour, mounts and deadly battle magic as you uncover their tales through a series of unique narrative quest chains.


Conquer this World
The very first Total War game to feature a fantasy setting. In the Old World Campaign, experience incredible depth and the freedom to conquer as you see fit across a gigantic sand-box map. Crafted from a twisted magical landscape and populated with an incredible array of awesome and deadly creatures, this is your chance to experience fantasy strategy on a scale as yet unimagined.
Unleash the Monsters
The battlefields of Total War: WARHAMMER echo to the swoop and roar of dragons, the bellowing of giants and the thundering hooves of monstrous cavalry. Towering beasts of both earthly and supernatural origin wade into the melee of battle, bringing death to hundreds of lesser creatures at a time.


Harness the Winds Of Magic
Smite your enemies with magical storms, melt their armour, sap their fighting spirit or bolster your own forces with devastating spells that split the sky and consume the battlefield. Rally wizards, shamans and necromancers to your armies and bend titanic and unpredictable energies to your whim.


Watch the Skies
Harass your enemies with Dwarfen Gyrocopters, plunge into their front-lines with terrifying Wyverns and achieve air superiority with a stunning array of flying units for the first time in a Total War game. Entirely new tactical possibilities present themselves as you deploy your winged minions in open battles and jaw-dropping sieges.
What is more, this title will go on to combine with two future sequels and additional content packs to create the largest Total War experience ever. An epic trilogy of titles that will redefine fantasy strategy gaming.

I have played every Total War game in the franchise. This is a slap in the face to what this series used to be. Rome 2 was the last good addition. Attlia was a stinker and so is this.

If you want an arcade style Total War than this is it. The battle animations have been dulled down ( No more watching individual units fight within a group as seen in Shogun 2 and Rome 2), The map is small and broken up into areas you can't capture and die if you try to cross (but need to cross), the game was completely bare when it came out. 6 or so DLC later (including a blood option which should be in the game already) and you get this polished turd.

Can't believe they are making 2 more of these dumps. Thanks..... Dicks

Mortal Empires.

I'm playing the original just so I get a feel for how it played, but if you are looking to get into the game, I'd start with the second and get the first if you want to play the extended campaign. This is also a game you want on an SSD not a hard drive, my computer is relative fast but the transitions between battles and the campaign map take minutes. Once it is cached the transitions speed up, but I literally was playing a game on my switch.

Overall this is like if you took Rome 2 and elements of gunpowder gameplay and mashed them together with awesome looking monsters. If you are a fan of the tabletop, I would say this is a nostalgic reimagining of the original. The base building is simplified from Rome 2's or Britannia, where there's really only one upward trajectory for a building type. Development has hard stops for non-capitals of provinces so it forces you to build important buildings in the capital, which is nice, but also restrictive.

The 4x map is not as grand and interesting as a Paradox games or an interesting simulation as a AGEOD, but it has a tabletop board game feel, which I like. The tactical battle controls are at peak TW. The faction unit selection is a little annoying and I hear 2 fixes them and makes the factions more nuanced in where they can setttle. I'm looking forward to transitioning soon after finishing a campaign or two. However I can already tell, I'm going to be playing something else in the background, as the load times are frustrating.

This game is hard as balls, which is good.
I would recommend playing on easy if you are a Warhammer fan that is relatively inexperienced with Total War games, as the game still offers a challenge on that difficulty and it gives you a chance to get to grips with the mechanics of a fairly deep and complex game.

They have the lore and setting down almost perfectly.
Everything feels legitimately Warhammer, the setting is appropriately grimdark, the Orcs are suitably derpy, and all the Dwarfs are British northerners workin' down t' coal mines and fightin' t' orcs.

Day one DLC Chaos has lost them some serious points with the community and was a PR miss-step on their part but I can forgive a lot when somebody actually makes a good Warhammer game.

It's also worth noting that the game works surprisingly well so soon after release, and I have encountered no bugs as of yet.

The lore is well respected with the caveat that the Dwarven AI could use use a few tweaks here and there. They are far too willing to make pacts and peace treaties, even alliances, with Orcs and Undead. I actually turned down a large sum of money for an alliance from a Dwarf faction as an Orc player in my campaign, just out of sheer instinctive disgust for any Dwarf that would do such a thing. It just felt like something no Dwarf, let alone a Dwarven king, would ever countenance.

That minor gripe aside, I'm having fun smashing stunties and being ded Orcy and I recommend this game.

Total war games have a history of being quite moddable, (it was a Warhammer mod for a previous title that almost certainly led to this game existing), so anything irritating to hardcore fans should hopefully be fixable. Who knows.

There is Steam Workshop support! Yay!


Some more notes after playing a bit more of the campaign:

Tends to run at about 40fps whereas the new Doom game runs at about 100fps on my rig, but the frame rate is not much of an issue for a game like this.

The adviser in the campaign just told me that I can't settle somewhere. It was empire territory. I was playing as Orcs. I happen to know that Orcs settle everywhere, being an incredibly hardy form of bipedal fungus, so that was a little off too, but it could be argued that that is just part of Total Wars mechanics. Still don't really see why it's necessary to restrict the play in that way but perhaps someone can enlighten me?

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Terrible entry in the Total War series. Warhammer is lower quality than prior games in almost every way. Rock paper scissors balancing makes the real time battles simply a matter of sending a unit at another unit which it will always counter with no need for strategic thinking whatsoever. No naval battles at all, siege battles consist of mindlessly charging your men at a single wall. Many units with unique models yet they are all functionally indistinguishable from each other. Even gun units function the same as crossbow units with incredibly low projectile velocity and even an arc to the bullet as if it were a crossbow bolt just as one example. The campaign is equally mindless and boring. The AI cheats and spams overpowered monster units (dragons especially) that it shouldn't be able to afford and the most viable strategy for countering this is to also spam entire armies of one overpowered monster unit whatever your faction is. The different factions initially appear quite different all with unique campaign mechanics but due to the reason just stated it doesn't even matter in the end they all turn out the same experience. In both the campaign and the real time battles there is no strategy or tactics. Of course there's also the criminal monetization policies of releasing so many overpriced dlcs that are basically more of the same but with different models, nothing a free mod couldn't otherwise provide. Churning out more terrible dlc touted as a full game which are all fully priced along with tons of tiny pointless dlc that despite costing $10-$20 provide basically nothing. If you respect your time and money at all I would suggest buying a previous entry in the total war series. If you're new to Total War and just wanted this because it's more recent, please get Shogun 2 or Atilla instead, as they are far more fun and engaging in every way. If you just want a Warhammer game then Medieval II has an excellent Warhammer mod for it and costs less than a dlc for this disgrace of a game.

I really like this total war game. It uses the fantastical setting to combine all the greatest total war mechanics from previous games, and it allows the game to have vastly contrasting factions. (Primitive, Powered by magic, powered by evil, technological, naturalistic. etc.)

Despite all these different ways of fighting and playing (as horde, in mountains, on land) this is one of the more easier total war games, where you spent less time checking many different properties of your state each round. Technologies, Units, Politics and Public Order are not overwhelming challenges, more so the fight for survival is what makes the game so much fun. The world looks bleak because there are these purely chaotic forces which keep you on your toes.

I previously posted a negative review because the AI cheats, but then Steam asked me on the store page for this game "You posted a negative review but kept playing for 100 hours, wanna edit your review?" I found that amusing, and I was like "Yeah, you got me there."

So... I changed my review. It was negative before and several criticisms are still valid, but there where some things I did to make the difficulty much worse on myself. 

This series can be a love/hate relationship depending on how you play, but obsessive either way. There is always MORE to learn and every tough lesson you receive will make you better. I could go on and on about features but YT content creators for this game do a better job showing you all the ways to play this. Go watch those if your thinking about jumping in first, because you will be jumping in to the deep end. If you like complexity and variety and cliff like learning curves then this is for you. If you divide how much you pay for a game by the number of hours you play it you will be down to less than a nickel with this one.

Let's start off by saying this game has it's flaws. That being said, what game doesn't, especially one this ambitious. In the later entries they don't even have the balancing perfect or even optimal. Again, all that being said, this trilogy of games, let alone Total War games and let alone Warhammer games, are some of the best and most engrossing I have ever played. Who knew fantasy Warhammer would translate perfectly to Total War. This original entry is beyond fun and with mods is extremely replayable. Also side note, some may consider it cheap but you can still earn achievements with mods on...and let me tell you that beating the game on Legendary difficulty is almost, not quite, but almost impossible to beat without certain mods for all but the most experienced and/or professional of gamers. As said the balancing can be wonky, some units are just OP and some magic is too. Cavalry in the first 2 games doesn't work how it should. Multiplayer has a crazy meta. But these are 10/10 games hands down and worth the time and deff worth picking up the first 2 on sale, as paying full price for at least the first one would be ridicoulous at this point, but eh...steam amirite. Start slow and really enjoy the early game as the endgame can become a slog, but beating a campaign is one of the most rewarding feelings in gaming IMO. Do yourself a favor and invest in this triology and do it on Steam for sales and mods.

This is a fine place for new players to Total War, Warhammer, the series, or even absolute beginners to start.   Many say "start with 2," but you'll need 1 to get the most out of 2 anyhow.   Highly recommend completing the registration process on the TWWH site as well -- they have a lot of downloadables there.

Note to those with integrated graphics on laptops:  While the game will technically run, and the world map is entirely playable, the 3D battlefield is so sluggish that you can barely input a minimal set of orders to react to the AI's movements.  Yes, you can auto-resolve on the main map, but the computer cannot calculate the idea of defeating overwhelming numbers by using strategy, tactics, and terrain.

So keep this on systems with dedicated GPUs, plenty of RAM, and plenty of CPU.  An SSD helps a bit, but a decent HDD is just fine too.  (Later games need an SSD for decent turn-speed.)

I have mixed feelings about this title. There are many positive things to say about it but also many negative ones, that folow TW series from quite a while.

[list]
    [*]Siege battles are a joke. They might have been deleted from this game and very little would change. Walls are more of an annoyance than a real problem and even the biggest garrisons have hard time defending against a single army.
    [*]No naval battles. I have no idea if there are any naval battles in WH universe so maybe that's the reason. Anyway they are crap as they are land battles.
    [*]Gun powder. This one is not even a joke, it's an entire circus. Rifle bullets fire in an arc, gunners can shoot even if they are in the 10th row and there is no reload animation. Empire TW from 2009 has much better gunpowder mechanics than this game.
    [*]No unit formations. Whis is my biggest problem with the game.
Why they removed something so crucial? There is not even a phalanx formation! I have no idea why devs made this decision.
    [*]No units' gear upgrades. In previous TWs blacksmith could improve the quality of soldiers gear. In this game it gives them xp instead. It seems that soldiers learn how to fight better by staring at blacksmith. I have no idea why make this change either.
    [*]No banners nor officers. It's a visual detail but I don't see why remove it. Especially when one of the first technologies of the Empire is literally a banner.
    [*]Soldiers bump into each other when units are moving through each other. It may seem like a small detail but it makes your units slowed down considerably and is annoying (especially because it wasn't the case in some older WT games). 
[/list]

Over all it seems to be a downgrade in some aspects in comparason to older games. I mean, yeah the game is pretty and nice, but for this price I'd expect at least good gunpowder ballistics.

I'm a huge fan of the TW: Series, and every game has a niche, where it excels. When it comes to TW: Warhammer, what stands out is it is the most "RPG"-like TW title I played. 
With heroes, items, quests and storylines it adds a new dimension to the TW series that fits well and is fun to play.

The game pressures you quite a bit, it's a world where danger is everywhere. So most of the time it is not about slowly building your empire, but putting out fires threatening you. 

I do like the diplomacy system which is mostly logical. Different to previous TW titles allies or friends don't attack without reason, you can coordinate attacks as allies and confederate.

Pros:
+ Epic battles (expecially if you like fantasy battles as in LOTR)
+ Great Replayability due to different factions with distinct playstyles
+ Quests and Hero development
+ Good music and atmosphere

Cons:
- Hunting enemy armys can be tiresome since they run away and are a nuisance (unless you sabotage them). Would've been nice if stragglers disbanded if their numbers were small enough.
- Pricey for its age, expecially when you want the full DLC Game. Since the base game (with free DLC) includes a lot of content already, I'd recommend to start from there and play the starting factions. Afterwards you can decide wether you like additional content (personally I enjoyed Norsca, but it depends on playstyles you like)

Overall, I recommend it for fans of the TW series and epic fantasy battles.

I wish Steam wasn't black and white. I like this game a lot and would almost give it a positive review, but there are some things that are so damn annoying, I would rather give a neutral one. Without that option I chose to look at the average reviews and because the game has positive reviews, I'm giving a negative one.

This game sometimes feels a bit incomplete. When I want to move an army in raiding stance to evade attrition casualties, I can move farther if I first move in normal stance and then change over to raiding stance with just enough movement points left. This in itself is annoying. What's more annoying is that if I hold down the mouse button, I can see what percentage of the move would cost me. This almost never tells me the truth. Most of the times it shows I would have 25% moves left, then as I commit to the movement, I have about 30%. However occasionally I'm dropped around 24% and can't use the stance. I couldn't figure this out in 83 hours.
Also if I move just 1 step in marching stance (because I forgot about it), I can no longer change to normal stance. Makes no sense.

The distance of an army reinforcing another army in combat is also weird. Until I found out that I can hold the button over the enemy army and another arrow appears from the reinforcing army, I had to reload lots of games. I swear sometimes an army is near the edge of another army's circle and still fails to join in. Then I move it a bit to the side and it works.

Auto resolving combat is so random, I'm terrified of it. Sometimes my full HP most elite unit dies to expendable enemies. I couldn't lose that unit in manual battles against those enemies if I tried, lol...

But the most annoying thing that really got me to write this negative review is that I received two negative traits after a battle: unjust and untrustworthy. I googled why I got it. People aren't 100% sure, because the devs refuse to answer it, but it's highly likely (based on some exported database data) that I got it, because I executed my captives.
I played as a dwarf and I executed orcs, so my dwarven subjects hate me (reduced public order for unjust) and also I steal money from the treasury (reduced income for untrustworthy)? It makes no sense. People are complaining for this on forums for 4-5 years. If I recall correctly the first complaints I read were from 2017. This is ridiculous.
What makes it even more ridiculous is that I first played Vampire Counts and always ransomed my captives, so I got the opposite traits (kind and forgot the name of the other) with bonus to public order and income. "What a kind guy, collects ransoms."
What makes it even more ridiculous is that I then played Bretonnia and I couldn't really choose between ransoming and executing, because the former grants negative chivalry and the latter grants positive chivalry. So I'm basically forced to execute my enemies.
What makes it even more ridiculous is that I discovered, that on the diplomacy screen my allies start to hate me if I release my enemies. So yeah, I should release the damned orcs if I want public order and money, but I should kill them if I want to confederate the other dwarves. Makes no sense. This is dumb. People point it out that it's dumb for half a decade. Devs don't do anything about it. Well, the only way I know to reward devs like these is by writing negative reviews. I'm sorry.

The game otherwise was quite addictive up until I realized why I get these negative traits. I wonder how much I'll play in the future. But either way, I stated at the start, that I wanted this review to be neutral, rather than negative.

Edit #1: As bretonnians I multiple times got the trait procrastinator. I got it for waltzing into an abandoned province and immediately colonizing its ruins. Upon colonizing I lose all my move points. Next turn I start with the procrastinator trait. With bretonnians, for some reason, the game actually explains why I got the trait. It says I spent too many turns idling in the same province. Makes no sense. It's even funnier that I get descriptions of why I got a trait as bretonnians, because they are the ones that can remove negative traits with ease. They are the ones who couldn't care less why they got the negative traits. Roflmao.

Edit #2: Warhammer is on sale on steam. The 2nd game has -66% off and all DLCs for both games -50% off. (Except Blood for the Blood God, but that's only 3 eur.) Alright, let's put them in the cart and go to checkout. 110 eur. WHAT?! WHAAAAAT?! Are you kidding me? Less than half price is still 110 eur? And the game has such epic bugs in it? WHAT?!

I have been a fan of the Total War series since Shogun Total War.   Some TW games I have to admit feel like it's the same thing just with a new skin on it. I've played both Total war WH games so far, and recently I started to prefer this one. Although WH1 feels like a beta test WH TW game, the campaign is balanced enough, unlike in TW WH2, where every time certain factions snowball into rofl OP empires. For example Norsca is quite fun, unlike in WH2, where you have to deal with Naggarond, who will of course attack you with your pitiful economy, instead of the High elves, and etc.. 
Unlike Nakai, the horde factions also work quite well here even without any rework, like what the Beastmen have in WH2.

I also adore the apocalyptic atmosphere this game has, where the AI Chaos and Beastmen can really mess things up quite. I can only hope WH3 will have the feeling of the first game.

I have played nearly all the Total war games and This Game, Warhammer 2 and Three Kingdoms have all been about the same experience. The battles are primarily driven by the heros and characters. You can fight a strategic battle as well as you can and if the enemy hero is strong, he will be there til the end and you just have to moshpit them. However, if you have a stronger character then their, you just have to bum rush the enemy general and their forces completely route once you've killed him, even if your army is losing the battle. This is not a strategic simulator, nor is it fun, anymore. I'm sorry this is such a sour review, but the game has changed considerably in the last couple of years. Its just not fun with the focus on heros and characters.

I'm giving this game a thumbs down but not for any of the reasons you think. CA thought the implementation of this series out, meaning that ownership of WH1 and its DLC carries over into the later games, unlocks content for the player, and continues to provide value even as later iterations of the game supersed past ones. That being said, it's really hard to justify playing WH1 when looking at what it provides (even with DLC). A lot of the time spent here it's pretty difficult to find fun or entertaining. This is mainly because regardless of which faction, the first edition of the Warhammer trilogy lacks any of the features prevalent in the second edition. Making the entire first edition of the game nothing more than one giant redundant & overpriced DLC.

If you are looking for a fun and immersive experience that is more meaningful from the perspectives of Strategists & Warhammer enthusiasts, you probably want to buy Total Warhammer II. Consider purchasing Warhammer I (& DLC) only if you like the whole trilogy and would want to unlock all the factions, in the grand campaign map. However the price of $60.00 for this base game + $18.99 for Wood Elves + %18.99 for the Beastmen ("THE BLOODY BEASTMEN" which is the worst faction in Total Warhammer I.) The price should be lowered substantially to people who already own Total Warhammer II.
So I give it a 6/10 would probably not WAAAAGH again.

In conclusion, but the game but skip the DLC.

Total War has always produced my favourite strategy games, with their epic battles separate from the management layer. This particular installment takes that much further with their departure into fantasy. Honestly, they couldn't have chosen a better universe, as Warhammer was ALREADY prepared for being used as a strategy game, and is a world rich with history and lore. It's really something to watch armies of hundreds or even thousands of monsters fight or spellcasters change the course of a battle with a few well placed spells.

It's not perfect of course, with issues scattered all over the game, but considering both the sheer scale of the game along with how much the game has changed and improved since it's initial release, they are easily within tolerable limits.
The first Total War game fully committed to fantasy, and they knocked it out of the park. Warhammer fans and casual RTS enjoyers rejoice.

Thought I'd take advantage of the sale & try Warhammer.  

The Good:

1.  Warhammer is a bit of fun.

2. We see a change of focus from Total War's increasingly CIV like emphasis on developing your economy & teching up your economy, & a lesser emphasis on the aspects of TOTAL WAR.  Here, one is expected to FIGHT!

3.  The artwork is surrealistic & the colors & explosions are impressive.  There is some originality here.
I have also perused Warhammer 2, & see a further expansion of the colorful battles with Magic & Horrifying Monsters of all kinds.

The Bad:

1.  Attempting to play on Hard, the battles appear to be unbalanced in difficulty, too strongly favoring the ai.  Defending on Hills appears to be irrelevent to the efficiency of the defense.  Dwarfs lack of a fast unit, (not even a Goat unit, as depicted in the movie version of Tolkien's "The Hobbit"), is, in itself almost a Game Killer, as they are seriously handicapped against other civilizations.

Early in the Game, one is attacked by multiple full stacks of enemies.  The enemies apparently have no problem affording such stacks of armies, or of finding your less defended settlements.  

2.  Town defense (except for walled settlements), is conducted on open fields, where the more numerous attacker has all the advantages.  This set up represents a retreat (step back) from the improvements of combat in Attila, & to a lesser degree, in Rome II.

3.  Your soldiers often do not obey your orders, & continue to do whatever.  This tendency/lack of control has been noticed by other reviewers.

4.  Warhammer is not as much fun as I thought it would be.  It becomes WORK.

The Ugly:

1.  The General has been demoted & stands all alone, without a Guard of fellow warriors.

2.  The diplomacy is mostly irrelevent - as usual.  If it borders on you, it will usually attack you - sooner or later.  An improvement to diplomacy (long overdue), has been added to Warhammer.  There is a new ability to occasionally confederate (combine/unite your kingdom)with civs of your own kind).  This appears to work best with the Dwarves.

3. The creators of Warhammer have not attempted to add patches that would improve game balance.  I have viewed some players on-line-videos, where they manage to expand & overcome the game difficulties (specifically in videos of Warhammer II gameplay).  

3.  Do not wish to dwell on the DLC scam.

Verdict:

If I could, I would give Warhammer a Neutral Review.  Its developers deserve a C for effort.  I cannot recommend it & will return to The Witcher (another game I find quite beautiful, but difficult).  And when I lick my wounds, & wounded ego, I will attempt to intelligently play Warhammer again.  Posssibly, I will play it on Normal setting & see if that makes a difference.

*Rome I & MTW II are far too easy & simplistic, although they were fun for a while.  Did not like Empire, or Napoleon (no cities, walls, 1 province countries, lack of programming/triggering).

I've played total war games since Rome and I have to say that yes, it's BS that you have to pay another 60 bucks (easy) to get the "full experience" and even MORE SO to pay 4 flippin dollars for BLOOD EFFECTS in a TOTAL WAR game; yet with that being said, this is probably the most epic, amazing, awesome game that I have in my library thus far- can't tell you how many times I banged my head against inanimate objects before taking a step back and appreciating the algorithmic-type cunning that the AI uses against you; as well as the deep and engaging gameplay aspects- morale has always been a thing but steamrolling an entire Orc Waaaaagh by concentrating fire and having nearby units re-charge the lines, close to routing, themselves- is fantastic. 

The fact that vampire counts don't have ranged units and use a different system in place of morale, the Empire's artillery superiority and professionally-drilled soldiers defending their walls with the seasoned grace of a nation beset by constant war, even Bretonnia (took me 2 playthroughs to like/love them) and their reliance on heroes and Grail Reliquae to keep their morale in line, the sturdy f***ing dwarves and the mindset of the Slayers, and the nuances of keeping a giant Orc army (waaagh) from ripping itself apart by constant, brutal conquest all blends together into this wonderful tapestry that is my #1 game on steam.

[damn them for making us pay 4 DOLLARS FOR BLOOD EFFECTS] Yet all in all, money-grabbing and executive corporate BS aside, it's an amazing game worth your time and money... yeah the DLC aspect makes me mad but it's hard to stay mad when you start playing and are presented with the scale and lethality of the game and the ability of it's AI to keep you reloading saves- and like I said i've been playing since Rome 1. Thank you for taking the time to read this review, 8/10; -2 for DLC shenanigans; pretty sure the developers aren't responsible for their pricing fiasco's and you can tell they poured their heart, soul, and a little bit of Chaos into it. God bless and FOR THE EMPIRE!!

Here's what you need to know - You can get all the content from this game in Warhammer 2, but it is still a great game, due to the insane pricing on these games I waited until they were 75% off to purchase them ( and it still cost around $80 with the DLC ) - Warhammer is nice departure from the usual formula of Total War games, every unit is Unique, every faction is unique, no more simple reskins of Sword/Axe/Spear/Bow units - The campaign is also a lot of fun - and each faction and leader gets a series of individual quests that unlock as you play. 

What Warhammer 1 gives you is the "Old World" side of the Warhammer map, with the Empire, Wood Elves, Dwarves, Orcs, Undead and Chaos - Warhammer 2's original campaign diverts into the "new world" with High Elves, Dark Elves, Skaven, Lizard men ect - as well as a "moral empires" mode that mashes the two games together into one. So you can get all the content from Warhammer 1 in Warhammer 2 if you wish to skip this installment. What Warhammer 1 does is give you a nice set of training wheels to learn the game systems and how to play each faction without having to play on a massive global scale. If you are a fan of the classic Fantasy Warhammer table top game you can also appreciate seeing the models brought to life, as well as the effort put in to keeping the lore of the game alive with each faction. The Dwarves have a mechanic for their grudges, the Bretonians get a mechanic for peasants vs population raised in the army, the Orcs can WAAAGH and the Undead... they do stuff to. I've had my eye on these games for awhile, and glad i finally was able to justify the price.

I now have 100 hours across multiple factions and while enjoyable in some respects this is a very unbalanced game when it comes to the AIs ability to have no limitations imposed on it that a player would have with any given build. I've played campaigns where by turn 6 I've been attacked by The Empire with three armies with total troops around 4200 and by turn 8 game over. This is also compounded by some factions having unbalanced 'super' units which in the hands of AI make defending or attacking impossible; I've cheesed a number of encounters just to move forward. The balance of power system is widely inaccurate, no real point in using it to make any sort of judgement. The characters and interactions between factions is enjoyable, it feels like a more critical aspect of the game to maintain relationships. Field battles can be quite entertaining and involve some strategic thinking, the use of terrain matters. Siege battles are monotonous, which is a shame as there could of been some beautiful and dynamic city/castles on show to make up for the mechanics. I am basing the recommendation on the price I paid for the game, which was low, otherwise it'd be a thumbs down.

As a TW fan and veteran of the series for several years I really just can't get behind this one.  The campaign map is just too far a departure from traditional TW titles and the way the game is sectioned off into DLC is off-putting.  The main bad guys, Chaos, should have been in the game from launch, but oh well.  I think I'm several years too late to gripe about DLC.  The battles can be eye pleasing but it just seems a little too arcade-y.  I suppose Empire and Shogun 2 spoiled my expectations of this title as I was hoping for something more in-depth strategy-wise.  I mean, it's fun to play the battles in TW:WH and I still enjoy that part of the game but the campaign is just lacking.  What they did get right, I felt, was the diplomacy system as it made sense to be able to unite your faction through confederation, but beyond that it's largely useless.  

I had high hopes when I bought this game, but after playing it a bit and now coming back to it I can't say I'd recommend this game to either fans of the TW or GW franchises.  Both companies have much better offerings that more fully encapsulate what each IP is really about.  For TW, I'd say give Empire or anything newer than that title a try for a good semi-historical strategy game and for GW I'd recommend either Battlefleet Gothic 2 or any of the Dawn of War series.  Space Hulk is great and so is Inquisitor if you're looking for more action.  

Anyways hope this helps anyone looking at this title to make a decision, I am a fan of both companies and I felt this one was just a bit shallow.

Great game so far! Not as many factions as WHII, but it's still a solid game. You have to plan your campaign map movements carefully as well as make alliances in the Warhammer fashion. The orcs are big bruisers and have great monsters. The beastmen are like the orcs, but have even more monsters and have croxigors that are very terrfiying (as is the whole roster). The wood elves have a lot of special units and are great archers. The Empire has great starting units with fewer weaknesses than Bretonnia, which uses more peasants for its archers.  The Empire has lots of industrial units, as well as great infantry and cavalry. I'd go on, but there is so much variety in the game.
Good fun.

I have just finished playing a Empire campaign.  Enjoyed the experience and would play it again as Empire.  Best to look at the technology advance panel before starting to play and prioritise what you think you play style will be eg cavalry-heavy, infantry-heavy or artillery-heavy.  There are special buildings in certain settlements that help with recruiting each type of unit.  Look out for them and prioritise what you want.  I did not recruit much artillery or cavalry only basic units like mortars, pistol outriders and legendary artillery units.  You can win without recruiting greatswords as well.  You can get several trade agreements with the Dwarfs, Bretonnia and Estalia especially when Chaos show up so build these buildings early on in anticipation.  Also get technology advancements that relate to this eg build the harbours early on.

The history at the end of the game is a great feature but could be a lot better.  Make the map a lot bigger and integrate the text information with the points as they appear on the map.  Having a small map and separate text box is hard to follow; they should be integrated into one large map with text on the points. Have a graph that charts the rise and fall of all the factions.  Have the option of multiple maps showing different aspect rather than all  in one map.  Be able to download this data and view it in a spreadsheet or other software would be great too.

The buildings could be made more interesting and relevant.  For instance the resources could also effect the speed you construct buildings, like marble, recruit units such as iron.  The already do it with stock, although that could also  be a trade item.

CA should also improve naval battles.  Recruiting different naval units would be fun and having that strategic element of the game would give another dynamic. Being able to protect the Empires coast with some form of proper navy with Greatships, galleys,etc would be fun (and make sense strategically?).  An advanced form of auto resolve could developed so some strategy could be employed without having to develop tactical sea battles.  A bit like hero actions but with some extra actions or variables to control. Hero's could also be embedded with ships, maybe a naval hero or lord/admiral options... 

All in all a great trilogy of games and I hope CA keep developing this title and adding more facets to the game.

Wow, great addicting game, not going to lie I did lose like crazy to AI at first, but then started learning when to accept diplomatic relationships and when not to, since the AI can turn on you instantly!

Total War: Warhammer is a fantasy, turn based mixed real time strategy game focusing on the building of a racial empire (orks, humans, dwarfs, unliving) by building an economy, researching technology, building armies and conquering other empires all on the campaign map which establish themselves in this diverse fantasy world. conflict takes you into beautiful and intense real time strategy as you work to build and have your empire thrive every decision you make creating a different outcome and different interaction with others around you. Many of the campains I have played offered interesting and at times challenging problems sometimes a decisive victory others a crushing defeat. Much like many of the Total War series this title is a sure hit with both total war and Warhammer fans as now you can summon monsters into the field, massive giants, spiders, Dragons and warbeasts with a wicked and enjoyable theme and style which has been incorporated into the games play unlike any other of the Total War Series. The main story line follows that a great evil (Chaos) is massing an invasion upon the old world and that only if a nation could build a strong enough empire and unite all other under the same banner could the forces of evil be stopped.

I truly enjoyed playing Total war: Warhammer not just the new feel but some new in game mechanics such as magic, units and movements. In time I hope to pick up the new DLC's to grow my experience in this game being able to play as Chaos interests me greatly other nations such as Beastmen and hopefully the introduction of elvish (both Dark and good) to enter the game or the rat people in future patches/updates. its been interesting discovering the differences between this game and others of the Rome II and Attila tiles and so I give the developers a good pat on the back and encourage them to continue their good work at improving game play to have this game stand as successfully as the others.

Possible improvements
- greater unit rosters for factions (giving a grander and wider feel)
- some work on AI mechanics such as:
   the return of factions which had earlier been destroyed through rebellion like others of its title 
   wiser AI moves making use of garrison forces and walls rather then sallying out loosing such advantages
- not to sure about the idea of racial territorial holdings such as orks and dwarfs can only capture mountain regions

I'd strongly recommend this game to tacticians, strategists and empire builders as it is really is a fun and challenging game which you should try see if you can hold out as an empire and save the old world from total Chaos. Well done CA and Sega XD.

I'm something of a Total War vet, and was new to Warhammer Fantasy when I came in (some experience in 40k; Dawn of War, Space Marines, some of the tabletop). First things first: this game is great. If you aren't sure, and it's on sale, get it. 

It's not a perfect game, but to date for me, it's the best Total War I've played, and they beautifully recreated the Old World of Warhammer Fantasy Battle for me to explore and experience for the first time. I love it. The factions are all quite dynamic and play differently enough to keep things fresh - Vampires have undead raising capabilities and only melee units, while the Dwarfs are exclusively heavily armored and boast powerful ranged tools. As well, they made it much easier to actually "finish" a game - the short and long campaign victories are treated the same by the game, and both are much more focused than, say, Rome 2, wherein you needed most of the map to win. 

The downsides: infrastructure got simplified. This is personal preference, of course, but the lack of food after games like Rome 2 and Atilla can be.. odd. They're replaced by a much easier to understand Corruption mechanic, so it's not like there's nothing there, but regardless. 
Siege battles also got simplified to very straightforward affairs. Again, this is flavored to taste, but for the most part you'll be using your Lord to tank the towers while you rush the walls or gates, or otherwise shell em with artillery. Not unfun, but it can get a bit samey. 
There's other issues, like not being able to settle in every province (they're racially locked), but they fixed that in the sequel I read, so it's not worth mentioning.

If nothing else, buying this game unlocks all the races for Total War: Warhammer 2, which I haven't played yet, but I've heard that it's somehow even better than the best in the series so far. Nice.

In response to GW's current stance on fanworks, the atrocious DLC purchase to unlock the full game practices (looking at easily over 300 USD for the 'true experience'), the downfall and degeneration of the order of battle in favor of blob or full archer spam armies, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to anyone, even people who are fans of Warhammer. Go buy Medieval 2. It's a better game, it's got better mods, and you'll get far more for what you pay for.

I say this with a heavy heart in regards to two series whom I have loved for years and can no longer support the direction they've chosen to take, both as a company and as games.

After some of my rants on Steam, I usually wait for a while before giving a review. This is for good reason. I will do pros and cons to not waste anymore of your time.

Pros:

- Great new battle system. It is simplistic and easy to use. I could compare it to creating a TW that is more action oriented if that is possible.

-Each race has its own unique strengths, so the balance in the game is just so vast. So much so that you never know what you are going to get when starting a new campaign.

-The interaface seems more easy to use, and the construction trees are simplified as well. You have a lot to build on without having to deal with other factors such as "marrying your daughter to an opposing tribesman" that was present in Atilla. It isn't that I didn't enjoy that part of Atilla, but it was rather side tracking from the battleground. This game delivers without having to deal with things in such a detailed manner. Which I think is nice. Others may disagree though.

-The cultural differences in the different factions are very significant giving a variety of gameplay that no other game on the market can deliver hands down.

-Movement on the map has been improved based on your race. The Dwarves for instance can travel further  by using a tunneling system that creates a new strategy. Mountains beware, no oysters please.

Cons:

-First and foremost, there isn't any longer a "Grand Campaign" mode. I have read that they may add this later, but at this time is an extreme disappointment that it isn't present at launch. It is possible that they may never release that mode in the game. If they don't, I will never buy another TW unless I know the grand campaign mode is available at launch.

-A lot of graphics issues for nVidia users, which I happen to be. The game runs fine, but it is just that: fine. I had to do a bit of tweaking to get it that way in the options, but the graphics are not what they should be. I hear that AMD users get to enjoy a much better graphical experience. Which in my opinion TW has just fucked off half of their customer base. What a fucking stupid thing to do. I am hoping that with patches and updates with nVidia this issue may be resolved. Apparently some of the base files in the driver names for the nVidia driver were the same in this game than for a game lost past released that had an outdated graphics system. This is total shit, and I am not so hopeful for the cooperation of nVidia and the creators of TW to work this issue out.

-The game does not have a variety of units as its predecessors. The combat has been simplified, which I like, but the variety of units have also been simplified and it eludes from creating an immersive experience. If that is why you like about the TW series this game is not for you. I imagine they will release DLC that will require further purchases in order to enjoy that aspect of the game series. This is total shit.

- The game is lessening the TW experience by cutting corners and cheapening the gameplay by dumbing down the game altogether. This breaks my heart to see such a successful series turn a corner like this. My guess is that they want to make the most money with the least amount of effort. That is business, this is life, and I am sad to say that TW is now being effected by it.


Conclusion:



So many DLCS for a game with so many flaws. It is a piss poor effort by a corporation to take your money with minimal effort put into the game.

The game is interesting, but because of the underhanded business practices, I must not recommend this game.

Total Warhammer I and II are basically the same game with different factions/maps so they only really need one review.

One main problem that Total Warhammer has is boring battles. The battles are slow paced and take too long. It feels like you have no real unit control and the units act as big globs bumping into each other. If you are zooming in on the action, you aren't managing units; if you are managing units, it feels like there is not much to be done and your actions don't have any impact and don't matter. I shouldn't feel bummed out every time I have to actually play a battle instead of clicking auto-resolve. If Total War could make their battles more engaging like in an RTS game (of which it is not) then it might be better.

Another problem Total Warhammer has is that it can lead you to believe you are making progress only to realize ten hours too late that you picked the wrong buildings from the tech tree. The tech trees are terrible. Why can I only build six buildings in my capital? Does that sound like a capital city that you've seen? No. It's stupid. You will fill up your building slots only to realize what you should have been building when it's too late to course correct.

On the world map, you will spend way too much time dealing with redundant pop-ups and adding points to hero characters. If you make a mistake, you get to start over again or reload from a save and spend all those points all over again. There's no way to auto-allocate hero points or pre-select them.

The DLC is overpriced and sometimes hanging out a bit in "pay-to-win" territory, particularly for Total Warhammer II which requires you to buy DLC to use Sisters of Avelorn or confederate Avelorn or Yvresse.

Overall it fits the Sega brand - the complexity is too high for the boredom it offers.

i have roughly 200 hours in this game so i think i have played this game enough to form an opinion about it.
if you are a historical total war game fan like me chances are you are not going to like this game. 

i was pretty hyped when this game was announced so that i even pre ordered the game, expecting it to be like the previous total war games. it wasnt. so what are the differences to historical total war games that make this game worse? this list is  going to be pretty subjective:
- the battles are pretty short. units rout quickly
- battles are pretty easy and not as engaging as other total war titles. for example an expensive cavalry unit will most of the time win against a medium priced spear unit. in other total war games the cavalry would simply lose.
- there are no animations for fights between 2 men
- the construction is the easiest out of all total war games. it is just not fun to build the same layout in every city
- special units like generals and agents are single entity units with enormous health pools interrupting  the feel of a battle. the were lots of occasions where the enemy army is defeated an the only one alive beeing the enemy general. your army will surround him and youll have to fast forward the battle until this one guy dies adding 5 minutes to a battle that is long over
- sieges are pretty bad only letting you attack from one specific side
- i didnt like the magic in the game. it just feels like point and click buffs for most of the time
- i dont like the rpg styled way you cant enhance the stats of the character with different types of armors weapons etc that you can give your generals ( they wont be displayed in battle ) just a point and  click buff to stats
- pretty cartoony visuals with over exaggerated animations
- no naval battles

what are the positives?
+ extremely beautiful and large map
+ a lot of factions with extreme unit variety. probably the game with the most unit variety in the franchise
+ replayability due to the different factions and different lord options per faction
+ the setting is unlike any other in the franchise with lots of love put into it so that it even got me interested in the warhammer franchise
+ beautiful character and unit models though i think they aged pretty badly compared to rome 2 or shogun 2
+ i liked the large units like giant spyders or ogres. they fit in pretty well into the tw formula. 
+ interesting battlefields. for example fighting in caves

over all it felt to me like a oversimplified tw game to attract the masses. simplifying both the battles and the construction system to a point it made the game not that enjoyable for me.
this could be a great game to get started in the franchise though i would recommend shogun 2 and rome 2 a lot more.
medieval 2 could be great too but i feel like it aged a little bit from the modern point of view.
Sweet

TL;DR I played WH1 so that you don't have to. 

The single reason why I'm giving it a thumbs up is due to the clever way in which CA thought the series out, meaning that ownership of WH1 and its DLC carries over into the later games, unlocks content for the player and continues to provide value. That being said, it's really hard to justify playing WH1 when looking just at what it provides (along with the DLC). A lot of the time spent here it's pretty difficult to find fun or entertainment, mainly due to the fact that regardless of the faction you want to play, the game appears to be designed around the idea of hindering the player and not giving them tools to work with rather than providing meaningful options. Sure, you get plenty of cool looking units, but for the most part they are terribly inefficient and cost-ineffective. It's frankly pretty depressing to see how poorly melee infantry & cav perform almost across all factions in a game that has bloody WARHAMMER written in the title. 

On the flip-side, if you simply spam  stacks of the cheapest infantry you have available and just auto-resolve all of your battles, or if you stack whatever monsters your faction has available, the game completely breaks down and is entirely trivialized. Either the auto-resolve engine gets overloaded and gives you a decisive victory with next to no casualties even against an army that would completely destroy you in the manual battle, or the monsters are so overpowered than when they're stacked together they just roflstomp any and all opposition. For the most part, there is no real middle-ground where fielding a balanced army can give you strategic and tactical advantages, or at least offer options to be considered if you want to play effectively.  

A lot of the above is due to how poorly siege battles are designed here. Regardless of who you are playing, most of the game involves besieging cities. It doesn't help that all look and play the same no matter what cultures are involved (in terms of substance, the textures are different of course). The main problem is that they are completely stripped of options or mechanics and everyone from the exalted champions of chaos to the sneaky night goblins simply have to bumrush a wall, losing half the army in the process due to how overpowered the towers are, following with the hope that you can outlast the defenders and win to attrition in a frontal slog with whatever you have left. So you can suffer through that, training costly armies that perform very poorly and wasting many turns setting up sieges and recovering your loses, or you can be smart and either cheese the towers and shoot the passive AI to shit with your cheapest artillery and archers, or simply blob a stack of monsters, smash your way through the gate and roflstomp your way to victory. Or even better, just bring 3-4 stacks of the cheapest infantry you have available and auto-resolve, which is the most efficient and headache-free way of playing WH1. 

If you are looking for a fun and immersive experience that is more meaningful from the perspective of a grand strategy game, you probably want to have a look over WH2. Consider purchasing WH1 and its DLC only if you really like that game and would want to unlock additional stuff, like the grand campaign map. I'll mention that the above impressions have been formed on Normal difficulty, playing the game across all of its campaigns and with all factions. The only 2 iterations of the campaigns that I haven't completed are the Beastmen grand campaign specifically with Morghur as the starting Lord (he is essentially denied the use of the single cost-efficient units in the entire roster, minotaurs, and encouraged to use Chaos Spawn, which are worthless) and Wintertooth (because I would have done an exact carbon-copy playthrough of the campaign with Norsca, as going for non-mammoth armies and pledging to anyone but the serpent god means just hamstringing yourself for no benefit).

All flash, no substance. Total War Warhammer is essentially half a game. The 4x strategy portion of the game is practically nonexistent as everything has been streamlined: no tech tree options, no food upkeep, severely unbalanced factions, a Dynasty Warriors-like unrealistic hero, and a boring agent system. The AI is still dumb as ever, by the way.

On top of this, there's no tutorial campaign any more, despite the fact that the game has the most changes to the actual units. Which leads to what the game seems to do well - battles. With new unit types, this is the first Total War since Empire and Napoleon that actually feels fresh. But I'm not looking for a simple skirmish game; I want a strategy title. Total War Warhammer fails in this regard.

The best part of Total War has always been the historical accuracy.  By setting their game in a fantasy setting, CA has given up the best part of the series.  

The second thing about Total War is it was always a strategy game -- until now.  This game is an RPG with some strategy elements.  You have a limited number of characters and you have to build their buffs and perks.  Also they can recruit other units.  

Like all Total War games this one suffers from a lack of maps.  With only a half-dozen or so battle maps and many armies constituted the same, we end up playing the same battle over and over and over.  

If you love Total War, skip this one.  If you want a decent game that kills time without being Total War, still skip this one.  For that you'll want the expansion, "Total War: Warhammer II".

This is a mixed bag, I only recommend this because despite it's blatant shortcomings somehow manages to suck you in and once picked up it's pretty hard to put down. I got this game on a sale, the full price for a 5 year old game it's just bonkers, and I'll wait for sales to get the dlcs too, although there's enough content in the base game to keep me occupied for quite some time.

The good:
- factions have unique traits, mechanics, units and playstyles
- units are diverse enough and early game units don't really get obsolete, used correctly they still pack a punch
- not a lot of economy micromanagement which lets you focus on battle and conquering
- challenging campaign: [spoiler] having to deal with vampiric and chaos corruption, as well as the feeling of impending doom when chaos armies are steamrolling all the factions on the map [/spoiler]

The bad:
- units are pretty dumb, there's a lot of micromanagement to be done in battle
- in battle units are slow, moving some parts of the army across the map is just mind numbingly slow
- some mechanics are poorly explained or not at all; magic for instance, I still have no idea how that works
- dumb but also cheating AI; chaos armies just steamroll over everything, your allies don't move on common targets
- there's no way to efficiently defend your territory once it grows, there's a limited number of money you can make and a limited number of armies you can support; this might be seen as a challenge, but it's not really a great one.

Bottom line, get it, play it. Base game has enough content to keep you busy for a long time and there's a lot of replayability value.

Overall would not recommend.

Long time TW fan who initially wasn't super excited for the fantasy departure, but it is a very refreshing entry in the series in retrospect. 

Biggest gripe being a common one. WHII was released a year and a few months after WHI. However in that time they still squeezed out $75 worth of paid DLC and 6 "free" lords. I felt absolutely indignant at the time that CA was moving on from a game I had bought only the year before and asking me to buy a sequel. It makes it hard to say WHI is a finished game (although its a great experience). I definitely can't recommend it for $60. 

Let's face it though, we're all CA junkies and we need another hit. You NEED WHI to play Mortal Empires in WHII. And Mortal Empires is the best TW:WH experience if not one of the best strategy gaming experiences ever. As others have said, get WHII and then this one on sale.

Interesting version of Total War and I think a perfect marriage of two very popular war game brands.

Having the Warhammer world, albeit limited in scope for Version 1, in a strategic setting was an answer to a dream I had from over 30 years, Mighty Empires could never provide the depth that Total War does.
I do recommend it and low the graphics of the map and the ambience of the soundtrack let me immerse myself in an universe I had not visited in decades.
