Sigh. I really wanted to like this game. After the awful mess that was Shogun 2, I hoped that the team would correct the atrocious mechanics. Sadly, despite substantial improvements, this game has missed the mark.

The main problem is the tactical battles. The mechanics are broken. Ignore any reviews advising you on how to win battles - there is simply no point. You can't win anything except when you have the most overwhelming numerical superiority. The following comments apply to a mix of normal and hard difficulty.

Firstly, the mechanics are grossly titled to favour the enemy. Units which are useless when you use them are nigh-invincible when you are facing them with your units.
*For example - zombies and skeletons. When I was playing VC, in a one-on-one fight, zombies and skeletons would not defeat empire units. When I am empire, I can have zombies facing two halberdier units, and charged in the rear by two units of reiksguard and a lord, and the zombies will hold out for five minutes. This gives another unit of zombies time to attack and destroy your units. 
*In another example - crypt ghouls are defeated in ~20 seconds by units of halberdiers that they charge. However, when I take the halberdiers, the ghouls push them out of position and will hold their own against three units of halberdiers (attacking from the sides). I need to charge in a lord to finish them off.
*Bats - absolutely useless when I use them. Two full units have been defeated by artillery. When facing them - one unit of bats will destroy two units of crossbowmen before I've realised they are under attack. Spearmen or halberdiers are reduced to at least half strength, and the bats just fly away, with above half of their unit strength.
*Heroes - mine are durable enough, but do no damage. I've seen a level one enemy hero take on four units of spearmen and wipe them out.
*Cavalry - black knights do no damage when they charge. At all. Pointless. You cannot charge spears head-on, you are wiped out in seconds. However, when I charge enemy cavalry with three units of halberdiers - they take several minutes to reduce the enemy to half strength. 

In all of these cases, I have upgraded the units with technology advances and lord skills. 

*Enemy armies seem to be more powerful when their lord is at a higher level. I can outlevel an inferior army by at least three levels, and the best I have ever done is a close victory. It is impossible to win against equal armies when the enemy lord is of higher level. Impossible. Your units simply don't do damage. Besides, the enemy lord could literally - without exaggeration - defeat your entire army by himself. I've played battles where this is the case (especially against Throgg). 
*Enemy artillery is devastating when used against you. When I use it - almost always misses, does little damage when it does hit. One enemy artillery is worth at least five of yours.
*Spells often simply don't work. The mechanics are broken. I read advice to use soul leech (VC power), but it only works 50% of the time.

Now, don't get me started on chaos warriors. They are simply invincible. Only one thing can stop them - missile troops. There are no infantry which will stand against them. I don't mean one-to-one. I've had five units surrounding them, and the warriors emerged victorious. I've had five fighting them, and charged in the rear with 2-3 cavalry units. I won, but most of my 7-8 units were on 25%. Most chaos armies are composed of at least 10 units. Five is sufficient to defeat any army I can field (without missile troops). It is not possible to defeat chaos armies with only one stack. You can do it with two, but you are left with at best 30% of your troops. Note, this is on normal difficulty.

Forget about fighting siege in battle mode. I've surrounded a unit of grave guard with five swordsmen and lost. Five units is enough to decimate any attacking army. Except when you are defending. Your units last seconds when enemy units use ladders. Even though they outnumber the attacker 3-to-1. 

Of course, the controls are so clunky you can't tell when you have selected a unit. It is very difficult to attack enemy units (why is this so hard? this was done very well in the first Rome, and in Medieval 2), because you can't click on them easily (especially enemy heroes). You have to zoom in and fiddle with it.

All of this leaves you with auto-resolve. Which predicts poorly. And you rarely win on an even footing. Meaning your only option is to fight an enemy stack with two of your own...
...and this is where the strategic map bugs come into play. The enemy can move absurd distances sometimes. You retreat randomly. Enemy stacks jump from 4-5 units to 15 in one turn. Normally gaining the most powerful units the enemy has. From nowhere (this is especially the case with chaos, but applies to VC, too). Meaning you can't win auto-resolve.

So much of the strategy map works, but the broken battle system makes this depressing. The not-quite-broken auto-resolve and enemy movement system means you are constantly reloading so your stacks aren't out of place.

Overall, a pale shadow of Rome: TW and Medieval 2. Substantially better games designed by people who knew what they were doing. Warhammer: TW - and, indeed, every TW series since Medieval 2 - feels like it hasn't been play-tested, and has used mechanics that were the beta of Rome: TW. Disappointing.

Oh, and the ridiculously long load time is annoying. I have to read a book in between battles. I can watch a tv show before the game even boots.
Âø´Ë∑ëÔºå‰ºöÊ≤âËø∑ÔºÅ

My one negative is the lack of a story. They could have turned the whole chaos thing into a grand epic but instead of get a "Baby's First Book". That aside, the gameplay is rather quite enjoyable.

If you want to see where Total Warhammer started, this is it. It's probably better to play the factions via Total Warhammer II and soon Total Warhammer III, but if you want a harder game this is it. 

This game is the closest to the original Total War formula of the series but mixes it up a little with magic and quest battles. Magic can turn the tide of battle and make even the smallest force take on bigger hordes. The Quest Battles offer a set of missions to accomplish and culminate in a battle that upon winning yields special prizes.

The stuff from earlier Total War games are here too but have been tweaked to match the setting. For instance, each faction belongs to a certain race and this determines what type of units and strengths and weaknesses armies have. Gone are the days where no matter what faction you played, you really only had a handful of unit types to choose from that only differed in stats. Total Warhammer introduces Wizards, Monsters and flying units. But these are merely the tip of the iceberg. 

Although at times the difficulty can be a little arduous and overwhelming, it suits the gravity of the Chaos invasion this games introduces and which permeates all of the games in this series. With that said, one major weakness of the game is that some factions are not fully explored or balanced to match up against others. Some of these inequalities are addressed in Total Warhammer II but not fully.

In summary, if you are a big fan of the Total war formula, this game is as faithful to that formula as any other. It cleverly melds it into the lore and style of the table top game that it draws  inspiration from without losing focus on what makes Total War great. If you want more streamlined gameplay, you will most definitely want to grab Warhammer II instead. But, to fully enjoy that game, you might as well pick this one up as it helps build up that game.

Final verdict: 8.5 Warhammers out of 10.

Secondly there's quite a but of tutorials for the game but they really fail to help you where it matters most - combat.  Tons of tutorials about managing your kingdom and such but very light on combat.

Finally - and this is the big one for me - but mileage may vary based on the kind of game you are hoping that this is:

I had hoped the kingdom 4x part of this game to be much more detailed and 'better'. It felt tacked on and very light to me. 

Conversely I had hoped the 'RTS' portion of this to be simple - instead it felt very typical RTS.  

I wanted a 4x game with some real-time combat, instead I got a RTS game with some tack-on 4x elements that were a complete let down.

Even worse I purchased 2 copies of it 1 for myself , 1 for my son as a gift. 

We both hated it. I tried to refund my copy but I could not because steam got confused thinking i was trying to refund his gift copy.

This would be only the 2nd time I had ever requested a refund on steam, but could no do so.

This game started the Total War Warhammer series. For its time it was something amazing and refreshing. People wanted a fantasy total war for years and few IPs were more suited for that than the warhammer universe. It grew to one of the most developed and ambitious  strategy game in years. I had lots of fun  with this title and I needed little to be convinced when warhammer 2 was going to be released ( I started playing like 2 weeks before that).  but as a potential purchaser you want to ask yourself  a question: is this game for me ?  The answer depends if you have already warhammer 2. If you don't own it then no this game is not for you. 

I have around 1600 hours in both games and I recommend getting the second game. Mainly for the many quality of life updates,more interesting mechanics and updated warhammer 1 races and the combined Mortal Empires campaign.  As of now Total War Warhammer 1 is more of a "expansion" for game two. The races are a nice adition to the Mortal Empires campaign and the second game allows you to purchase a separate DLC that enables you to play some of the game 1 races in the Vortex campaign (Markus Wulfhart in the Hunter and the Beast for example). This is a great feature to help you decide which race you like.

So get this on a sale and play warhammer 2. You will enjoy thousands of hours of gameplay.

Long time ago, when the RTW 2 came out, i did post a review about it saying that it's probably my fav strategy game ever. Now i can say that definitely Warhammer 1+2 might be my fav ones yet. 

The lore is amazing, feels like World of Warcraft but different. (Now i do hope for a warhammer fantasy mmorpg lol). Pretty rich in details and immersion as well as the gameplay. They are greedy and shitty with the expensive DLC's, but this is one of those games that i just tell them "SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY" that's how good this game is. (If you are into medieval/fantasy universes that is).  

One thing that this game does better than other Total War games is that the factions feel unique and there are lots of them! 

Usually with other total war games let's pick RTW 2 for this example, yes they do have lots of factions, but it's pretty much an illusion as most of them play the same. In truth you have 4 factions at most (Roman culture, Barbarian culture, hellenistic and sand people culture ?)  If you try to replay with other factions you will get bored pretty fast as you will discover this illusion. 

BUT with TW Warhammer that's not the case! Having so many factions and each of them is pretty unique and have to change the play style to fit it's something that gives huge replayability value! I do recommend this game to all total war fans out there, best game in the series hands down!

I've never played a Warhammer game in my life, and have no exposure whatsoever to the lore. I also am generally not a fan of the fantasy genre as a whole. I've always liked Total War because of the historical element, seeing the tides of history play out on both the grand scale and on individual battlefields.
All of that being said, Total War: Warhammer is a great addition to the series.
The fantasy element seems to have been what this engine and game template was born to do. Both epic battles of thousands and skirmishes of a few powerful warriors feel enjoyable and suitably dramatic. The campaign map is absolutely gorgeous, with Total War's consistently impressive graphics lending themselves to impossibly high snowy mountains and blood-red rivers cutting up the landscape.
With this game as my first introduction to the world of Warhammer, I can definitely say I'm sold.

Man I hate to give a thumbs down but this game is just not fun to play.  I'm a huge Warhammer and strategy game fan and I really wanted to like it.  
First of all, about half the game is locked behind multiple pay walls. Even on sale major $$$ to actually get all factions.  Some bugs here and there (Dwarf book of grudges bug means I could not complete campaign for one), Annoying little surprises for each faction (You must randomly move your armies around the map each turn as Bretonnia or you get big penalties ???), tedious city management (want to go fight with that nice army? ha! they must stay behind so your city won't rebel.  Don't want them to rebel? turn off taxes.  Now you can't pay your army! Are we having fun yet?). 
Strange map/army interactions (want to attack that enemy army? sorry! you can't for some reason!  Were you hoping to reinforce this army? Sorry! not close enough! Sorry your beloved hero you spent so much time cultivating is now dead)
 So so SO many turn reloads with really long load times.
The worst part is that the highlight of the game; the truly impressive real time strategy battles, are annoying long and just about who has the better troops.  The maps are ludicrously large and that's not a good thing. A single powerful terror causing monster will rout an entire field of weaker troops.  Skimishing range troops are impossible to box in.  Spells are cool but very weak. Even worse, the auto battle ALWAYS does better than you! How? no idea because there is no replay to watch and learn from; it's just a calculation.
Sure all those cool looking battles in the trailers and gameplay clips look neat but you won't be zooming in to enjoy that during your game.  You are too busy trying to keep your troops from standing there picking their noses while getting shot.  
Sorry but this one is maybe fun to watch a battle or two but no fun to play.

It is essentially an expansion pack/DLC for TWWH2 at this point, but still worth picking up as it adds a great deal to TWWH2.

I highly recommend buying it when it‚Äôs on sale. It can frequently be found 50-75% off multiple times per year. I bought it and all the DLC on sale for a little over $50 USD.
 

I bought this game after enjoying its sequel TWWH2 and wanted to expand on playing that game as it adds an expanded campaign map(Mortal Empires) that is widely considered superior to the base Vortex campaign as well as adding the ‚ÄúOld World‚Äù factions from this game. I decided I would play this game before I play the Mortal Empires map for WH2. I did enjoy it and can mention a number of things the game does well and not so well, but every one of them TWWH2 does just as good or better. You can play this game and have a good time with it, but you can and might as well just get it to add to your play through for TWWH2. I feel weird saying spend money on a game and never play it, but that‚Äôs what I would recommend as you aren‚Äôt really missing anything because you are basically playing the best of two games at once when you play the Mortal Empires campaign. This is why I and many others now consider it an expansion pack/DLC for TWWH2, even though it came out first.

 

The game consists of varied factions with unique play styles. There are humans, vampires, dwarfs, elves, beasts and demons. Each has strengths and weaknesses that you will need to use to you advantage to win battles and the campaign. 

 

Addressing some Negative reviews.

A common review of just about all Total War games raised by a vocal portion of the player base criticizes CA for releasing DLCs that all together end up being as much or more expensive as the base game and feeling the ‚Äúfull game‚Äù is locked behind this sort of DLC paywall. I appreciate were they are coming from, but I feel CA is doing it the best way for both the players and themselves. Firstly, if you buy the game at full price at release(otherwise wait for one of their frequent sales) you can get hundreds of hours of game play for your $60 USD, far more than many other games or other forms of entertainment that you would potentially substitute that time and money for. I feel a few hundred hours of fun is a great deal for my money and if it‚Äôs not, their frequent, heavily discounted sales ought to make it worth it for anyone that enjoys this genre of games. The DLC portion of the game gives the hard-core fans hundreds of hours more playtime for about the same price and a similar reasoning of entertainment for the money makes it worth it for us. Because I believe the complete package of the Total War games plus all their DLC to be worth more than the ~$150(it would be around $250 for both WH and WH2 if you bought and played them from release) you would pay at release for these games. But, if they charged that at release, I may be hesitant to buy it just in case I didn‚Äôt enjoy it and many wouldn‚Äôt consider it, meaning CA would have spent the same amount of money and time making it, but would have fewer players and less money to show for it. By building a base game and adding varying amounts of DLC based on it‚Äôs popularity, they don‚Äôt waste resources on DLC for less played games and redirect resources to ones we want to play more. It also allows them to release the base game at a completive price that allows players to take a chance on an historically strong franchise instead of having to stomach $150 upfront that would lock many players out of the franchise entirely. Even considering that Steam seems to be generous with their return policy from what I have heard from others. FINALLY AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, the DLC route avoids the real micro-transactions prominent in other games. I would stop playing their games entirely if the put in pay to win mechanics in their games. Some may disagree with me, but I find it unreasonable to expect CA to put out 1,000 or more hours of quality content for $60 USD. Where are you finding entertainment for less money per hour?

 

The second pricing themed reviews are mainly about the price increase due to inflation that mainly impacted non-US players. Not being political, but economically speaking, just like you have to manage your in-game economy or else bad things happen, you have to manage it in real life too. Poor monetary decisions by your government(like printing money) can lead to inflation. That means the money your currency can be converted for into other currencies is now worth less than it was before(the creators would take a pay cut for their hard work due to something that is out of their control). Blaming Steam or CA is unfair to them in this situation. These negative reviews should be redirected towards their politicians, not CA/Steam.

 

There are some real problems with the game. While not game breaking, there is some degree of ‚Äúagent spam,‚Äù fortunately it can be partially alleviated with a workshop mod. Heroes can be in armies as powerful, single entity units or out on the map doing work formally done by agents. The agent aspect is the problem, like some previous TW games, the AI can spam them and it‚Äôs more tedious and annoying to deal with them than it is difficult. Another smaller issue is unit balancing, especially in auto resolve. Some units will get ~700 out of 1,200 total kills in an auto-resolve battle, while some get 0-10. It can be used to your advantage if you are interested in a quicker auto-resolve focused play through, but I think they could have done a little better in the balancing department. Some magic spells can be very powerful and some aren‚Äôt worth the cost. I will add the unit balancing and magic are better balanced in TWWH2, while there is still some agent spam.

 

Overall, the game itself is a bit dated after playing TWWH2 and Three Kingdoms, but you can still have a good time, just remember to get in on sale! I was able to buy both TW Warhammer games and all the DLC for both games for around $130 if memory serves.

I'm a big fan of the Total War series and Warhammer 40k, but after the disaster called Rome II: Total War, I was hesitant with buying the game. But when Valve added the Dota 2 Treasure of the Old World, I prepurchased it and holy sh*t, that was a good decision (thx Valve!).
Like all Total War Games it features real-time (Combat) and turn-based (Moving Armies, Upgrading Cities, Recruiting Troops, Diplomacy, Research) Elements, but it all happens in the "Old World", not in the real world. And instead of British, French, ... you play and fight Orks, Elves, Dwarves, Humans and other fantasy races.


The gameplay is very smooth and focuses on raiding and combat. Citybuilding is reduced to ~10 different buildings (most are upgradeable) with a limited amount of building-slots per city. Since your building slots are limited, you have an incentive to conquer more cities. Cities are grouped into provinces - if you control an entire province you gain bonuses (another incentive to conquer).
The main aspect of the game is land combat. Like all Total War games, your soldiers are grouped into units and fight in formation, but this time it's not (only) humans fighting each other, but also Orks, Dwarves, Dragons, Trolls,... Another innovation is the introduction of mages and flying units.
Your Armies are led by some default commanders (of various types) and Legendary Lords like Karl Franz or Grimgor Ironhide. All commanders gain levels by Fighting and Raiding - those levels can be used to give them a mount or buff the character or the army they are commanding. Legendary Lords are usually stronger and cannot be killed (if they are assassinated or their army is annihilated they are "wounded" for a few turns). Commanders can also equip items and Legendary Lords have access to unique items by fulfilling quests, which involve moving the hero to a certain location on the map and defeating at least one army.

One of the biggest achievement of the game is the balance between the races - each race feels and plays differently and they still fare equally well on the battlefield. For example Orks get strong melee infantry and rely on numbers while Dwarves have strong melee infantry and strong artillery, Bretonnia on the other hand is heavily cavalry focused. Speaking of cavalry, Warhammer Total War seems to be the first game in the series where cavalry feels right - it was way too strong in Rome and Medieval II, but got demolished in Empire - now its useful without being OP.

Total War: Warhammer succeeds where Third Age Total War (a Medieval 2 mod) somewhat failed: the races are all balanced and fun to play.

Last but not least I have to praise the setting and atmosphere - Games Workshop's worlds are just perfect for grimdark, brutal and epic games and Warhammer:Total War is just such a game. Every race and it's habitat feels right and the permanent threat of neighbouring factions and chaos is always at the back of your head. The atmosphere is further enhanced by great memorable soundtracks.

this is less of a review and more of a rant on my frustrations with this game, you have been warned.

after giving this game a fair chance i have to say it's totally horrendous. many of the core mechanics are heavily flawed but the worst thing by far is the hideous amount of cheating the campaign ai commits alongside their fixation in harassing the player and overall just being annoying and obnoxious.

playing the empire campaign on "hard" and in turn 13 i'm getting attacked in 3 different fronts at once by hordes who apparently not only have full banner armies with elite units, 2 beastmen hordes and 1 orc horde and one undead faction which all have decided to ignore the other 50 ai players and focus down on my 4 settlements because "fuck you in particular", i can't field more than a single strong army without crippling my income, i could build garrisons everywhere but that would cripple my economy aswell as my growth and besides garrison buildings kinda suck anyhow. this would be fine if i could just build units to defend my cities like you could in every pre-rome 2 total war game but that's forbidden now.

but that's alright, as is tradition in total war games, the battle ai is so braindead that i can easily beat them while taking minimal casualties 99% of the time. but of course the ai seems to be aware of this, so they wait in the campaign map just out of sight and the moment i dare to move my army out of a settlement they will instantly attack that undefended settlement with a full banner army, so really that's where the difficulty comes from during the early game, playing hide and seek with the ai on the campaign map, once you get past that stage the game is pretty much over and you've already won.

i've never felt challenged while playing this game, only mildly annoyed. the older total war games were enjoyable to play even if they were pretty easy, but this one feels like an exercise in frustration

Summary
-----
Honestly, I usually write pretty long and in-depth reviews, but I think this one is very simple. Total War: Warhammer II is a better game in pretty much every regard. Literally the only reason I see to buy this game is if you want the Mortal Empires campaign in Warhammer II. Sure, that‚Äôs fine if you love Warhammer II and want that campaign‚Ä¶but that still means you should buy Warhammer II first and see if you like that game.  So, the final verdict is: spend your money on Warhammer II‚Ä¶there are plenty of places to drop cash on that game.
-----
A bit of context:

I played my first campaign in 2019, 3 years after this game released, and 2 years after Warhammer II release. It was fine. I even had fun. The campaign story was below average, but I sunk my teeth into this heavy 4X wargame just fine anyway. It still had occasional bugs, with one preventing me from being able to complete my dwarf campaign.

Then, 9 months later, I play Warhammer II and the game is more polished, MUCH better maps, very few bugs, more refined, and a neat campaign. And‚Ä¶it was the Exact. Same. Game. Sure, different factions and maps‚Ä¶but really it was the same game. It left me feeling like they took the lessons they learned from this game, used them to improve Warhammer II, and did not bother to update this game with those same lessons.
 
So, I literally see no reason to buy and play Warhammer I. Just buy and play Warhammer II. If the siren‚Äôs call of the Mortal Empires campaign (a Warhammer II campaign that also requires this game to play) latches into your soul at that point‚Ä¶sure I could justify buying this game. But sadly, that still means you are buying Warhammer I to just play a Warhammer II campaign. If this smacks a bit of corporate greed, you are not the only one that smells that. It‚Äôs up to you to determine if it is worth it. In the end, I like Warhammer II enough that I would end up buying this game to support the devs and hope to get a Warhammer III. But make that choice after you play Warhammer II.

So, I'm generally pretty good at strategy games, and TW: Warhammer is a great one, even though I have to admit that I get frustrated regularly with the manufactured difficulties here and there. I love the Chaos faction, but it's really frustrating that mid game, when I feel like I've finally gotten things under control, the game spawns a demon that is significantly higher in level than I am, which hunts down my warbands systematically and destroys them. I have similar problems with other factions. As much as I enjoy this game and could spend hours going on and on about the level of nuanced detail that's involved with it, I do miss the more simplistic days of Dawn of War. 

That said, if you're a fan of the other TW games, or these grand strategy games are really your thing, you cannot pass this up.

I have tried to like this game, wanted to like this game, I've given it a few goes, I've tried battle mods. 
I love the warhammer fantasy universe and lore and the game generally does a good job of setting the scene, I like the unit design, but I just hate the battles so much it spoils the entire experience.  
I have spent many hours playing total war titles; Rome, Rome 2, Attila, Shogun 2, Empire etc and I've always enjoyed the battles but they have utterly munted it on this one. Plenty of people play it and its successor so others obviously disagree but I really don't get any satisfaction from the battles.  Victory comes from having more and/or better units and a couple of well placed spells can turn the tide.   Who cares?  Trying to be tactial with positioning and terrain really seems to have fairly marginal effects and fighting combat through trees is just awful as you can barely see what units are engaged.  And without battles through settlements and decent sieges they are all very samey.
The tech tree is also very disappointing, no sense of progression gained from it at all.  Build a building then you can spend a long time researching a selection of three buffs.  Woohoo.

So no.  Not for me.

Now to start off i want to say that i both adore this game and dislike it at the same time. I will now attempt to explain why in this review and probably end up ranting in the process. This is my first time reviewing a game so bear with me if the review is a bit shit. ;)

Now i haven't played a lot of Total: War games.... But i can confidently say that from all the Total: War games i've played and watched, the battle system is much better in this one. It feels a lot more satisfying, and it actually feels like you're doing damage for once, instead of 2 armies just staring each other to death. There is also many new interesting units and mechanics due to the fantasy setting. So yeah the battle system definitly improved a lot in my opinion.  

The setting of the Warhammer universe offers a nice and unique take on both Total: War and Warhammer. 
I personaly am a huge fan of the choice they made to stray away from the usual historical stuff to try something new instead.

Now to the bad stuff... The game is a lot more simple and has much less replayability than most other Total: War games. 
It becomes boring very fast due to the game pretty much playing out the exact same way everytime. This combined with the limited amount of factions makes the replayability much worse than previous titles. 

Now to wrap it all up. 
Is it a good game? Yes, very much so. 
Is it worth the full price? Nope.
I recommend picking it up on a sale if you're either a very avid Total: War fan, or someone completely new to the franchise. Play it for a bit, and see if you like it then you can pick up the dlc's afterwards.

As a TW game set in the Warhammer universe yes i absolutely recommend this game.
It's FANTASTIC. TW at its best IMO. It plays like any TW game but with Warhammer races. Dwarfs have great siege weapons, Chaos have gigantic beasts, Bretons have awesome Knight cavalry and so on.

Now i see a lot of people MOANING AND MOANING about the price, They're 100% right. This game and the Multitude of DLC for it are WAYYY too overpriced for how old the game is. However, If you can get it on sale like i did, You're laughing all the way to Eight Peaks with a flagon of Ale in one hand and a Greenskins head in the other.

IMO hands down one of the best games ever made, I loved historical (Shogun 2, Attila, Rome 2-once they fixed the glitches, Napolean/Empire back in the day) Total War games but the Warhammer series the best of the bunch. Keeping horde faction mechanics (and using it 4 Chaos) from Attila was genius. The monsters (shaggoths and bone dragons, and mammoths oh my! just2 name a few) and spells/hexes/items add many tactical options to the battles.  And of course the animations are uber dope, you can save battle replays to rewatch when that Chaos Giant stomps your enemies or that Comet of Casadora descends gloriously from the heavens to turn enemy heroes into a shimmering icy crater.  Campaign is well done with a fruck ton of factions (with purchase of expansion packs) and troop rosters. They keep improving the A.I. particularly the strategy map A.I. The battle AI is gettiing better but obviously multiplayer is the way to go if you want a real challenge. Lots of mods for people who like cheat codes and customizing. Warhammer 2 is also excellent, but as the series goes on the map gets bigger and bigger (which is awesome but more time consuming, lots of water and island hopping on a huuuge map).  Some people complain about Warhammer 1 because certain factions are restricted from "occupying" all the provinces on the map. (i.e. Human/Vampire cannot occupy Dwarf/Orc-Goblin). You can still Sack/Raze, but for those who absolutely must paint the whole map one color there is a mod that allows all factions to own all provinces.
Why do I love this game so much?  I love how many times you can replay the campaigns and it feels different every time, (even using your favorite faction over and over again).  I never get tire of playing the game, and its just as fun now (maybe more so) as when it first dropped so many years ago.  I used to play Warhammer tabletop when I was a kid- the tabletop had strategy and complexity but battles took forever and you had to memorize thousands of rules like a lawyer so it was way more work, and killing stuff will all the dice rolls could be like pulling teeth. For example on the tabletop, for each catapault you would have to guess a distance and then measure (with a tape measure i kid u not) it out in inches on the table(plus a "scatter" dice roll to account for accuracy skill of the catapault crew). Then put the damage radius circle down to see how many enemy models were hit and then armour rolls to see how many were killed. And at the end of that 3-5 min process usually the catapault misses and nobody dies. So yea the computer game version is way more action packed, very satisfying to group select 2-10 pieces of artillery and aim and fire them pretty much instantaneously (unless they are reloading) then watch fire and flame devastate the enemy ranks as enemy models fly through the air.  Battles are like your own personal Lord of the Rings movies, and Game of Thrones episodes. I just hope they keep making expansion packs for all the Warhammers not just Warhammer 2 (and eventually Warhammer 3 when it drops). Thank you Total War game developers, can't wait for more Warhammer games its the gold standard. Always looking for more content, keep it coming.

A fantastic addition to the series. Not only did they do Warhammer right, but I think that was probably the best type of game for Warhammer Fantasy to be done in. The graphics can kind of be wonky at times, the music is not so great, and the AI is terrible when it comes to diplomacy and other actions like co-ordination, but in the end the gameplay saves it all. Total War is a fantastic game franchise, and to see all of the different factions in Warhammer Fantasy and all of their units and war machines going at it is beautiful. I have had tons of fun playing this game, and I would probably have a lot more hours in it with the DLC and more factions to play, but that is another negative aspect to this game.

The amount of DLC and the price is pretty brutal. For some of them you get quite a lot, with some entire factions being changed depending on the DLC you get, but to still have Wood Elves at 22 dollars, or Norsca at 12, is just unforgivable. They are not that great, and after 4 years they shouldn't cost more than actual full length games that are out there. Then there is the fact that they charge you for blood and gore to be added. In a war game, set in Warhammer. That is just not right. Don't waste your money on the DLC, get the base game and the second game and play on the huge world map with all of the factions, it is great. I recommend this game, but only when it is on sale.

Im gonna go ahead and tell you guys that Total war games are not for the light of wallet.
Pros:
-Stays true to the Warhammer universe
-A lot of bugs have been (or are being) addressed. Not a disaster on release like Rome 2
-Community constantly pumping mods for you to try
-Campaign can be fun and is easier to grasp for new players

Cons: (This is where it gets good)
-Chaos DLC (Luckily I got this on release week) and already another coming out. RIP wallet
-Missing mechanics from previous Total war games (How is this game getting better reviews the Total war Attila?)
-only 4 playable factions without DLC's 
-Custom battles and multiplayer get repetitive and boring (Almost the same thing over and over)
-SEGA and CA will milk your wallet faster than steam sales do

All in all if you have time and money to burn this is for you but If you have money to burn in the first place then i think other Total war games are better (At least until a few patches and DLC's come out and make TW:Warhammer better)

Turn based strategy mixed with real time battles in a grim fantasy setting.  What's not to like?

If you're new to Total War I have to ask what rock you've been living under.  This game isn't for the feint hearted, and it certainly looks and plays the part of gothic edge lord.  You play as a lord of a faction in the Warhammer universe and your goal is domination by raising armies, fighting battles, taking cities and then rinse and repeat.  It has the Civilisation just one more turn aspect down and mixes in epic fantasy style battles with gruesome units and magic to boot (though you don't have to fight the battles if you don't want to).  If you've really never heard of Total War but are a fan of strategy games (and specifically real time strategy) then this could be for you.  Don't be put off with the Warhammer backdrop, you really don't need to geek out on the lore...if you don't want to.

Personally my favourite faction were the Vampire counts.  No one likes you but your units are kickass.  I mean who doesn't want to field a giant flying mutated bat thing whilst your undead ghost cavalry charge at the enemies flanks.  The different factions like the Empire, Dwarves and Orcs etc, change the general play style, strengths and weaknesses.  For instance the Vampire counts have no ranged units so a very vulnerable to gunfire, arrows or cannons.  But their units don't break per se and they have a pretty diverse range of flying and cavalry units to boot.  You can play both single and multiplayer skirmish battles or campaigns.  There is a number of DLC units and factions but the base game is still very good value with lots of replay value.  Still, it's best played with a friend or better against one!

Overall this was a surprising success of the Total War system mapped onto a fantasy setting.  I highly recommend for those into Total War or Total War like games as well as those into strategy and real time strategy alike.

A Bullet Point Review:

-To be brutally honest, in 2020, Warhammer Total War 1 should be treated as a very large DLC for Warhammer 2 (and soon, Warhammer 3) that adds all the Old World factions to the game as playable factions. If you're interested in playing the Empire, the Orks, the Dwarves, the Vampire Counts, or Bretonnia (except for any factions added as DLC in Warhammer 2 [or 3])  you need to buy Warhammer 1.
-All race sin this game have received significant changes and overhauls to how they work in Warhammer 2, such that they will be completely unrecognizeable between this game and the second.
-All DLCs for this game should be treated the same way: as DLC for the overall game package. All of it transfers over to the future games in the series.
-No changes in future games have been backported to Warhammer 1. There is no reason to play Warhammer 1 over 2 (or 3 in future) at this point, unless you feel really really nostalgic for some reason.
-Yes, there is a lot of DLC. However, all of that DLC represents *playable* content. All of the factions and units added will still be present in your game to fight against. You only need to purchase the DLC if you are interested in using the units and factions yourself. If you never want to play Wood Elves, don't buy Wood Elves - they'll still exist for you to beat up endlessly. Same for the Lord Packs - don't want to play Belegar or Skarsnik? Don't buy King and the Warlord. They'll still exist, but you can't confederate them or play as them.
-This game, and the DLC, often goes on very heavy sales now due to its age. If you want to stock up, wait for a sale and do so, remembering the above: you only need to buy what you want to play and use. If you want everything, wait for a sale!

I don't have anything else to say here - Warhammer 1 as a game is totally deprecated due to the existence of Warhammer 2, and should only be viewed as a DLC investment for future games in the series, not as an actual game to be played in itself. All other DLCs, and the games in general, should be viewed in light of that investment - yes, it's a lot of money, but there is an absolutely fantastical amount of content here. This series is the *definitive* Warhammer Fantasy Battles experience, for lovers of tabletop and lovers of strategy games.

Well, I've been playing total war for the last 15 years. This has proven to be the most bug free experience so far. The different factions all have a unique twist to them so the game play seems fresh for longer as well. Good graphics and effects as always. However, my biggest complaint is how lazy things feel sometimes. 

For balance reasons there are times where several full strength armies just spawn in your territory or behind it. The spawning of chaos armies makes sense, since they are the main game event. However, other than that, it just feels like "Oh, you got your alliances, economy, and armies well organized and operating effectively? Here have a distraction, so the game seems longer and more challenging." Fortunately, you can memorize the spawn points and just deal with it and move on. AI is kinda simple, but good enough.

Total War: Warhammer is great, combining Games Workshop's classic fantasy setting with the design genius that is Total War. Absolutely a perfect combination. The first game of the series is good and I recommend it, but it does feel a little flatter compared to Warhammer II which took the series to a new level. 

If you are thinking of getting this only for the ability to play the Mortal Empires campaign in Warhammer II, then I still recommend it as that campaign is truly epic.

As with all Total War games, the fluidity and the adaptability of this game is awe-inspiring.

[b]Pro's[/b]
- Seamless large scale wargames with massive armies of largely free play units
- Graphics are fantastic (for an RTS game)
- True feel to the large scale battles that I believe are accurate to the way these war's would of progressed
- Wide roster list for every faction to suit every playstyle
- Repeat gameplay value is high, with no two playthroughs ever the same
- AI (whilst sometimes clunky and counterproductive) can recognise its own opportunities, and can challenge you at most difficulty levels by capitalising on your mistakes

[b]Con's[/b]
- If you don't like having to wait on loading screens, this game will not be one you enjoy (but in my opinion loading is worth it!)
- If you only play one way, and your playstyle is best suited to one race/faction, you may get bored, and the replayability can be affected
- The 'Quick-Match' game modes are exactly that; do not expect to be able to jump in and out of campaign at a moments notice

A solid addition to the Total War Franchise, and even better mixed in with one of my favourite fantasy worlds!

10/10 would recommend to both Pro and Casual RTS gamers
Slighty grindy & repetitive but very epic & fun overall!

This (and TW:WH2) is my first experience with Total War and very nearly my first experience with the Warhammer setting. I've recently gotten into strategy games again (after a hiatus of a couple decades), and this scratches the fantasy itch very well. As strategy games go, Total War seems kind of odd; it is part turn-based (where recruitment, building, diplomacy, economy, etc. happen) and part real-time (tactical, confusing combat). This is worth trying if you haven't played such a game before (and I'm not sure whether such games exist outside the Total War series).

Warhammer is a grimdark fantasy setting, kind of like a D&D setting where everyone only thinks of murder all the time. If that sounds like your cup of tea, grab this (especially since it seems to get a deep discount fairly often).
It is pretty complex and confusing but I am learning about it and it feels AWESOME so far.

my generation and the one that came before me believed too much in the strength of character and the beauty of hope. The one that came before me believed too much in the victory of authority and the bleakness of the future.

But not many believe in the teachings of the god king Sigmar, the Wolf god Ulric and the many protector deities of the Old World. Not many believed that even while the world ended, you had no other recourse but to pick up that sword, load that gun, aim that crossbow and stand firm. For as Sigmar once said.
"There can be no victory, for the darkness. Always returns."
And yet, it does not matter.

Too many believed in the strength of character and the beauty of love, too many feared the bleakness of the future and the power of defeat.

Not enough believed that never mattered. It only mattered that you fought.

Faith, Steel and Gunpowder. The Empire prevails.

By then your only choice of enemy has 2 or 3 army stacks.  You spend more time fiddling with nonsensical things than actually fighting. The actual fights are fun, but enemy is always stronger than you, regardless of when you engage and always wins "even" fights.  Fight strategies dont seem to make much difference like they did in Rome Total War.  One battle I repeatedly charged my cavalry into archers and somehow lost.  If you love banging your head against the wall or spending 30+ hours in research before starting, go ahead and get it.

If you have no idea what Total War: Warhammer is or how it plays, think of Civilization with real time battles set in a fantasy world/setting thats been around since 1982. If you like grand campaigns with considerations of economy vs military, diplomacy, and conquest, this one has all of that. There are different factions, which for the most part play the same but have different goals or mechanics or unit strengths to take into consideration. Every lord of the same faction has a slightly different start, be it different units in starting army, or different enemies to take on first. All of the different factions and lords provide a lot of different flavors to the game play that keeps it fresh and exciting. This holds true also for Warhammer 2.

Even in a time when Total War: Warhammer 2 exists, Warhammer 1 is still a game worth buying and playing, for a few reasons. At the very least, owning both Warhammer 1 and 2 gives you access (for free) to the mortal empires campaign, which is a map that combines the eye of the vortex campaign map from Warhammer 2 with the Old World map in Warhammer 1, and allows you to play any race from either game in it. This means that just owning Warhammer 1 is worth while, especially if you pick it up during a steam sale, like say the one going on now (written 6/27/2020).

However, there are more reasons to get and play Warhammer 1 than the extra content you get for Warhammer 2. One such benefit is you don't have to deal with those Skaven rat bastards, lol. There are some other differences in the game play, like in Warhammer 2 when you control a whole province, no matter the race, you get to issue a commandment for some extra benefit, like growth, recruitment, or money. In Warhammer 1, not all races have that. Also, in Warhammer 1, you can't settle in towns that are not suitable to your faction like you can in Warhammer 2. The differences aren't really enough to throw you off, but are enough to offer a compelling reason to play Warhammer 1 as well as Warhammer 2.

If I had one complaint about Warhammer 1, its that even 4 years after its release, there isn't a definition edition you can buy that has all the content for one low price, say $30 or $45. Given how much DLC both games have and how they're all pretty much $9 or $20 USD, the price really quickly adds up, even if you are picking it up during a sale. 

Anyway to wrap it up, Warhammer 1 is worthwhile on its own merits and as a dlc pack for Warhammer 2, in my opinion, especially if Warhammer 3 continues the tradition and lets you play factions from previous games.

I played several Total Wars but never was I confronted with such a beautiful experience. It's a new world for me, with new art / graphics style, very easy to comprehend battles but many challenges. I love the setting, artstyle and how the battles and campaign play. The UI is really nice, even if I wish for more hotkeys (for provinces and settlements for example). The game is really good at immersing you in this beautiful, heroic world full of magic and wonders - and exciting battles with tons of different units and strategies. You really become invested in the race you choose and its struggle for survival and domination in this epic universe I didn't know a thing about prior to playing - but that is very easy to love !



The only thing I regret is the struggle for survival of my (average) gaming laptop, even in low settings the game stays quite beautiful and so you have long loading screens and it can make your PC heat up a little. I write this review specifically for people that think they can play this game with 2 or more friends. This is NOT civilizations where you can have several friends all playing in the same game with or against each other in a massive empire building sim with added real-time RTS type battles. You can only do this as 2 person head-to-head or co-op. 
The only portion that supports additional players beyond that is the battles mode, which is just one-off battles between armies with no empire-building mechanics involved. If you are into that or just want to play the 1 or 2 player campaign modes, then by all means buy and enjoy. Just don't buy intending to play the campaign mode with more people than you'd play chess with.

Wow! This game has SO little to do with an Empire building / Empire management game. It's all about attacking, losing settlements, gaining some, wash, rinse, repeat, with zero strategic planning nor strategic development possible! Just go-go-go attack, attack, attack! You'll win at the end, but clearly this has NOTHING to do with true Empire management game! You are even slapped with severe "procrastinator" (traits) penalties if you decide to opt for managing your empire from your capital city for a few turns, through improvements and diplomacy, etc. 
And the most boring consequences of this style of gameplay is that you only have an 'illusion' of decision-making freedom. But the truth is you have to follow a very linear and highly 'guided' path: i.e. attack whoever is the weakest player the AI has placed there underneath your nose for you (regardless if this would make any sense for any Emperor trying to strategically build a lasting Empire)...or else! Really: Anything else will get you punished with a swift defeat!
This game is clearly made by and for RTS or first shooter CSGO / Fortnite / MOW or COH 'chicken-with-no-head' types of gaming. But NOT for Total War, Strategic, or Empire management fans!
Sad as it is otherwise robust and looking real good and could have been the GGOAT (Greatest Game Of All Time!). But this is NOT a Total War game at all! And I am now running back to Total War Rome I and Medieval II ...in a hurry!
Buyers Beware!

Be Prepared to pay for DLC after DLC including one that Puts BACK in existing content that was removed to secure a better PEGI age score.

4 year old Base Game: $60
The REST of the game: $85 and counting

GAMEPLAY:
The fine folks at CA Watered down the territory management found in previous titles.  Which may not me a bad thing for micromanagement but it means when you lose a settlement you take a serious hit.  That said, the AI cant even handle the few tasks it must do so its given bonuses, immunity to attrition that devastates players, gets free gold and units, insteant heals and respawns, and cheats.

Be prepared to always have an inferior army because somehow, you having 8 settlements, wont be able to field an army as big as your neighbor who is down to his last town!

How many times did I max out my upkeep costs to put an army of 18 units, supported by an army of 12, marched on the enemy city to be faced with a 20 stack, with a second 20 stack in range to reinforce, and a garrison of what seemed like millions of troops?  If you attack, you die.  if you call off the attack, they bum rush you with yet another 20 stack that was hiding somewhere.  Now its 60 vs 30.  And if you take his last city?  well he amazingly had 3 twenty stacks hidden near your cities and quickly devastates your homeland so you are left with less than what you started with.

I WANT to like this game.

Why I don‚Äôt recommend this game 

This game was the creative assembly‚Äôs jumping the shark moment. This game blindsided fans and sharply divided the fan base of the series. I know and have met many total war players and YouTubers and anyone that has been with the series for a long time was shocked at this game coming out. It is painfully clear that the creative assembly got their hands on the cheapest license they could get while still making the most amount of money from their existing fanbase and the warhammer fanbase. I looked into the warhammer series after this game came out and it‚Äôs not as popular as the total war series. Many total war fans had never heard of or played a game for this series before. It also basically started off as a board game. Total war was originally supposed to be a historical RTS sandbox but CA fell to greed with this. Total war‚Äôs fan base has shown that they aren‚Äôt opposed to the series doing a fantasy game but the most popular choices for that among fans would have been game of thrones or the lord of the rings, both have been made into very popular mods for total war medieval 2. There isn't much wrong with the game on a graphical, mechanics, and technical level, but that is really the only saving grace.

cons

This game was like apple's failed U2 album giveaway, it was executed without error, but it drew the ire of a lot of people, especially those who were blindsided by it and/or never heard of it. Overall 0 out of 10 for what it did the fanbase and the total war community.

This past weekend, I just built my first gaming pc in 12 years (been on 360/Ps4 since then).  I really missed Total War games (grew up with the original Shogun/Medieval/Rome, etc...) and the last TW game I played was Empire.  I decided on Warhammer first even at full price just to get back into it and....

I LOVE IT!!!!!!!!

PROS:
-unique factions (love the vampire units / chaos units / orc units) and the flavour of unique battles most of the time
-unmodded diplomacy seems a lot better than older titles (I was unreliable so couldn't trade).  I have focused my attacks on vampires/chaos/beastmen and gradually I am trustworthy again, have alliances with other empire factions/dwarves and have lots of trade agreements meaning lots of monies!  Seems to be working as it should
-Big battles!  I love that the ai (even unmodded) seems to be able to put together full stacks all over the place meaning I get the big battles i sometimes wouldnt get in earlier titles
-Easy army setup - I love that the army creation is now from the commander vs having to recruit from towns
-Great mods! I added some mods that suited my tastes and even if they show as outdated I have had no issues
-1 crash in 18 hours from reloading a save file but otherwise has been very stable and great frames

Cons:
-I wish they had more of the troop movement options like they do in empire (rotate / move forward buttons) actually in the ui when controlling units.  As well better built in army auto assigned orders/ai so I dont have to micro-manage as much (dont stand around if you routed an enemy, find someone else to fight!) to allow me to enjoy the battles a bit more.

When Warhammer II goes on sale I will be getting it for the Mortal Empires campaign and to try out the other factions!
I was a fan of old RTS like 15-20 years ago, and I decided to build me a pc to play some again, THIS game did not disapoint and it confirmed to me that I made the right move! I LOVE IT

I have mixed feelings, let me explain!

Lets start with the positive. I gave a thumb up because I would definitely recommend to play it. The game is challenging, which is not bad. Battles are very well made I like it very much. First [b] 5-10 [/b] hours this was the best game ever, lots of variability, different things and approaches, super cool units and races. You will have a lot of fun, until...

After some time the game started to get a little bit [b] frustrating [/b] due to some issues:
- The non stopping pressure from every side, i feel like there is too much enemies, you cannot not leave your developing cities alone or immediately some dimwit dark sided enemies come and SACK IT. (You also cannot defend all of them because you do not have enough income for enough armies)
- I feel like enemies come out of nowhere. (some kind of watchtower system or increased visibility in the map is missing)
- [u] the battle will take place outside of the settlement [/u], this should definitely be changed, making [b] walls [/b] to your settlements takes way to long.
- Enemy [b] lords [/b] are way too overpowered but yours dies in middle of a combat every...time and fast. However, playing with the lords and using the spells during battles is one of my favorite things in this game!
- The overall [b] income [/b] is too low and the army upkeep is too high. You might be at turn 100 and chaos knocking at your door and you still do not have the best units upgraded, neither enough armies (because you can't keep them up)
- Public order changes too much and is too difficult to get up -> rebels appear (too easily)
- Artillery is not useful enough
- Have horses been nerfed too much?

I always have been looking for the fantasy genre and I have an overview of a many of fictional worlds.. the world of Warhammer is not exception - I knew and admired it long before this game was released, I read several books and searched the unofficial wikipedia. Where am I going with this?
The TW Warhammer project reached my absolute first place in popularity and changed my gaming life (of course I mean the whole three-part series).. Warhammer took the crown.

The style of play is the same as in any Total War - building an empire, fighting for territory, diplomatic agreements, player-controlled and detailed battles.
The story of this part of the Warhammer takes place in the "old world" (type of middle-earth), where factions are crammed into each other and have to fight for supremacy and survival from the very beginning. We have a choice of several playable races such as Empires, Bretonnians, Dwarfs, Wood Elves, Greenskins, Vampires, Norscans, Beastmen and Chaos.
The politics of the world is based on the idea - everyone can fight with everyone, but this is not the case everywhere, cooperation between factions and races is often key to survival, or to victory. How the individual races get together (for the uninterested of this topic) is a diplomatic tool in the game, which will show who has an aversion or affinity towards whom, or what a large number of the mentioned feelings. Classically, some races are good and some are bad. Some races are peacemakers or builders and some races are aggressors or exterminators.
Each race has different life goals, a different style of play, different fighting tactics, different diplomacy, a different army, different conditions of victory. A everything Warhammer has to offer can take a lot of game hours.

Certainly there are still a lot of players who have not yet had the opportunity to get into the game for various reasons and do not even know what they are missing. I recommend correcting this mistake. [b] 100% [/b]

Preface by saying that I don't even care about the DLC policy. If this was Medieval 2 Strategy and siege warfare + this games theme and battles I would buy all DLC and put the 500+ hours into it I put into that game. 

I played the original Shogun, Medieval 1 and 2, Shogun 2, Rome (the first one) I tried the buggy mess that was Empire Total War. I skipped Rome 2 and Attilla based on reviews about the oversimplified Strategic level.

I like the Theme (why I took a chance on this game). The lore is interesting. The races are cool and different (the tried and true paper rock scissors remains in place) The battles remain fun when the odds are stacked against you (even if they are over in a minute). I like the heroes. I love the Chaos invasion. 

However this remains a completely dumbed down total war (which was apparently true for Rome 2 and Attila). Total war used to be half strategy (campaign map), half tactics (real time battles). Now the "strategy" is take over a province and spread out your building across four settlements. Want to build more than 4 buildings? Too bad. What to choose your garrison forces? too bad. (Garrisons are upkeep free though, because free soldiers make sense.) Worried about where you want your barracks? Don't worry your troops just jump into your army from the far side of the province. Logistics are irrelevant. Chase stupid AI armies across the map and fight glorious (way too fast though) battles. Watch helplessly as a Beastman stack appears in your indefensible settlements (because yeah no fortifications and default boring garrisons)

I wish the game makers would realize that a meaningful Strategic experience will make the battles much more fun in the first place. I care a lot less when I lose a settlement that I invested no thought or effort into. there are no meaningful choices for towns. You always need the money building, you probably need the defense building and one settlement builds a barracks of some type and the unrest building. The worst part, simplification of the strategic level makes no sense since the battles are hardly appealing to a mindless clicker. I want real choices and resource management. 

Bottom line, I recommend this game to people who love the realtime battles, but for anyone who prefered the strategic side of it, no. It really just makes me want to go play Medieval TW 2.

As a budget gamer, I picked this up on sale. Of course. I am a Big fan of the total war series.  I have Rome 1 and 2, Empire, Shogun 2, Attila. When this series was released, I kinda poo pooed it. I was a purist when it came to total war series. I felt they needed to be historic only. I never got into the Warhammer table top games, even though I have been playing D&D since the 80's. and an otherwise  big RPG MMO type nerd. Well the last sale was a good one and I had some extra time and a little money in the entertainment column of the budget, so I said what the heck, why not. Man I was surprised, I really like it. It has had me engaged for the last week since the sale. I did pick up Warhammer 1 also. I have now 4 or 5 different campaigns with different factions going on both WH 1 WH 2. If you got the dough, pick up for regular price. If your on a budget wait for a sale, they both come with some free DLCs too. What I like waiting for a sale and not picking up a game when it's first out, is obvious the savings, but the loads of Mods in the workshop. This Total War offering does not disappoint in this area, I played it for about an hour before I loaded all the best mods for it. I do this a lot as the modding community is very talented and makes the games way better. IMHO.

Sure the game manage to instruct the player on how to play, move the camera and armies.

A much needed edition to the total war series, Warhammer and total war an amazing combo.  Being a total war fan there was a lot of stigma to making a fantasy total war since fans of the series were used to historical titles, but in my opinion besides Medieval 2 Total War this is my favorite.  It adds tons of gameplay changes while a lot of the older titles didn't experiment much.  Whether it was legendary lords, flying units, monsters, magic or others the battles felt a lot more chaotic and engaging.  Not to mention I had started to feel with recent titles that faction rosters were too much the same being copy pasta from one faction to another, in Total War Warhammer while fewer each faction feels drastically different and made me feel like I had to play through each of them.  Each faction also has their own set of legendary heroes that has quests you could complete to gain equipment for your character this could also be done through battles making your hero insanely powerful.  Besides the equipment that they can equip, the legendary lords you get can also level up buffing their stats further and allowing you to put points into a skill tree.

There are many other things I could say about Total War Warhammer, but I feel to me this covers why I would buy it, I would rate this game a 9/10.

I LOVE Total War Battlefield!!! ...I HATE the STUPID things they do on the campaign map that almost totally ruin the game.

DIPLOMACY:
1. Create a Diplomacy System to raise expectations and brag about features,
2. Make sure the Diplomacy mechanics are horribly unfair and broken,
3. Release new version of game and gather feedback,
4. Revise the Diplomacy system based on feedback and remove everything still usable,
5. Repeat from Step 3.

The only thing 'new' about this diplomacy system is that Diplomacy is a more useless aspect since there is nothing the computer can give you other than trade income. It all still works the same, make alliances with everyone, if anyone tries to drag you into conflict just check which of them has more enemies and break your alliance with the hated one. Your reputation will always be steadfast.

...if they made the trade agreement automatic for non-hostile factions, i think no one would ever need to click the "Diplomacy" button. They could make things clearer by just replacing the computer responses with "No" or "I'll stab you in the back later."

PLAYABILITY:
I think the issue at the center of the CA teams struggle with making a good Computer AI is that they don't seem to grasp the difference between 'Competitive and Challenging' versus say 'Cheating your Ass Off'.
  There is facing off against a computer opponent that is operating under the same limitations and on an equal playing field while still being difficult to beat. And then there is fighting against an opponent whose interpretation of Hidden is "I know where they are, I just need to get LOS before shooting them in the face", or say turning off the 'Routing' mechanic for the computers troops.
  The former is what I would call 'Challenging' or enjoyable 'Competition'; the latter though, I would put more in the category of 'very annoying' or 'stupid'.

I'm an old guy, I used to paint minatures and build battlefields long before games like this made their debut.  I remember how much it cost for individual minatures, game books, guides, materials.  It was wort the premium back then simply because of the physical aspects - heavy lead figures that you personally put time into painting.  Table top could justify the expense.  I'm sorry but it just doesn't translate to digital for me.

Grab this game or any other in the franchise when they have a franchise sale.  It's definitely worth the price at 40 - 60% off.

Just...dreadful. This was my first Total War game and I now regret every brain cell I ever spent keeping the series in mind for when I finally had a computer that could run one.

All 13 hours of my game time were as Dwarves, the "easy" campaign, and every minute of each failed game was frustrating in all the wrong ways. And, frankly, the game is far too grindy for me to care to try again.

Apparently the trick as Dwarves, reading peoples' guides, is to sit and turtle for dozens of turns until each and every one of your settlements are completely garrisoned and equipped with city walls. Or go to one province north of the starting position, completely not where the tutorial tells you your main enemies are, and then turtle for dozens of turns. Which is maybe thematically appropriate but boring as hell.

And not even a sure indicator of success, in large part because of the cheating, unpredictable AI. Unpredictable not in the sense of devious, but just...random. Some games the Greenskin ork faction would absorb other ork factions every other turn, ensuring that they were quickly able to send numerous full armies and just demolish anything I had. Many of those armies were recruited free as a result of the "Waagh" mechanic, of course. Other games the orks would do almost nothing. Except send out seemingly endless numbers of their heroes, which unlike your heroes have no cooldowns on using their incredibly disruptive abilities and the AI often gets to recruit for free.

Speaking of cheating, the AI is able to abuse the movement stances to a frankly ludicrous degree, granting them huge amounts of free movement. In addition, the AI does not suffer from fog of war and knows the location of every one of your units. The result is that the AI frequently positions its armies either at the very edge or completely beyond your movement range. And apparently gets to retreat for free, on your turn. I had multiple instances where I ordered an attack only for the opposing army to just get an extra hop back once I had completely exhausted my army's movement getting into range. So be prepared to be kited for multiple turns before you even get to a battle.

And the battles quickly become tedious. You rarely wipe out an enemy force, just get it down to maybe a third health (or not even that). So the next turn you have to repeat the battle again. And again, And again. Or more likely just have another army come zooming in from BF nowhere to reinforce the guys you just walloped, and now outnumber you because most battles are grinding slogs of attrition that rarely destroy individual units let alone whole armies.

For the last game I used a bunch of mods to disable some of the AI cheats and reduce enemy hero spam and it was still frustrating as hell. Gave up when I trounced 3 different armies in one turn, only for all of them to emerge from the battle with about half health, then turn around and gang up on me the next turn and collectively destroy me.

I got this on sale for $15, plus $5 for one of DLCs. For that $20 I could have bought a copy of Into The Breach. I already own ITB and it's utterly brilliant, a genuinely clever and fiendishly brain twisting strategy game. I wouldn't have got 1 minute of playtime for that extra copy. But I could have gifted it to a friend and they could have played a great game, and I could have enjoyed them playing a great game, and instead I got to "enjoy" Total War: Warhammer.

Less Warhammer and more...Boringhammer.

The perfect adaptation of the tabletop game to PC. Warhammer mods were made for Total War games years before this was ever announced, but this is the real deal. It feels like you're commanding the armies in a way you never could even with the minis. I also find this to be the most fun to play Total War game, with more varied and interesting armies than any other. The only downside is the high cost of this game and TW: Warhammer II with all their DLCs. I'd recommend going for whichever race interests you the most and buying the game/DLC which has them to start, and to wait until they're on sale. That being said, even buying both games with DLC at full price wouldn't be as expensive as collecting one army for the tabletop.

Final prognosis: this is the ultimate Warhammer Fantasy experience. Get it if you're a fan of either Warhammer or Total War, or just war games in general.

DId my best here to just keep playing. But the AI is so against you in every aspect to force you to lose it's anti fun. It's more of a chore to play this game even with mods specifically trying to stop AI from cheating. 

Ai don't care, even though they should, about the oncoming chaos or beastmen. They only care about you losing to them. Your allies will raid you, purposefully send their assassins against you, not help against any sort of rebellion THEY end up causing and actually take your forts if you lose them to the beastmen, chaos, or rebels. On easy mode. The Ai BEG for peace and the minute you give it to them they immediately start encamping and raiding your towns ceaselessly, even if they're losing at their own base. You look bad if you do anything against them, move on their land, you look bad, raid you look bad, sneeze,  you're the incarnation of Nurggle and deserve death. 

This game looks incredibly fun but it's to have fun when the AI knows your every fucking movement both out of the field and on it. Over the top it looks like Civ, best comparison I have, with cities/settlements and your armies moving around. You have a general for every army so you don't have a giant cluster of soldiers. The AI seems to know without a drop of a beat where your generals are 100% of the time on the map without any vision or given thought. They'll march against you without any cause to block you or immediately run away the minute  your army turns around and starts heading back from the other side of the map. The battles now are just BS. They tell and try to teach you about ambushing your enemies where I believe they took away the AI's map hack. Follow it up with other points of conflict they know 100% of the time where you are at all times. Even if you're troops aren't moving, have been hiding the whole time, and are ready to try for a flank the enemy will immediately disband a part of their army to head straight toward yours even though they have yet to even see them. I've had this happen now multiple times to where it's not even worth setting up a flank or surprise attack it's just "well I guess I never get to do this." even though the AI has actually done this before in hiding their troops in tree's and buildings then rushing me after a minute when they caught their breath. 

If a game has to resort to cheating, like also giving the AI a bonus to auto-resolving a fight, it's not worth even bothering to play or support. Stay away from this game unless you can apperantly get the second one. They said, and people who support it, that they fixed all the AI issues and more. However with the amount of mods that have to tinker the game and that I'm actually told to get if I want the AI to be winnable against I doubt it. My recommendation unless you're a Total War fan looking for a fantasy based game this your game if not stay away from it.Not worth the hassle

Edit is here: If you do plan on getting this, wait for a sale. This game is not worth the $60 price tag it STILL has after a coupld of years now. It should be more along the lines of $30 especially with the dlc, majority of it, still being either $10 or $20 depending on what you get. Get the second game, see if you like it, then come back here when this is on a major sale and get the other races. Do not support this money grubbing tactic.

This is my favorite Total War game. I think the fantasy setting opened up a lot of new design space for the series, and you can see it used in the addition of character quests. The number of ways heroes can support your lords allows many unique strategies to conquer the old world. I just finished my first long campaign at about 40 hours, and it was glorious. I am looking forward to trying the other factions next. That brings up my one major complaint. The paid DLC factions are super overpriced. I definitely intend to buy Total War: Warhammer 2 because of the integrated campaign feature that is free if you own both games. I wouldn't mind paying $60 or $80 for the two games together, but the current sales structure disappoints me.

Another disappointing Total War title.

UPDATE:  Ok, i have added another 24 hours of game play because i really WANT to like this game.  But i cannot, in good conscience, recommend a game that cannot even follow its own rules.

I have inflicted crushing defeats on enemy stacks, watched them retreat a few inches, and attacked them a second time in the same turn, only to find that the entire army of 90% depleted retreating foes had SOMEHOW replenished itself to 100% in those few inches and while STILL on MY SAME turn.

In this last campaign i started, i saw my capitol sacked by an army of Green-skins consisting of 16 all but invulnerable LATE GAME units, and the campaign was a mere 8 turns in.  Not even a full TEN turns.  They spawned inside my province, marched and sacked in the same turn, crushing not only the standard garrison, but the general and his 13 units i had stationed within the city.

The tutorial adviser had only JUST explained what "offices" were the turn before.

These weren't the only questionable events, but you get the idea.

If the only way you can program a challenging AI is to give it cheats, then QUIT.  There were games with better AI crapped out in 1995.

I have played most of the Total War games and most of them i liked, but i'm seeing more and more truly shoddy work squeezed out by these publishers.  They spew out so many projects that they are becoming spamware.

Finished Total War: Warhammer. Played on Linux. Well, "finished" may not be the precise term. I've mastered the Grand Campaign with The Empire, The Dwarfs, Bretonnia, Greenskin, Wood Elves, and the Vampire Counts... and this game is awesome! It is the sort of game that gets you hooked on playing "just the next turn".

The graphics and the sound is nice and captures the Warhammer look & feel known and expected from the tabletop game. Apart from some minor glitches (e.g. having some crashes) and some wired idiosyncrasies (e.g. navigating armies across the sea is not calculated by the pathfinding algorithm, need to "exchange" troops to be sure the same army is in the attack range of the other, ...) the game plays very smoothly. Each faction has their unique playing style, and some are harder than others. However, each has its own pros and cons.

Ok: micro-management of cities and overall gameplay could be more complex in the campaign part. Yet it does not stand in your way. One will also find some optimization here in there in the player navigation on the menus when one really wants to find something, e.g. more than once I found myself typing escape to abort a hero's action, only to be confronted with the "Exit Game" dialog, huh?

Ah, yes and the stupid implementation of probabilities! The game tells you that your hero has a success chance of X%. Well, the game did already role the dice on that one and only shows you this number it had [b]before[/b](!). It took me a while to figure that out. I read that this is to prevent Quick-Save - Quick-Load series until your hero succeeds. ... which turned out in a Quick-Save - Quick-Load if the hero fails to save the money spent. Errm, this is not how math works, does it?

But still: a must-have for strategy fans, a feast on tactics.
