I mean, game has its good sides. Warhammer universe for its fans, warhammer units and okayish battles. In this installation of TW series there are some other experiments turned shitty: expensive DLCs of each additional race, limit of how many armies you can field due to increasing army tax (my dwarven empire spanning half map can affod 7 armies. In previous installments you could run 15 armies easily, allowing epic battles). Then there are chaos spawning without upkeep with monstrous armies - 4 armies with full stacks, which you cannot afford with funtioning economy for first 50 turns). Also at the same time Norska attacks, and if both decide to attack you, you are pretty much screwed, as you 5-6 armies ar usually split while cleaning up last goblins. So you reload few times, until Chaos army decides to kill Empire. As even empire has only 4-5 armies, Chaos usually burns down half of empire before it can be repelled. After your victory there are still random army spawns of chaos and goblins, so you have to chase those respawns constantly. I am wrapping up dwarf campaign and not sure if I want to try human campaign due to those issues.

First Total War game I have ever played. It would be okay if it was not designed to annoy you instead of letting you have a good time fighting battles. Some of the problems with this game:

- AI cheats in campaign movement. You will spend a lot of time wandering why an army dwarfs that hauls cannons across Reikwald forest is faster than your cavalry that is chasing them. You cannot catch the enemy armies and they often refuse to fight. Thy want to win by making you quit playing the game.
- non functional diplomacy designed only to keep you at war and under pressure. Small state that cannot expand to your cities and has been your friend all along declares war on you because it helps another state across the map. Factions commit suicide by going to war with you when you are way stronger. Friends never stay friendly for long. Also you cannot give liberated provinces and cities back to your friends or trade territory at all. 
- in campaign there was something called chaos invasion that killed almost every other AI faction and left half of the map in ruins. It resets the game and suddenly you play something else.  
- Battles get boring because AI doesn't have too many strategies and the complicated ones mostly work against them. For example undead cavalry positions on your flanks and waits until their main army approaches, but they are waiting in range of our crossbows. So you kill them before their friends arrive. AI is more successful with a head on attack. After a while you just make sure you have the numbers and auto resolve everything.

This game and TWW2 are probably the most fun I've had with any TW game and I've been playing them since Shogun 1 and have played them all except for Empires. 
 
The varied units among the factions including the heroes and lords, along with the strength and weakness associated with said units made each battle a challenge.  I was actually excited when someone new attacked me because I had no idea what they were going to field in battle and I found out what works against one faction, does not necessary work against others.  

For instance, played my campaign as the Dwarves with Thorgrim Grudgebearer as my legendary lord and learned over time that what strategy was effective against Orcs, is not necessarily so with Vampire Counts or other factions. First time going against Vlad von Carstein they rolled my army with all sorts of units I had not seen yet!  Giant bats, some corpse cart thing, and demon wolves OH MY!  Army was routed before I knew what to do and this was the same army of Dwarves that was destroying Orcs fairly easily.  It's a rock, paper, scissor match against units sometimes, however you can have the rock, paper, and scissors at the same time in your army.  Just takes good placement, timing, and patience.  It takes a defeat or two to figure out where you are going wrong.

In the end is this a great game, yes!  Is it for everyone, no.  Learning curve if you have never played a TW game is steep.  Even on easy and being able to pause battles you may still lose due to superior enemy units or strategy, but to me that's half the fun...fixing those mistakes.  Campaign can also be equally unforgiving if you aren't paying attention to who's allied with who and putting your forces too deep into enemy lines.  It does, along with all TW games has a great tutorial and a pretty detailed built-in instruction guide.  You also have an adviser that does a good job of keeping aware of the going ons in your empire like unhappy population which can lead to rebellion armies popping up and other things like that.  If you are a veteran TW gamer like me, I really have a hard believing you would not like this game, unless you don't like a fantasy-based game and prefer more historical ones.  Game is worth full price IMO but it has been on sale the last two Steam events at 75% off I believe and is definitely worth it then.

Also, addressing the DLCs....not at all necessary and don't see what the complaining is about.  Get Dwarves, Empire (humans), Bretonnia (humans), Orcs, and Vampire Counts right away.  Those also all have at least one sub-faction too available.  Tons of hours can be spent just on those alone.  Have 50 hours on one campaign!

Total war: Warhammer is a turn based game with the option to do battles in real time. I really love the game. I love it to the point where it's easier to point out it's flaws than to list everything I felt it has done right. The atmosphere and portrayal of the Warhammer world as well as the faction diversity put it heads and shoulders above other total war games and orders above other medieval RTS games. I think I'll break this review up into my mental notes about the notable mechanics in this game in order to give you guys the most complete look at this game that I can.

Single player: This is mainly a turn based empire management game- Like Europa universalis or Crusader Kings from paradox- with the option to do rts battles whenever you get involved in a fight. The turn based part is much funner than it could be because of how different factions have different mechanics and wildly different play styles than other factions and add to the uniqueness and replayabillity. My criticism here lies in the turn-based nature of the game and the lack of starting areas. 

turn based games seem to naturally tend toward being frustrating when they're complex. This is probably gonna be the reason why you refund the game or rage quit. losing a town because of dumb oversights and misunderstandings are gonna happen if you try to be inquisitive because, imo, minor mistakes and major mistakes get the same punishment in turn based games. Setting up an ambush a little much to the right or positioning your army a pixel reinforcement range of a settlement in the case of a seige get punished in exactly the same way as ignoring the goddamn enemy army entirely and raiding your own provinces. Your still gonna lose that settlement, have to deal with a rebellion and get emotionally drained. Turn based games can still be fun, but there are gonna be a lot of moments where you get the socks raged off ya. As for starting areas, I don't like the base ones. It gives you the option multiple lords per faction but all the lords start off in that factions capital and are working for their cannonical leader- which is lame. Like your telling me Manfred's frollicing through meadows while I'm subjugating the world and putting down insurections?

Typical Manfred.

The only other problem with the game is that it's loading screens are waaaaay to long. way to long.

As for the battles; they are fun but sometimes I feel like Lords shoudln't just automatically retreat from a battle. After a certain point- even if they're fresh tomatoes- your units will just give up and not make a final last stand. That's lame but kinda acceptable, I wasn't gonna win anyway. But the speed that it happens and the fact that my general runs too is what makes it feel so unfair.

Those are the problems. I mean, they're are a lot of reasons to get this game but those are the reasons why this isn't my favorite game, it's frustrating a lot of the time. still, it's fun.

I have returned to this game after playing it when it first came out. At that point it was a good game. With the changes the patches and DLC have made it is now a very, very, good game. 

The amount of different races you can play and with the huge Mortal Empires campaign the replay value for me is staggering (not to mention the many mods for the game). I think the fantasy setting is a sweet spot for Total War games.  It seems to have allowed the developers the freedom to set up very interesting and balanced scenarios that perhaps historical setting would not have allowed.

I highly recommend it. If you are a newcomer to Total War give yourself time to practice the real time battles. Once you become reasonably proficient at these the game really opens up.

Total War: Warhammer brings together some of the best elements of strategy gaming; real time and turn-based. Anyone even remotely interested in fantasy tabletop gaming will likely find themselves playing Total War: Warhammer for hours, if not days.

I liked this game and I did enjoy playing for the one campaign I played when I first bought it. Since then, it's sat in my Steam library and I haven't ever felt the urge to revisit it. Much of the bitter taste is from Creative Assembly/Sega's business practices when it comes to the Total War series as of late.

I am a big fan of Total War and I love the concept. Merging turn-based grand strategy while you manage your realm with real time strategy battle segments where you command and manage your troops on a massive scale is genius. The idea of putting the series in a one-off fantasy setting into the Warhammer universe is also genius. But unfortunately, around the time of Rome 2, Creative Assembly decided to really change around how cities are developed/managed, and really bogged down much of the gameplay so that, while still fun, slows down the campaign time in a series where the campaigns were already crazy dragged out.

More so than this, around the time of Rome 2, Creative Assembly also began the practice of never, ever dropping non-sale pricing, limiting sales (in terms of percentage off) and locking the VAST majority of game content behind ludicrously high and numerous DLC paywalls. There's been DLC before, for sure, but it was more reasonably priced to begin with, they further dropped the price when the games became older, and had typical steam sales so it was never THAT unreasonable. Even then, they would start you off with the majority of the factions to play as.

So what you get now when you buy a Total War game made after 2013, is a bogged down, bloated, overpriced shell of essentially 40% of the full game. Be prepared to pay a king's ransom. I really do think you're better off playing the much more reasonably priced Shogun 2, my personal favorite. It really does suck, because I'd love to play this series more, but it just feels off. I really disagree with how Creative Assembly and Sega have been managing this series.

This is an excellent game.  I have previously enjoyed total war games; however, the fantasy fiction setting of this on makes it far superior to predecessors.  I have completed the grand campaign playing as Vlad Von Carstein and I am looking forward to playing with a different faction.

The game does a really great job of capturing the feel of certain races with game mechanics. The Dwarves feel sturdy if a bit slower, and are driven by grudges. The Empire feels well rounded with a more traditional total war feel, and the orcs.. They get mad if they're not fighting all the time. WAAAGGGHH!

Total War did great bringing in the fantasy aspect into a usual historical franchise. Every campaign is different since each faction have their own way of playing. There is also good amount of replay ability since the factions also have different lords you can command which can bring different ways of playing and the game becomes a lot more fun if you play with your bud on a Co-Op campaign. The game also has some fantastic mods to that can even more things to it. Its great!!!!

It's a lot of fun and I would recommend playing this game before playing mortal empires as it will give you the feel for a lot of the factions from this game. 

Pros:
- 17 factions to play as
- Smaller version of mortal empires map
- Magic is fun
- A lot of variance in each faction
- Story/ Quest battles in the old worlds campaign
- Loot
- Bribing beastmen to go attack your enemy is really funny.
- Chaos is actually a threat in this game.

Cons
- Beastmen... they're more of a pest that just does not go away.
- Diplomacy can be really random. Stay away from defensive alliances.
- AI has a tendency to retreat instead of staying and fighting on campaign map.
- AI has cheats the higher the difficulty.
- Like always, Vassals are more of a hinderance than helpful.... don't get me started on vassals deciding to declare war on your other vassals.

Neutral
- Wood elves are meh
- Some factions are more prone to confederate quicker than others. i.e. Dwarves.
- Sieges aren't as good as Shogun 2

The Bad:

Would I recommend it? Yes, but... be prepared for a ton of frustration. Enemy armies can calculate exactly how far they need to be away from you so you can't reach them. Whether it's a band of marauders or the end-game chaos army, all enemies play an annoying guerrilla warfare game against you where they'll attack towns your armies are nowhere near, then run away at the first sign that you're heading over to defend. I would dare say 75% of this game is playing cleanup - simply running around trying to catch weak enemies that have no business attacking you, but are trying to skim a little off the top. Luckily, the core gameplay is solid. It's the idea that zombie armies or chaos armies or otherwise monster armies would dart around and avoid you and play an annoying game of cat and mouse, rather than mindlessly attack. But still, game is great. Check it out.

The game is insanely fun, everything I wanted out of Civ and more. Some systems aren't as robust, such as city building and management, but where this game shines over Civ it massively outclasses it. The buy-in is somewhat intense for this and TW: WH2, but just purchasing the base game and maybe a DLC for a faction you like is all you need, factions you don't care about will still be in the game but just not playable. The game also basically combines with its sequel, all playable races in 1 are available in 2 in addition to all of the new races. 

Overall, if you like 4x and fantasy elements you can't go wrong with this game. Total War's 4x and Warhammer Fantasy's lore together make an incredibly fun ride with massive amounts of replayability and depth.

Poor execution, if not utterly pointless due to the remake.

The menu being capped at 30fps feels cheap. The multiplayer battles looked empty only showing 2 lobbies, and both were private. I tried singleplayer battles, and armies can be totally invisible (Empire TW forced atleast 1 unit to be visible at all times) and won't attack, so you just aimlessly wonder around the map hoping to bump into something. There's so many other gameplay mechanics that worked in previous total war games but were butchered in this one.

The hero units seem ridiculously overpowered, killing hundreds of units each, making for a poor blend of fantasy and realism. This was nowhere remotely near my experiences of the tabletop game. Surely the immersion should be anchored by a foundation of realism. If a flying horse quickly wipes an entire army then what's the point? It's a fantasy game, but it does overdose on fantasy to a sickening degree...

The campaign was a poor experience. Already starting with multiple wars, and facing constant "incursions" that spawn units of another hostile race in your own land. With a limit to how many units you can sustain - how on earth are you supposed to defend from "incursions" AND go on the offense, when taking another city would promptly lead to another nation taking it from you. It's not intuitive enough to make clear progress, and with so many restrictions and such a cluttered campaign map there's little room for creativity.

With so many heros, so many abilities, and so much DLC there's a steep learning curve. If the battles and campaign gameplay don't entertain, then where's the motivation to deal with the learning curve? I was put off by the whole thing. They had the money and experience to make this game complete and intuitive, but they didn't. They cut it up, and left it in its state to go work on the next years project. And what was that next project? A near exact copy of this game...

Then why on earth should someone buy this one? I wouldn't recommend it to friends.

Edit:
For the people trying to explain the game to me, I'm just getting more and more confused. It's not intuitive to me.

Warhammer (not warhammer 40K), has been and still is my most favourite fantasy world, no other fantasy world has ever managed to capture and describe the different races, even the skaven and goblins, with such magnificent elegance and powerful characters, and the races vibrantly rich histories and cultures that give such a raw feeling of the Warhammer world and characters to anyone reading the books. And I truly wish that more books would be written, my most favourite book that I've ever read is Grudge Breaker, written by Gav Thorpe (someone you should probably get involved in the development of Total War Warhammer). One of the best series to read of Warhammer is The War of Vengeance.

I've been waiting for a quite a while for a game to come along that would do the original Warhammer justice. And when I started watching videos of Total War Warhammer gameplay, this game did exactly that. And no other game has ever managed to capture such a core part to the essence of such a monumental, and truly magnificent fantasy world, of the Warhammer.

So far, I think this game is amazing. The Total War: Warhammer series introduced me to Warhammer Fantasy in general.

Some things that I enjoy about it include the quest system and revamped diplomacy.

In some older TW games, making peace with someone who was attacking your vassal would leave your vassal defenceless. In TW:Warhammer, making peace with someone would force them to make peace with your vassals as well. The diplomacy isn't perfect especially since the eggheads at CA decided to remove region trading but it is an improvement overall.

I would highly recommend buying this game on sale.

After 11 years of using STEAM, this is the first and only refund I have asked for. This game is absolutely not at all what I expected. The first hour I played was with my friend in co-op trying to explain how things worked in game, which just confused me more. I watched almost 3 hours of tutorial videos online just to be able to get a handle on how you're supposed to play it as there is essentially ZERO tutorial for the hundreds upon hundreds of interactions in the game that are explained poorly (or not at all). A massive strategy game with two massively different learning curve portions: A) Overland base building/diplomacy/army management/exploration and B) Massive army battles with dozens and dozens of units with no reference which has a completely unique system of movement and formation (which is NEVER explained in any early tutorial). Overall, I really hate this game. Even on 75% off I can't justify the purchase. As an avid Warhammer fan, to me, this is just an abomination. I'm really, really disappointed in how poorly this game was executed for first time Total War players.

The transition from tabletop to desktop is a fantastic experience with Total War: Warhammer. The strategy is fairly light on the campaign map but detailed enough to hold your interest between the epic battles. The battles are the bread and butter though. 

Have you ever wanted to see a giant bat eviscerate a poor goblin? How about an orange mohawked dwarf split a beastman in two? This game delivers a satisfying punch and I'm sure I'll have many more hours diving into Warhammer 2.

The game is well thought out, with many facets to explore. Having said that, when you get to turn 80, even on easy, you encounter Chaos Army. Even if you control half the map, random chaos events, uprisings, clans you wiped out reemerge in the center of your territory, and the Chaos Army runs right over all your castles with 20/20 defenders inside. I wiped out an chaos army in a castle defense, down to like 20 enemy remaining and I received a "Defeated" completion somehow. 
I enjoy a game that requires me to think and plan. And that reward would come from that. This is a chaotic game and I would not recommend to anyone unless they enjoy losing everything they worked for because of an OP game mechanic. Replies are not required, I read many guides and watched many videos on youtube in an effort to combat the game itself.

Final Review:

Don't buy this unless it's 70% off and you like random punishments distributed throughout  a game.

Build your faction. Slowly make progress over hours and hours of effort. Expand and make alliances. Fight, build, complete a couple of neat missions. You're just about to get your capital city to where it can make a new kind of cool unit.

10,000 Chaos forces and a Greenskin Waagh attack. The Chaos forces have possessed a faction on your border, so it attacks. Two other factions suddenly declare war on you because you're in an impossible fight. Your weakest ally sends almost no forces to help you. Everything except the 8,000 wandering attacks at once, and those Beast Men raid your provinces. You are nearly wiped out in four turns. 

Rebuild, but to half of your previous strength before all the above happens again. Get a random environment event that causes two of your provinces to rebel. You can only build level one forces now and are fighting on four fronts. You are wiped out completely.

This is on Normal difficulty. 

What kind of jerk makes a game this way? Randomly setting you up to fight everything at once is not a "difficult game." It's just a roll of a die that lands on You Are Dead. This is the way games are made by companies that can't figure out anything but a deus ex machina to generate difficulty.
It is a really good but extremely complex game. I might never be able to learn how to play it properly.

Sometimes you just want to go on a holy crusade with Bretonnia and venerate the Lady.

I'm still trying to find my footing in Total War: Warhammer. I've followed every total war game since Medieval and this one is certainly the most unique being that it's based in a fantasy world. I admire the game for it's unique factions and various details in both the campaign map and the battle map. However, I have to warn you, this is not your typical total war game. Those that are lovers of the series due to the historical context may not appreciate the appeal. I also have a personal gripe with the Chaos Faction. If you recall crusades and jihads in medieval total war, the Chaos faction is a version of that, beware! This faction seems much too overpowered and hijacks the rest of the game for many. They have the ability to conquer faction after faction until you're one of the few left. There are mods to get around this issue, but it is intended to be part of the game? Perhaps I'm just not ahead of the curve in this game! Overall I'd recommend giving it a shot. It's a beautiful game and will certainly appeal to fans of the Warhammer franchise.

With nearly 300 hours played in the game, I think it's safe to say I am a fan of the latest installment of Total War. The game does have a few issues, but if you have been looking for a fantasy-themed strategy game then I highly suggest picking up Total War: Warhammer.

Graphics: 8/10
As with my previous Total War review, Warhammer hit it's pretty square on the head in terms of graphics. To truly enjoy the game in all it's glory, your going to need a decent video card. I originally played the game on a GTX 750 and was able to play with most settings on medium. However, I soon upgraded to a 980 just for this game and was blown away. The detail on each unit and character is amazing. The developers really did their homework to ensure the units accurately reflect the tabletop detail of each specific race. That's not to say it's all great though. The terrain seems to lack some detail in the graphical department. Expect to see terrain similar to other Total Wars with fantasy elements thrown in. The over world in the single-player campaign is great to look at, but at times I would experience some stuttering when moving during my turn. This may just be some optimization needed on Creative Assembly's part.

Soundtrack/Audio: 7/10
For the most part, all the audio is intense and matches the theme of the game. For the longest time I would turn up the music because at certain points, it was very 'epic' if you will. But the same music does get old after a bit, and there does not seem to be much variation in music. Sound effects are what you would expect and add immersion to the game but it's nothing over the top. It's good, maybe even great, but not excellent.

Gameplay: 7/10
The game plays like many TW's with some exceptions. The exceptions are the main reason why this game didn't get a perfect 10. Creative left one KEY aspect out of the game, NO VILLAGE BATTLES. Yes, you can siege castles and large cities, but when you surround a town and decided to attack, you will be met with a flat landscape. This can be very frustrating during the campaign because in other TW's, the town's defenses would at least give you the chance to put up some sort of resistance. In Warhammer, if your town is small and not built up, even the smallest armies can destroy you since it turns into a straight 1 on 1 battle on flat terrain with the AI.

Speaking of the AI, it seems creative has not done much to improve it. You may frequently come across AI armies made entirely out of artillery, or notice that the army you are chasing can somehow stay right out of your reach even if the AI technically has the 'advantage'. I have also noticed the AI will rarely siege settlements. They would rather wait you out which is very disappointing as I find defensive battles to be quite enjoyable. Expect your typical Total War AI sillyness. (Also, would it kill Creative to make the Greenskins not spawn SO MANY AGENTS? Thx.)

On the other hand, tactics do play a very large part in the single player campaign. Many races have certain abilities that can be utilized during the game. Dwarfs move underground which can be great for making up their general slowness on the overworld map. Elves utilize 'forest paths' to quickly move about the map making ambushes quite common and unpredictable. Agents play a key role in the game and can be utilized in your army as an actual unit. Magic is a new and welcome addition to TW, and for the most part adds to the enjoyment. Some of the spells are underwhelming but many can make or break a battle if cast at the right time and place. If your race uses magic, don't discard it.

Overall 7.5/10
In the end (get it?) the game is very enjoyable and well worth the money for both the game and a few of the DLCs. The Blood DLC is would say is a must at the minimum. Race DLCs are not mandatory and even if you don't buy them, you can still see the new races in game (You just can't play as them in SP or MP). The gameplay, paired with the amazing graphics really make TW:W something special. IF your a fan of the fantasy setting or Warhammer in general, you might find yourself playing this game for quite some time.

Dwarfs line the walls of the Everpeak, weapons ready. They fire bolt and lead at the incoming Orcs, but to the Giant lummoxing forward at the head of the green horde it may as well be a light smither of rain. The Giant crashes into the gates, stumbles back and crashes into them again. It bursts through to be faced by massed units of Longbeards, fearless Dwarf veterans, who mob the Giant like dogs harassing an elephant.

They win, because in the rock, paper, scissors of Total War: Warhammer the Longbeards' immunity to psychological effects makes them good at fighting fear-causing Giants. Slayers would be even better as they have the Anti-Large trait as well as Unbreakable, but this is a game where paper can beat scissors so long as there's enough of it.
Moldy Old World

Until now Total War has recreated historical eras, and so the tactics have been based on simplified versions of real-world tactics, whether deployed by Rome or Napoleon. Cavalry flank and race ahead to attack missile units before they get too many shots off; spears defend and resist cavalry charges; missile units pour volleys into dense infantry units as they slowly advance. Here, things are more complicated.

The Warhammer World is a fantasy setting, one loosely based on Renaissance Europe but with the fiction of J. R. R. Tolkien, Michael Moorcock, H. P. Lovecraft and Fritz Leiber funnelled into it through industrial pipes while copies of 2000 AD and heavy metal album covers are scattered on top. It's a mish-mash of everything someone at Games Workshop ever thought was cool, and it's both familiar and really weird. 

The tactical map gives a good overview of how badly you're losing.
The tactical map gives a good overview of how badly you're losing.

There's plenty of crossover between fans of historical wargames and Warhammer, as shown by two of the previous Total War games receiving fan-made mods that squeeze Warhammer armies into them. This is something else though, a ground-up alteration of the Total War formula to make it suit the fantasy setting of the Old World (and it's moddable too, so someone out there must be itching to reverse the trend and put historical armies back in). That formula comes in two halves. The first is a turn-based grand campaign about marching armies across a map and managing provinces through construction, research, and taxation, trying to balance the economy and people's happiness with army-building. The second happens when those armies meet and drop into a real-time, though pausable, battle.

In previous Total War games the factions played in a relatively similar way, but not any more. For instance, the Greenskins have a meter measuring each army's Fightiness. Win battles, and it rises. Lose, or squat in your hovels like a coward, and it drops. If Fightiness is high enough, and there are at least 17 out of a maximum 20 units in the stack, all that sweet victory encourages other Orcs to band together in a bonus force called a Waaagh! For other species buying and maintaining multiple armies is a huge expense, but for Greenskins can earn them free, which encourages a state of constant aggression that's entirely appropriate.

    Dwarves never forget a slight, carefully noting each in a massive book of bitterness.

Dwarfs on the other hand have to keep track of grudges. They never forget a slight, carefully noting each in a massive book of bitterness. Any time their land is raided or attacked or Dwarfs are hindered in any way some scholar back at the capital sucks in air over his teeth and says, ‚ÄúThat's going in the book.‚Äù While revenge earns rewards, having too many unavenged grudges drops public order as people lose faith in their leader. It breeds a playstyle all about defence, limiting fronts on which the Dwarfs can be attacked and only marching off to make new enemies when old ones have been thoroughly dealt with.

Each faction has their own tech tree, though the Orcs is a bit rudimentary.
Each faction has their own tech tree, though the Orcs is a bit rudimentary.

Meanwhile, the Vampire Counts rely on spreading corruption in the form of a grey, sickly taint on the map. Other factions suffer attrition when moving across corrupted land while Vampire Counts armies are diminished by marching across uncorrupted land. The Vampire Counts can also raise the dead to fill armies instantly rather than waiting (like in Rome II, armies are generated by generals rather than settlements, but cost extra away from the buildings that produce specialists). It's not as much of a game-changer as you'd expect. Unlike the Heroes Of Might & Magic games where the undead grow and grow as they incorporate the fallen into their hordes, Warhammer's Vampire Counts are still reliant on the old-fashioned way to get decent troops, though provinces where large battles have been fought provide a better class of corpses to recruit.

The final of the four playable factions (Bretonnians exist as NPCs but can be used in multiplayer, while Chaos Warriors are available free to those who pre-ordered or buy Total War: Warhammer in its first week and will be paid DLC later) is The Empire. Modelled on the Roman-German Empire, the humans are the most traditional faction, with starting units including crossbowmen, spearmen, and knights that will be more familiar to Total War players than Terrorgheists and Arachnaroks. Imperials get weirder as they go on, with Steam Tanks and knights who trade horses for eagle-headed Demigryphs while their leader Karl Franz can upgrade to a flying Griffon.

All these differences dramatically affected the way I played. As the Greenskins I fought just to keep armies Fighty and raided neighbors without regard for what they thought because that's a significant part of the Orc income even though it went against what I learned with other factions and my regular tendencies. It's not the kind of game where replaying as a different side means "focusing slightly more on missile weapons because they have +1 with bows". Each faction is almost a different game, and that's kept me interested.

Clothes shopping must be hell for Giants.
Clothes shopping must be hell for Giants.
Fantasy battles

There's variance between factions in both the turn-based campaign game and the real-time battles. Dwarfs don't have wizards but are blessed with plenty of artillery, and are generally more of a defensive, come-get-me-you-lanky-bastards force. Vampire Counts don't have missile units (not even skeleton archers), though their wizards have a decent Wind Of Death spell. For them it's all about lurching forward, targeting specific enemies with flying units and Black Knights while the skeletons and zombies shamble up to fill the gaps. The Greenskins have a bit of everything, but can be hard to control. When their Leadership drops due to being flanked or attacked by enemies who cause fear they have a tendency to scarper, but recover quickly and need to be shepherded back into the fray for wave after wave.

The effect of spellcasting on battles is less than expected. There's a limited pool of Winds Of Magic to draw from, with goofy blue haze wafting over the campaign map to show where it's strongest this turn, and individual spell effects feel slight compared to the impact of a flanking manoeuvre or well-timed charge. The Raise Dead spell can summon a unit of zombies out of the ground, which is suggested by the handy in-game guide as a good way of blocking a charge, but also works to bog missile units down or pull off a flank attack. Zombies are weak combatants, however, and the spell can only be cast if you're at less than 20 units. Plus, even if those fragile zombies survive they'll be gone at the end of the battle.

First things first: This review is coming from someone who has been playing, interested in and/or actively researching warhammer and warhammer 40k since the early 90s.

This game is absolutely fantastic. It's satisfying when everything clicks and can absolutely make an entire day disappear in an instant.

That being said...This game has a pretty steep learning curve for new comers of the total war series and even more so if you're new to both Warthammer AND total war. I've never been super great at strategy games, so my first few hours with this game meant CONSTANTLY restarting the main campaign, because I would back myself into a corner that I couldn't get out of. But after doing some research (Especially tips on the early game) I was able to hit the ground running.

Also...Don't pay full price for this. It's currently sitting at over $70 CAD and I would NOT pay that much for this game. I did however pick it up for $17 on sale and was TOTALLY worth it.

I have been a Total War fan for a long while having played the historical titles such as Rome I, Empires and Shogun 2. When I saw the trailer for Warhammer I knew I had to have it. It looked so cool. I knew nothing about Warhammer Fantasy but that didn't stop me. I rolled an Empire campaign and they seemed to be the most newbie friendly since they were human and had balanced armies familiar to historical titles.

Then I ended up fighting vampires and really fell in love with the game. Here I was fighting monsters and the undead. I just knew I had to try the vampires next. And so I did. They play exactly as an undead faction should. With tons of zombie meatshields to bog down their enemy while their actually valuable units flank and wreak havoc. Hell, even if the vampires lost most of their army, it's not a huge loss. They can simply raise the dead and fight again. I love it!

I had to try every faction. Each time I encountered a new one I thought they had some really cool units or characters and wanted to try them next. Through this game, a love for Warhammer developed and I began to research more about the lore and world. No regrets. Still one of my favorite fantasy worlds ever. And now I have moved onto Warhammer Total War II.

The first game is still very well polished and has the added benefit of being at the end of life. No more updates will throw it out of balance which is pretty good. If you purchase both this game and the second game, there is a combined map that can be played from the second game. You can choose any faction from both games and fight factions from both games! The only downside is the load time can be excessive. So that would be a reason to switch back to Warhammer I. But otherwise, can buy this game, and then don;t even need to install it and can just play the factions from within Warhammer II instead if you wish.

Ok i was super excited about this game when i first heard of it. I've been a big fan of the other Total War games as i have over 1000 hours between Rome, Rome II, Attila, Shogun, and Medieval. So i bought this game as well as Warhammer II. 

Truth be told, this game is a TOTAL AND UTTER DISAPPOINTMENT.

If you are a fan of traditional (and new) total war games, then do not buy this game and do not waste your money. As for what is wrong with this game...where do i start??

1. First of all, there are no minor settlement defenses. At first i was like "why not, might as well try it out since i paid money for this game." Then i proceed to waste 50 hours on a campaign as the Empire, upgraded all my settlements to 3 or higher, and even BUILT GUARDHOUSES in these minor settlements. But then, 3 stacks of Beastmen just magically spawn in the middle of my land WITH NO WARNING and proceed to raze all my settlements to the ground as my main armies are HALFWAY ACROSS THE WORLD. And the funny thing is, if there was minor settlement defenses, i would have been able to hold them off. 
Which leads me to my next problem with this game...

2. Absolutely ridiculous campaign mechanics. Some of these AI cheats makes the Huns from Total War Attila look like babies. I'm talking about random full stacks spawning in the middle of your land with NO WARNING and you might have had a chance if you had minor settlement defenses...oh wait... there isn't any....
So next time you are 100 turns in and waging a war across your kingdom and its going fairly well...think again. 

3. The battles are a joke. There is no strategy. No formations or abilities you can use. No shield wall formation with a unit of fully armored swordsmen. No pike wall with halberdiers. Hell they even removed loose formation. And some of you are gonna say "Well theres a mod for formations..." which i have tried. And it got my hopes up. Except this "mod" doesn't change formations. All it does is change the shape of the unit and give ridiculous buffs. (Like unbreakable).....That's only the first issue with the battles. Next up - armor and defense doesn't mean sh*t. Neither does well composed armies with ratios of cavalry, spear infantry, shock infantry, and archers. Noooope. That strategic army you just raised just got decimated by a motley crew of dinosaurs, wizards, and magical floaty chariots. No strategy like i said. To win....just have the biggest monsters and the most amount of wizards.

4. Diplomacy is bland. Compared to other total war games, Warhammer diplomacy is half-as*ed. It was literal copy and paste from the first Warhammer. Nothing makes it special, it is just meh.

5. Greedy devs. LITERALLY HALF the game you cannot play without buying DLCs.
You'll break your computer finding out that all your money was wasted on an utterly useless game.
(Side note: Any game starting with, containing, or ending with the world 'Warhammer' or any game in the Warhammer series is a rip-off and money hungry.)

All the hard work put into this game was in the wrong places. Its like the old phrase of putting gold on a pig. The graphics, particles, and battle maps are supposed to be icing on the cake. If the cake is sh*t in the first place, then icing is useless. The strategy is gone. Old school Total War feel is butchered. This game is like a mutated and wrong version of Total War.

So heed my advice and do not buy. I almost broke my computer over this game. Do not make the same mistake i did. DO NOT BUY 1/10 UTTER CRAP

While the learning curve is certainly steep, Total War: Warhammer is a meticulously crafted and endlessly engaging experience, even when you still suck on easy mode just like I do.  The presentation is nigh on flawless, logistical campaign gameplay manages to be just as fun as the mighty and ferocious battles, and it's all brought in a beautiful package full of gloriously cinematic bloodshed and politicking. 

This is one of those games where it really does feel like every decision you make matters, even on repeated campaigns when you've got the general rhythm of gameplay and upgrades down. The A.I. is intelligent enough to match and combat almost every decision you make along the way, at least with the help of some subtle balancing mods that help prevent early game enemies' bad habits of spamming archer units when you have no effective way of countering them yet.

Mods are highly encouraged to really enjoy the game, especially when starting out, and this can easily be seen as a negative.  But the vanilla experience is balanced well enough that 99% of the time you have to be just making extremely poor choices to get yourself in an unwinnable situation.  The mods and surprisingly engaged community, such as youtubers like Lionheartx10 and Zerkovich and the subreddit, are there to ease new players into an experience that actually isn't as complicated as you might think.

The abundance of expensive DLC is definitely a turn off in this day and age, but there's such a massive content available in the base game and with the free DLC that it has more than enough to get you invested in the experience.  There is absolutely no reason to purchase any DLC right when you start the game.

All in all, this is the game that got me interested in grand strategy, and I'm very happy I picked it up. This is one of the most thrilling and frenetic strategy games ever made, constantly bringing a new challenge to the table and making you feel like you earned every upgrade and victory.  

Highly recommended for purchase on sale prices.

For someone who loves Warhammer and has the expirience of Total War. I must say this game is cut short :( and believe me when I say I'd rather not point that out.

To some, this may be a great game, but after following the warhammer series and knowing total war mechanics, I cannot sujest this. Even the workshop community is trying desprately to revive what the devs of WH:TW failed to do.

First off, The DLC's are dumbfoundedly limited <other then chaos thanks to workshop, GJ guys, especially Chaos Devided, very nice stuff there.) and don't have as many units as they should. The elves are woth it only because of their treemen, but, sadly that is still not enough to buy it. All the DLC's have so few units in them <cept chaos because WS>. Like, elves and beastmen according to WH lore, have TONS more then what is there, and even non lorefriendly ideas would be amazing just so that it doesnt feel like a compleate waste of money. 

TW:WH does not have enough content even though it has so much, compaired to Medivel II: Total War it's not very much.
The only reason I can put up with the lack of units for the overpriced DLC is because of the hard working Workshop members who arnt even getting paid.

SECONDLY AND IMPORTANT TO OTHER TOTAL WAR PLAYERS
This next and simple part brings the soul of Khorne out in me. It is that there are NO UNIT FORMATIONS.

When I say Formations, I mean, No shield wall, no spear wall, no turtle shield formation, NONE OF IT. I have NO IDEA why that CRUTIAL option is not included, but it isnt there.

Instead of formations, they have buffs against charges, etc. Stupid... no animations or anything for it.

This is what you need to know before you buy it.

Pro:
Beautiful Characters
Amazing Locations
Fantasy Fights in Total War
Diverse Units
Dedicated Workshop Members <Honestly love their work>

Cons:
Few units
Mostly Reskined units
Minimal Content for high priced DLC
No Strategic Formations for units
Units tend to not actually have much Morale compaired to other Total War games
Many Warhammer Units have been excluded from the game.

And finally, I am Waiting on Skaven <Yes I am going to wait for the Skaven even if it never happens. I mean, cmon, they could be a good addition, I WANT MY GLOBADIERS. Assassin rats, rat ogres, stormvermin. Cmon, they basicly made the Skaven ready for Total War. Just saying. Look into Vermintide guys, you can find some ideas.

Love you all, If you get the game, hope you enjoy it. You will understand the cons and pros i've pointed out if you do get it.

If more units/factions/races get added, I would definantly change my opinion. And if unit formations get added. Makes it more stratigic and satisfying as you watch your shielded spearmen line up to counter a calvery charge.




Edit:   Only buy this game and it's DLC if you have the Second game.   If you do not plan to get the second game, Do not touch this. It is outdaded as hell and all the effort is in TW:W2

I absolutely love this game.  Have clocked hundreds of hours in it and the sequel.  People complaining about the price are retarded.  It's not like you can't buy the gamekey somewhere else and have steam honor it.  If somebody is too stupid to do that or wait for a sale (which steam does all the time) that's on them.  

As to the actual game, Warhammer is unique cuz it didn't go away when the sequel came out.  They literally build on each other.  This may not be a new concept, but it's still awesome and it means I still get lots of screentime in this game's content (though admittedly, I'm technically playing Warhammer 2 when I login but it's the same shit).  

The fact they still make mods that impact the factions from the original game is awesome.  Yes, the cost of the game will all mods is pretty high, but the amount of replay value TW:Warhammer offers is almost unparalleled and so I don't see that as a poor place to have invested the money.  With steam sales, I've paid about $150 for every steam mod that wasn't cosmetic, plus Warhammer 1&2.  I've bought tons of games that I didn't play for 1/10th the amount of time and that cost a shit ton more than 1/10th that price.  And I'm still not bored of this shit.  

CA may have made some trash in the past, hell they may still turn out some crap, but the Warhammer series definitely isn't part of that.  These games kick ass.
The game does not deserves all the negativity. It's the best of its kind if you like classical warfare in a fantasy setting.

I don't understand the negative reviews.

CA made Warhammer Total War, made some changes and released DLC that added more stuff to it.
Then came Warhammer II, a continuation of Warhammer I, so much so that some people complained that it should have been an expansion.

While I agree, at this point Warhammer II is what Left 4 Dead 2 is to Left 4 Dead 1: it overtook the game and is now the "main" game of the series.
The same will happen to Warhammer 3 and I will happily buy it again when it does.

Now, regarding Warhammer I. It's good, even if it was suplanted by Warhammer II. I think it's worth the buy, especially since it unlocks all its races for Warhammer II (it's in fact the only way to unlock them) including Empire, Dwarves, Vampire Counts and Green Skins. 
Factions like Chaos, Wood Elves and Beastmen must be unlocked via this game's DLC, but it also unlocks those factions for Warhammer II.

I don't think this game is worth the full 60$, 20$ is a more worthy price tag, but if you can buy it during sale (or even a hard copy) that includes all the DLC it is 100% worth the price.

I want to get my feelings out after playing this game.  Those of you that like total war series IMO you will be let down.  I found this game to be fustrating I know most people say my review is not helpful but I played every single Total War game via CD/DVD or Steam.  Of course I have prejudice as a Total War game.  it's a step backward you be better off buying Atila. As a game it's not a bad game it's just not up to my expectations of Total War Series.  IMO Total War is the greatest game series of grand strategy / rts games. I enjoy other RTS games like blizzard, command & conquer extra.  But those do not have a grand campaign similar to total war series.   

CONS:

Cost more than other Total war games that are more fun.

Boring implimentation of common units, other than lords.  Even Humans in Total War Rome had shield walls to make a different stance.  Here everything is " Lord " 

lack of intresting or unique technology tree seemed to just be random with some races like an after thought as if I got to get this done fast.  
lack of unique spells (general) all spells between the lords is similar 
lack of control in battle field seems like units were unresponsive in pathing around buildings
lack of commands for units no special stances
lack of grouping or battle formations during fights (2 only) 
Also they don't stay in the formation such as in a group movement once assigned unlike other total wars they stayed in formation here they don't.
 
PRO:
new units large, flying "kind of"
introduction to non-human and magical units
new fight animations
unique terrain/castles

I recommend wait until this game is on sale unless you never owned any other total war game then by all means get the game you wouldn't have any frame of reference to complain you probably like it even in it's weakness.

I don't want to be one of those "history or nothing" people that hated on this game when it first came out. I love 40k, I played the tabletop, the RPG, and many of the video games. I'm just not a fan of this. One of the cool things I liked about the old TW games was the ability to rewrite history. Win the 7 years war as France in Empire Total War, conquer Europe as Napoleon, restart the Roman Empire as Byzantium in Medieval. I don't know enough about Warhammer lore to know if I'm doing something spectacular. I'm not a fan of the "Hero unit type" in this either. While it reflects well on the tabletop (generals are tanks on their own that can wipe whole units), it makes for a strange game. Knowing I can wipe a whole army with just my high leveled general is boring. I also don't like the different settlement types. Humans can't live in dwarf settlements and viseversa. I'm sure there's lore or something behind it, but it's poorly explained.

Total War: Warhammer is still one of the best RTS games I have ever played. Total War does Warhammer justice by paying attention to every detail and making every faction in this game stand true against those portrayed on the table top game and written lore. Its this attention to detail that makes this game great. 
Now, I'm sure you've read a long list of negative comments about this game claiming that the devs made Chaos faction a DLC and that is true. Chaos faction is, in fact, a DLC but...you would have got the first DLC for free if you pre-ordered your copy or if you had bought the game in the first week of its release. Now, you can't CLAIM to be a fan of this franchise if you didn't meet the aforementioned requirements and THEN complain about it several months later when your mom bought you a 'puter for your birthday and are finally getting into the swing of things.
 True fans of the franchise we're more than ready to buy this game when it was released and the devs rewarded us with the Chaos legion DLC for free. 
 But, then again, posers gonna pose.

First of all, this is one of my favorite games to play, because
A. It combines turn-based and RTS-strategy.
B. You have a number of different campaigns, faction unit rosters to completely satisfy your hype for warhammer fantasy
C. You can practice your plans for world domination, I mean do I have to say more.


There are some negatives though (and the developers should look at this for future games)
-The Dlc policy, I know the developers may need extra cash for the budget, but a lot of the games-content is made of dlcs and some are just bizarre to be a dlc. Like blood for bloodgod, I mean it is a cool game feature and shouldn't demand an extra buck.
-The AI. It is sometimes quite crazy what the enemy as well as the allied AI does, so of course it keeps exciting, but it is something that can be improved
-The level of difficulty. Now I usually play the campaigns and I think everything is quite enjoyable until the hard-level. After that, the enemy factions just have a higher budget than they should have, which then makes winning the campaign mostly luck.

If you are Total War or a Warhammer fan (or both), this game is a must have.  I finished the campaign as the Empire, Vampire Lords, and Dwarves and completed the Eye for an Eye story (ok that one was not as good as the main campaign).  And I can attest that the 4 factions I played are quite different and refreshing.  A quick note that yes the DLC policy is quite annoying as the vanilla game without paid DLCs doesn't feel like a complete experience.  But the option of combining the two worlds from Warhammer 1 and 2 is simply fantastic.  

Pros:
+  Multiple factions with distinct gameplay mechanics.
+  The battles are very fun.
+  The Warhammer universe brings quite the epic flavor to the Total War formula.
+  If you add the DLC contents, you can easily sink a few hundred hours.
+  I liked the Quests, but I think they can expand on those and make them even more complex.  Would have liked to have some more varied situations like quests where they force you to start with specific Units or where you fight an overpowered Boss that cannot be played...

Cons:
-  Everything is monetized.  There is no loot boxes, but quite a bit of DLCs.
-  The Legendary Heroes are not as Legendary as one can think.  I believe this is done to have balancing among factions...  But Archaon the Everchosen should be able to literally piss on many other Lords that are Tier 1 in this game.
-  You need a beast of a PC if you want to have everything maxed AND use the Mortal Empire DLC (the one that combines both Warhammer 1 and 2).

Verdict:  9/10.

I am new to Total War and Warhammer so I understand nothing but so far this is awesome.



Edit: I've had Total War: Rome in my library for a while after getting it for like $3 in a sale. I played the tutorial for that after being frustrated at this game's lack of help and it pretty much got me up to speed on the basics. I'd recommend that to any newbies feeling lost like I was.

This game would be good if it weren't for the loading times. After the intial wonder and fun soon the annoyance and impatience set in. And after a few hours in the game the fear to fuck up and have to load again undid every fun I had with the game.
That probably is no problem to the total war players who already are really great at the game, but for me it's no fun like this. And because it is so tedious I also have no desire to put myself through the torture of getting better at the game that consist of 50% loading screen.

Also something minor, I think the UI is pretty bad, it adds to the unhandiness of the game.

Edit:
The diplomacy system is absolutely bare-bones, if Archeon isn't on his way or you're not a big power or you're not just swimming in money, others most of the time don't want anything to do with you except for killing you. Alliances mean nothing even for trustworthy nations. And the good deed - bad deed system is only made to keep you from having a real ally since the good deeds you do are forgotten after 2 turns (yea that's an exaggeration) while you're allies find the dumbest reasons to get mad at you.

Actually...this isn't a bad game. Until you realize that the game's AI is only able to challenge you by cheating. Personally I detest cheating. It doesn't matter if a player cheats or the game's AI cheats. The rules of the game must be the same on either side of the "game board". Everything else is just bad game design. To be precise:

- AI doesn't pay Upkeep (Mousillion started with 2 full and one half army while only having a small settlement)
- AI does not have to "build" an army (After defeating a Lord's army he was back after just 3 turns with 3 full armies)
- AI force marches without restriction
- AI doesn't pay for building troops

(I realize there is mods which make the AI unable to cheat. However these mods actually prove my point, since the AI even fails to cope with paying Upkeep. One by one all AI factions lost the game simply because they ran out of money.)

The game is fun not gonna lie but the constant crashing is absolute bullshit.

This mixed review will center around a mod so stay with me until the end of the review. Strategic part of the vanilla game is simplified and relatively OK. You have diplomacy similar to Attila TW which is not bad when compared with diplomatic options of the older games including Shogun 2, Napoleon and Empire. Map is a bit cramped and combat often unavoidable. Now you might say what is wrong with combat? Here comes the punchline: the vanilla game is horrible because battles last 4-6 minutes. You gather your troops carefully and watch them getting slaughtered in a few minutes time. If you stick with only Patch 7 and install old mod, whose community is still active, called Wakes Realism Overhaul, the game changes completely, battles are satisfying and the whole feeling of the gameplay is centered around enjoyable experience which has some depth. All thanks to a mod. Now comes the controversial part - is it recommendable to buy games only because of mods? On one side one might lament the missed opportunities of original developers, on another you can be happy that independent mod creators are fixing the mess called vanilla game. I will say it is worth it so I will recommend the base game as just that - a platform for mods like the Wakes Realism Overhaul.

I didn't verse any humans (I can't imagine it's very fun though), so I'm reviewing this based on the campaign. I am baffled why anyone would give this a positive review, much less a majority of people reviewing it as such. This is my first venture into the Total War games, and I now know why there's so many of them; these must be real easy to pump out. There's more load time than gameplay here. It's like they took the worst, most tedious parts of Sid Meier's Civilization and Warhammer, and mashed them together to make one of the least enjoyable, least playable RTS games I've ever experienced. There's 2 different "gameplay" elements in this - the campaign map, and the battles. In the campaign map you get to move around your armies and "heroes." Heroes can fight in battles with your armies if you choose to have them do so (which is really the only time that they're vulnerable), otherwise, they can run around the map on their own, and be totally immune to any danger, unless another very high-leveled hero has unlocked the ability to assassinate other heroes.  This means that heroes can just move freely around the map, and hamper armies by just standing in their way. There's nothing the army can do about it, and the AI knows it, so this is what they have their heroes do to you, and each other, ALL GAME LONG! Heroes are mobile mountains; awesome. The campaign map lets you manage pre-placed cities as well, which have very limited building options, and are constantly under the influence of multiple factors (order/support, chaos, vampirism, etc). A majority of your interactions with cities will be trying to manage those factors with the very limited options that you have. Now, onto the battles...which you also won't do much in. The biggest influence you have in battles is placing your units, and choosing their first fighting engagements. After that, good luck getting them to do anything you tell them to. And that's it. You don't really do anything in battle past that...unless you include battling the camera, in which case, a majority of your time in battles will be committed to that endless war. Now, let's say that you want to actually do these battles, and not just pick to auto-resolve them when they happen. Everytime you enter a battle, you have a long load time. If you messed up your placement in battle, or if your units really fudged something, you'll probably want to try the battle again. Unfortunately, there's no 'retry battle' option, so what you actually have to do is pick to concede the battle, endure a very long load time, then load the save, endure another long load time, then enter the battle again, and endure yet another long load time. I kid you not, redoing a battle takes over 5 minutes of sitting around! And it's not even time where you can go and do something else while waiting, because you have to keep picking to load the next thing! IT'S SO ****ING STUPID! WHY DOES ANYONE LIKE THIS?!

I've been playing Total War games since the original Shogun back in 2000. This has been my favorite thus far. It feels as though CA is growing with each and every new iteration, and the Warhammer lore is such a rich jumping off point for the epic scale and narrative required to sustain playability in what some would ordinarily consider a "boring" strategy game. Having truly unique play-styles for each faction is the difference between simply choosing between teams with different, but similar units. If you don't like strategy games, but enjoy fantasy, I'd still recommend this at the $14.99 price tag. Do a quick browse of some of the lore and before you know it, you'll be feeling an overwhelming sensation to build vast armies and stem the tides of darkness (or spread them, if you like to play as the evil factions).

Pretty late review, but this is a really good game where CREATIVE ASSEMBLY really nailed the combination of Total War with Warhammer Fantasy. The atmosphere is great and the Warhammer world really comes to live here.

I think I have only two major complaints:

1.) The campaigns don't offer too much depth in the economic system. Money seems to easy to get, while trade isn't important enough and spam of elite units far too easy.

2.) Heroes and generals being one-man armies is even for Warhammer a bit too over the top. A single character trying to beat an entire regiment on its own is even in the tabletop game pretty dangerous. I would have vastly preferred a unit attachment system for characters.

Nevertheless, this is THE computer game for every Warhammer fan to play. :-)

My hardware admittingly is mid to low range PC (plus laptop) that I had trouble running it in 30-25 fps, but what I played was worth getting it at launch. I will list some of the prods and cons down below. I hope this helps

Pros
- Heroes/Lords/Wizards character is a must buy for this game
- Map gameplay is secondary but fleshed out
- Battles are the best for my first time playing TW
- Each factions are unique with their own Story, Goals, and Lords

Cons
- Not low spec friendly
- Disappointing Magic Mechanic 
- Long to finish one campaign
- Chaos Warrior OP at the beginning of the game

As someone who is a huge fan of historical TW settings, when I first saw that CA was developing a fantasy themed TW, I was put off.  Even though this game got positive reviews, I didnt buy it until recently...And oh boy was I missing something. TW:Warhammer is definitely one of the best in the series. 
Every faction has a different mechanic such as Vampires have to corrupt cities before capturing them or Dwarfs need to keep their Grudge Book clean to avoid conficts at home etc. etc. Unit variety is on point, you won't get bored by playing the same units over and over again. Dragons, helicopters, pistols, magic...This game has it all.
Battle maps are excellent and for the first time ever in a TW game, you can really use the terrain to your advantage. Battles are challeging and you have to play to your factions strengths to win. For example, you can't run your Dwarfs around all the time and expect to win the battle.
This can go on and on, so to keep it short; from campaign map to battle map to battles, this game delivers. Only thing it is lacking is a real story to keep you going for the ultimate victory (I heard TW:Warhammer II has it). All in all, this is a fantastic TW game, which both TW fans and Warhammer fans can enjoy. I easily recommend it to any strategy fan out there.

As somebody who is mildly familiar with the Total Wars series, this game is superb!
(I've played through a full campaign in Rome Total War, and messed around with Shogun 2) 

The fantasy elements of this iteration in the series really shine through, and help this game stand out from the rest of the city. Where there is less complexity in the city-building elements compared to other TW games, this is made up for by having a massive variety of units between all of the various Warhammer factions. We've gone beyond just having archers, infantry, and cavalry. We have crazy artillery, flying units, a massive cavalcade of monsters, and tons of magic trees to take advantage of. 

Can't recommend this game enough!

A largely faithful and action packed recreation of the Warhammer Fantasy World! While the paid DLC is a little daunting much like any modern Total War game, there's also more than enough to chew on within the base game, including a pleasant amount of FreeLC (Bretonnia yay!) within the base game. Very well optimized and possessing an epic scale! 8 )

As a life long total war fan, I wish I played this sooner.

This game recaptured my love for the franchise, no historical title could have. One of the main things I loved about playing RTW for the first time was how it introduced me to wanting to learn about ancient Rome. And like RTW, WTW introduced my to the Warhammer universe. As a DnD player and someone who only knew about spacemarines in 40k, I was so glad to experience Warhammer in such a nuanced setting.

After not buying any TW after Attila, I moved on to AoE2 and Paradox games. What made me pick up WTW? Learning from  one Heir of Carthage video and some friends that I was not only good, but thankly better optimised that the FPS crunching of R2TW and ATW, and was the accumulation of most of the best features of modern TW's.

Long story short, I spent 50 hours in one week on this game. If you ever loved TW and left it behind before WTW, pick it up on sale, despite it's fantasy setting that turned me, and many others off.

Game is fun to a point.  Then turns to nonsense when horde after of horde and faction after faction, all with further, faster movement and greater strength, invade internally and externally simultaneously.  It's like the beginning of success triggers the AI to shut you down.
     Hooks players  with things like curiousity and frustration,.  Then the game reveals insulting cliche
If you were getting bored of total wars, then PLAY THIS GAME. I bought in on sale, and i admit, the forty pounds is pretty hefty, but the game itself is just...noice.

I have always loved total war mechanics, this game has changed some things, like reinforcements sourcing from a global pool for double the price and time over the local pool. One thing that bothered me when I first played it was that you could not settle any old type of settlement, you could only capture or settle compatible settlements or raze them if not. 

Economy is a much simpler version to most total war titles. As food was only required for growth of a settlement to enable upgrades. Military buildings only needed to be placed sporadically leaving room for other elements to be built.

Family trees seem to be no longer used. Personal faction politics are also not used as far as i seen.

All in all I love this game and will play every faction at least once.

TRIGGER WARNING !

This is not a game for people who may get " triggered" if chaos ensues !
Like me for example..
Purchased game, bought most of the dlc's.
Said to myself, "lets try easy mode", and try to figure out the schematics.
But,,,,, there is no easy mode... As a matter of fact,, it's barely a game.. 
If you are willing to spend 40 hrs on you tube, watching videos that some kid who lives in his mom's basement posts, on how to micro manage a completely broken economy, then buy this game immediately, and prepare to go on welfare.

If you enjoy, building an army on a Wallmart workers salary, running it across the map to take a city, only to lose 4  by the time you take 1 ?? this game is for you !!

The level of frustration will be sure to cause anyone with anger management issues to punch your monitor through your mom's basement wall. 

If you smoke, get the patch, you will go through a carton, and that"s before the chaos even begins. !

It starts out fun, but even on easy mode, it's a terrible game to wrap your head around. 
The economy does not work, unless you are able to outsmart the most OP artificial intelligence on the planet.
Mark my words kids, if you get zits easy from stress, you will need a lifetime prescription for proactive after the first couple hours.

In short, this game is for hard core basement dwellers, who can do a Rubik's Cube, without pulling all the stickers off ! 
I had to pull the stickers off....
Frustrating game... broken economy... it`s Chaos ! In the literal sense..
I give it a 2 out of 10...

A very close thumbs up, and then only on sale.

This game has an excessive amount of DLC with some glaring power imbalances. TW:WH2 also came is also out as a separate title (with yet more DLC). That being said, it captures the aesthetics of the WHFB very well and the TW engine is as solid as ever. Diplomacy is pretty off, but what did you expect in a wargame? It's all an excuse to murder the other team.

The campaign is pretty rough starting with the basic Empire faction- use guides or get your face bashed in repeatedly. Likewise, game mechanics aren't always very clear and the game is punishing on bad matchups. Auto resolve can also be wonky. This can be exploited, but may also mean you lose and army to what should be a decisive victory.

For WHFB fans, faction imbalance, odd combat mechanics , mandatory purchases, and power creep will be nothing new. Wait for a sale, pick it up and start playing- even with all the downsides (and maybe because they are so similar to the tabletop flaws) it will feel very familiar to you first games of WHFB, complete with learning curve. And, again, the models are very pretty.

Even though I cant enjoy the graphical capabilities of this game in full (i have an old nvidia 660 card), this is hands down my favorite total war game. Though all the other historical tw games are fun to play; if you're into orcs and dwarfs etc, then this game is right up your alley. Overall experience with the game 8.9/ 10

Great game somewhat hampered by excessive DLC and bad diplomacy.
If you like Total War titles you will love this (hence why I'm recommending it), but I would wait for it to be on sale. I still feel pretty stung by the fact that TW:WH 2 came out so soon after release and is yet to drop in price.

The game also suffers from power and feature creep; many of the new DLC characters and factions are absurdly OP compared to the original ones in the game. The Empire, for example, was a faction in the game from the beginning. Their research tree has an option to increase your soldier's armour by +5 (a pathetic amount), and this takes 12+ turns.

On the other hand the new Vampire leader gives every single one of his soldiers on the map a big XP boost every turn, or his entire army gains poisoned attacks. Similarly the new Dwarf lords, particularly Grimbrondal, do absolutely absurd damage and are very hard to kill. These are ridiculously powerful buffs by comparison and can feel pretty unbalanced because the old factions have not been brought up to equality.

Some of the heroes are way to powerful taking on armies by themselves. They removed the formations for troops making it more simple and sort of like a point and click game. And because the factions can only take certain areas every time i start a new game it turns out to run the same as the previous making it very repetetive.
Total war died with this game.

I want to give this game a positive recommendation, I really do.  The problem is, I just can't.  This game has far too many bugs for how long its been out, the most egregious of which is the constant crashes to desktop.  This typically happens during a hard-fought, or hard-set-up battle.  You can play a flawless battle, only to suddenly be dropped to the desktop, all of your progress wiped.  There are also numerous camera bugs that make the campaign map useless at times.  I would recommend passing on this installment, and going for Total War: Warhammer 2 instead.  Hopefully, it's more stable than this thing is.

I highly recommend the base game. It is easily the best Total war in year. Great visuals. Great Balance.
However they want to charge a 3rd of the games original price for an additional single race which is almost a re-skin of the chaos knights. I have played the total war games since the original but every game they release they become more and more money hungry.  I am satisfied with the base game even though they did not place an option to remove the campaign boundaries that severely limit the flexibility of the game. I like to play the game following the lore but I also want the option to replay the campaign and conquer the whole map. *Edit-This was added through Mortal Empires in the second game.  
I rate the base game a solid 8/10 but with the release of $18 DLC for only one additional race a few months after release. I am giving it a 4/10. Don't strip your completed game down and try to sell it in pieces. I mean the game was $60 and came with 5 factions and a decent bit of side content. How can you justify an additional 1 faction for the price of 1/3rd of the original game! Great game, Corrupt company...

As with most Total War games, I didn't purchase Warhammer Total War until I was sure that the bugs, patches etc had been sorted. I refuse to buy a new Total War game since Rome II.

Overall, I think that this is a very good game. The mechanics, the campaign map, and the unit/ faction diversity is very good. 

The major negative is the DLC and the fact you need to pay for it. Understand extra campaigns, but factions such as Chaos and Norsica should have been included and factions such as the Empire should have been released with all their heroes and units.

Unfortunately, this is the direction CA have decided to take.

I am personally waiting for a sale before I buy the DLC .

Overall, it is a very good game. Just pricey all things considered,

Total War: WARHAMMER once again shows that Total War is one of the best RTS games ever made. Let's start by saying I have played every Total War game up to this point. Total War Warhammer is the last Total War game I intend to buy. I've watched as each game gets better graphics but reduced gameplay and complexity in every installment. Warhammer is not a total war game. It's a very cut down arcade game. I'm not saying it's bad. It just isn't the grand strategy game I enjoy.

If you enjoy Warhammer or fantasy combat then you will likely get some enjoyment out of this. If you want Total War grand strategy then you're completely out of luck. It's all fantasy and geared for arcade style player vs. player combat. I have tried to get into the combat but it's so completely alien to previous Total War games it's just not interesting to me. Sadly this seems to be the direction Creative are taking all the total war games. Online live service multi player competitive play over historical strategy. Yes the AI is appalling in all total war games and very easy to exploit once you figure out how it works. But I do enjoy single player games and the ability to just do a few turns as and when I have some free time and that's what you can achieve with Atilla or Rome or Empire. 

Creative have patched most the bugs out of Warhammer and combat is fairly balanced for the type of game it is. Graphics are very nice and in keeping with Warhammer. I can't recommend this as a Total War game because it isn't Total War. If you don't mind that fact then give it a try or watch some campaign plays on YouTube.

Don't quite understand some of the choices that were made in this game.

You can build a settlement up to have walls and a significant garrison for defense, but then a random army can roll up and attack, and I am forced to LEAVE those walls and defend in an open field against a superior force? Why even have the option for walls?

Diplomacy doesn't make sense either. The computer only wants to trade or form alliances if you are weaker then them. Even if you declare war on all the factions they are at war with boost your reputation with them... getting a basic trade agreement is like pulling teeth. Hell, the computer can still deny a trade agreement if you subjugate them!! Yes, the game is called Total War, but why waste time building a Diplomacy system if a Total War run is the only way to play? Might as well just declare war on everything right away every time you play and save yourself the time of the computer making a non-aggression treaty one turn, and then break it the next.

These games aren't known for smart choices made by the computer, but it seems even worse in this game. They just charge right at you. There is no trouble kiting tougher units and isolating weaker ones to achieve crushing victories every time. I just ended up auto resolving to save time, as I was having more fun building my territory up and dealing with the broken Diplomacy system
