Probably the best total war instalment since Rome ( that's no achievement as they have nearly all sucked since Rome ) but 15 years on it's still the best , hey CA can't you just redo Rome with better graphics please. The map is small and you can win inside 250 turns probably a lot less on 2nd play through if you're that bored and want to do it again and all because of one thing, the stupid event that is supposed to bring death but unless you are playing as a troll it's completely your best friend, it starts in the north and wipes out the competition leaving ruins for you to easily colonise. When will CA learn that roaming horde factions suck, every game that has these just turns the game into easy mode. I want to plan and struggle taking cities not colonising their remains, castles and armies are far harder to kill than a roaming horde. I won the long campaign without ever being the strongest faction the whole game wtf. I had one battle with the elves and barely saw any orcs or goblins, I started as the empire and made friends with the dwarfs at the start of the game who were the strongest faction throughout the whole game, they took care of the south while i cleared up the norths ruins. Not even having to fight the strongest faction to win is a major flaw in my book, the battles are an improvement generally although can be very messy when there are trees making you struggle to click on or see a unit ( not hidden just hard to see ) they really should have made these go transparent when you're directly looking at them. 
It was still fun ( mainly the early part of game ) but lacks a challenge once the main event starts, maybe I'll try a troll race as really they are the only ones who could struggle.
CA when you make your next game please remove roaming factions, they suck, suck, suck. I bought this for 10 pounds and wouldn't recommend paying anymore than that.

I'm a huge TW far, but this is the worst Total War game ever.  I played some 200 turns in Empire Grand Campaign on Very Hard, basically after the Chaos hordes start spawning you spend most of the game fighting against them, after you defeat their first 4-5 army spam, and kill all of their agents you have some 10 turns before they appear again, and you repeat the process all over again until you realize you are doing only that, fighting the damn Chaos hordes, killing their agents, my turn feedback was full of reports of enemy agents actions....
Conclusion: boring and repetitive, previous Total War games were more innovative and diverse, I don't think it's worth the price, and btw TW Warhammer 2 is the reskined TW W1, so not worth the money as well.

The most important part about the game, the battles are clunky , especially the cav play is terrible.
The cav get's stuck , even if a single rider gets stuck in combat, it has Disastrous impact on the whole unit.

There is a severe pause between user click and a unit caring out the command even if done manually.
The SHIFT queing of commands is basically pointless as units behave in strange ways , sometimes they stop randomly and think about god knows what.

the charge mechanic is wonky, as you have to be specific distance from the enemy to perform a charge , it's not very fluid , it's clumsy. However it's not like you're going to make good use of it as the units get glued to the enemy regardless. 
So most of the time you charge and then baby sit your braindead unit until it FINALLY somehow get's freed, inb4 half of it get's killed anyway. 
Especially low tier units have not that very strong charge ability, they can't really push trough entire unit. So you don't get to utalize it strategically, other than maybe to chase down the missle infantry.

If the combat worked smoothly as it did in say Shogun 2 , then it would be the best one , but with this clunky combat and controls it falls short. 

If it doesn't feel good , then what's the point.

I have played several campaigns so far and this game can be very frustrating. My last game I played as Norsca and by the time I started to add a few advanced units to my main army the game was over. I controlled 4-5 provinces of 3 regions each. The elves and empire each had a power ratio 30-50 times mine. When the Elves attacked they and the Empire each controlled 21-22 total regions. They sent in 8 armies in a few turns. One army had 7 dragons at 400+ upkeep each. 

Two games back I got destroyed by 5 full stacks with my only army have 13 units. The game before that I had 2 full armies and was ready to start a third. The dwarves controlled probably twice the territory and could throw 3+ full armies at each of mine within a couple of turns. 

I cannot recommend a game where the computer has such a vast advantage that it becomes a race to win very quickly or you get overwhelmed. I have 1000's of hours in the Total War games up to Rome II and have never seen anything like this on normal difficulty. It is just not fun to spend 150+ turns building up your territory and armies to see them wiped out in 10 turns.

A much needed change of scenery for the total war franchise. Refreshing to have a few factions with such different play styles. Only drawback is the dlc, worth it when on sale but it seems to just give you access to the different clans that are already in game for you to play.
However overall an enjoyable change, rather than the usual updated visuals of older games.

I usually don't bother with reviews but I'm actually annoyed enough this time to do it. I have a pretty good rig. Ryzen 1600 overclocked to 3.8Ghz and a Vega 64 with 16gb of 3000mhz DDR4 RAM. The game doesn't utilize my card properly because no matter what I do it wont go above 60% GPU usage even at 4k. This is causing abnormally low framerates when I should be at 60fps and above at 1440p. My PC can run DMC5, which looks a lot better than this game at a locked 120fps maxed out settings at 1440p. I've looked all over for solutions for my problem but nothing helps and lowering the settings actually makes it worse because then my GPU works even less. All 90 minutes of "playing" this game was just trying to get it to run right. I really like the Total War games, especially the idea of this one, but this game engine sucks. I'm not the only one having this issue either because when I looked online there's people with 1080ti's and such that are having the same problem. They can't find solutions either. So I'm requesting a refund until I see better results or until hardware just goes so far beyond what this game needs that a futuristic toaster could run this game.

I love this game. I haven't played that much because I don't have all that much time and prefer to play other games with my friends but I love this game and this franchise. The game looks great and is very unique in unit rosters and play styles for different races and factions. However lets say you were to buy the game without downloading or buying anything other than the base game. You would get The Greenskin's, The Dwarf's, The Vampire Count's, and The Empire. You miss out on The Beastmen, Chaos, Norsca, The Wood Elves, and a whole heap of lords and unique units for some factions not to mention a distinct lack of blood. (Also Bretonnia but they are technically free DLC) So you miss out on more than half the game without the DLC. Which I hate, you can't buy just the game you gotta get the DLC too. Which is where this game begins to falter. Now this isn't the first time CA has done this. They did it with Rome 2, Warhammer 2, and will most definitely do it with Three Kingdoms. I hate this practice and so does most of the community, and as much as I don't want to do it, if the game plays like this one I will likely continue to buy it. I hate this practice as a whole and don't support it at all. But Warhammer 1 and 2 feel so good to play that, given the game as a whole, feels this good. Then I'd buy it.

8/10
TL;DR DLC whoring is bad but I feel okay to buy it if it plays like this, aside from the Chaos Warriors, They suck don't buy them

EDIT:

Just wanted to give an update to this review, not that anyone cares or is buying Warhammer 1 other than to play Mortal Empires... Anyway!

I haven't purchased WH2 yet, simply because of the mountain of modding I will have to do to get the game even to a playable state.  I've heard that CA finally went back and rebalanced the old world factions to still not be as competitive as the WH2 factions and they're drastically overpowered skills/spells in the second game compared to the first.

It's a great game, it is NOT a Total War game.  This is a WARHAMMER game.  There are elements of Total War, such as the campaign map, and that's really about where it ends.  This is meant to be played as if you were competing on a tabletop.  IF you can get in that mind set and compare units going up against units (pseudo-rock-paper-scissors style), it's actually a great game for combat.

The main mods I did with it was edit the Morale, items, and abilities/upgrades of characters.  The base morale values in this game are absolute shit, fights won't last more than 5 minutes if it's not edited.  These are supposed to be trained soldiers fighting for their entire world against age old enemies, they wouldn't just up and flee in 30 seconds of the fight going the opposite direction.  But that's how CA have them coded when you download the game and start playing it...

Long time fan of the Total War games, but I can't really recommend it even at sale price.   It still has all the flaws TW has had since, well, forever:  Poor path finding, questionable AI, so so interface, bizarre camera, and more bugs than a motel 6 bed.  I think the historic aspects in the previous TW titles allowed me to see past the flaws, but there just wasn't enough there in this one.  If you're a fan of WH Fantasy you can probably appreciate the campaign part, but I personally couldn't get into it.  The close in, the battle graphics are vastly superior to previous TW titles, but there's no actual point, as you're never viewing the battle from there anyway.  The campaign map also looks pretty in the screenshots and whatnot, but actually it's a lot of clutter, and it makes it difficult to see where anything is.   Most people seem upset about the absurd sticker price, and paywall scheme, but I'm not sure I blame Sega.  Anything with a GW sticker on it is going to be 3-4 times more expensive than anything even approaching reasonable.  I'm not recommending it at any price unless you're a WH Fantasy fan.

As a fan of warhammer, I was excited to see how warhammer mechanics made their way into combat.  Excepting activate spell abilities, it would seem that a lot of the mechanics are simplified.  So I would say on the whole this is a Warhammer themed total war game.  In that spirit, it captures the style, variety,  and feel of Warhammer very well.  On the whole, it is a faithful and well balanced production.  

I decided to play the Dwart campagin for my first campaign, as this was labelled as "Easy."  I enjoy playing 4x games and learning the mechanics.  Replaying a few times on a bad start can be part of the fun. I was ultimately disappointed.  Usually I can play through and learn, and then come back a second time and know what I am doing.

I kept losing very badly to the greenskins.  On my third attempt,  I was able to contain my main enemy to three provinces.  (by all rights, having 3x the economic might should have clinched the war, espcially considering the loss I kept inflicting.) He had a full army, which means nearly his full budget should be going to pay for most of it.  He attacked where my army was not and took two provinces before I could catch him.  Then a second full army appeared, seemingly out of nowhere.  It is quite impossilbe for several reasons, the least of which is that he could not afford such an army.  Seeming that the game was unbeatable due to cheating, On fourth attempt, I then discovered that attacking the greenskin provinces in the right order provided much better results.  In short, I had to move straight to attack his main city.  This contradicted several game guides, to which I had referred since I was apparently doing something wrong.  It would seem major balance changes // content updates severely upset the campaign balance.  I was annoyed there is only one, specific right thing to due at the start,  I hope this frustration does not continue in the other campaigns.

The problem with this game and the problem with all total war games is that they haven't changed their base mechanics in 10-15 years. It is build city up, go to war, and fight baddies will baddies you have gotten from said buildings. Its a game that some people really like but for me it offers nothing but a thinly veiled starcraft with a world map. Once you have "won" you have no reason to continue playing. AI is very uninteresting and defending cities to me is the only interesting part of the game because you can defend cities with 500 men versus 5000 and win. It never feels like a challenge but when it does its fun as hell. When it doesn't feel like a challenge it feels slogish and slow. By the time you got the big baddies and the coolest units you have already won. And if you like these games for the spectacle watch youtubers play this game because its not worth it. I don't like it but if others like it no shame on them. Play paradox games except don't buy them pirate them. Because fuck paradox.

First off, when I bought this game I figured I would play it for less than 5 hours and return it. 400 hours in and I can say I thoroughly enjoyed it. I enjoyed the new units and factions, which with this and WH2 there are a ridiculous amount of factions and play styles that will fit everyone out there. If you want to play a more medieval knightly style there is Bretonnia. Basically heavy horse troops out the ass. If you want to play as a more of late 1500s army theres the Empire. Greatswords, and riflemen. One big flaw I have with the game, even playing on hard or higher difficulties, is that it is easy to get a big death ball of sorts going.
Its a fun game. The most and most iritating is the running away from enemy units and they are always just out your grasps. you let them go, they sack you persue them its endless.......

I was so disappointed with this game. I love M2TW and was hoping for something similar in a fantasy vein, but so much has changed that this doesn't resemble Medeival 2 at all. Managing your settlements has been dumbed down to a degree that is just disgusting and there is no direction at all in the game. 
It plays a little more like a single player story campaign, which I liked at first, but your options seem to be to attack characters who are much too strong for you to defeat or travel huge distances to find someone who is. Why put the player in a starting area where all the enemies are too strong? 
The battles didn't feel fun or tactical either, plus the amount of dlc is outrageous. So much of this game is behind a paywall that the publishers should be ashamed of themselves.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

Total War: WARHAMMER is a game developed by The Creative Assembly and published by SEGA and forms part of the Total War series

The game offers some pleasant graphics and really vibrant colours, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same

The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game but a fun game nonetheless

Total War: WARHAMMER overall, however, is a fun game to play, yet sometimes flawed, but is a great grand strategy game to play in short bursts!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

Total War: Warhammer is an excellent Turn-Based Strategy game, perhaps my most favourite Turn-Based Strategy game that I have ever played. You get a buddy to play with you and it's heaps of fun, along with the Real-Time battle screens with some cool magic and item abilities to use in those Real-Time battle screens. It's a great time killer too, since you'll conquest little by little until you win your long campaign and even then there's still around half of the map to go and mess around with afterwards. 10/10 would recommend to any friend who likes strategy or even just anyone in general.

This game is really very bland.  I was expecting a little more out of this title, and it lacks in any real empire development.  The Rome and Shogun games you at least felt like your developing a bloodline of succession and generals, and you slowly grew your armies and territories.  This game feels like you have to constantly making mad dash grabs for territories and if you don't quickly tree up with certain types of units your armies are simply crushed by the opposition.  I love the Total War games, but this one just doesn't do it for me.

[b]"DLC FOR THE DLC GOD!"[/b]

Pretty solid TW game, but atrocious DLC practices mean I can't recommend this title. With the sole exception of Bretonnia, every faction in the game has important  on-disc content locked behind a DLC paywall. At times it feels like a "pay-per-character" fighting game, only instead of being released F2P, the devs expect you to shell out sixty dollars for the base game.

Worth playing, but not worth paying for. Unless you're an idiot like me, give it a pass until everything is on sale.
CA continues to nickle-and-dime players with piecemeal DLC, including charging extra for blood effects in a game with a AAA price tag. Pick it up from your trusted Skidrow retailer.

I paid CA good, real money to get violated by elite units and other factions I must pay extra for. Don't get me started on the unkillable legendary heroes either. Such a mistake putting indestructible, nuclear-powered, god-tier heroes in the game (that when max leveled) can destroy half your army or more. Can we maybe get an option to debuff heroes? Definitely going to dump some more hours into this though.

Being a big fan of the Warhammer universe and of the Total War games (older ones mind you) i was expecting a lot from this title, i stayed clear of it til the whole bugfest and DLC fiasco cleared up then got it on sale with all the extra content for $60 AUD.

This feels like an incomplete game, in 14 hours i have already hit the end game in two campaigns and noticed that despite the variety of tactical gameplay between factions; there is no variety in the main objective of the game.

Simply put 3 things happen.
1. Chaos curb stomps you.
2. You curb stomp Chaos.
3. Play as Chaos and run around the map doing nothing.

This leads into the same kind of strategic gameplay across ALL factions, which is just utter stupidity and boring as watching paint dry.

End game units can be made available in turn 40, so about 2 hours work. However these units (with exceptions of course) are barely better then baseline ones which are also significantly cheaper, while tactics may win you battles in this game, overrunning your enemies in cheap units wins you campaigns.

The map is smaller then many previous titles that CA has developed, many of the races are behind a pay wall and you STILL have to pay for blood and gore effects. Take out the setting and this is one of the more shallow Total War games i have ever played, they still have a rock, paper, scissors mentality to how units fight and not to how they would realistically perform or even how they performed on the freaking tabletop game. Top it off with nearly half of the races in the setting missing and it just ends up with a whole lot of its potential missing.

It plays like half of a finished product that has been polished so it can be sold to consumers at full price, lo and behold when CA brought out Warhammer II with the rest of the game for another $80.

I am tired of CA, tired of SEGA throwing this franchise against the wall and beating it to death. I said that i would not get another total war after Attila but i made an exception for this one due to the setting that i hold dear, especially since the makers of said setting, Games Workshop, have thrown it on a dumpster fire.

I am not buying another total war while CA and SEGA have control over it; a mixture of franchise fatigue, bullshit business practices and oversimplification of gameplay has left me sour and bitter.

I had put it off for a few years. I have played Total War since first Shogun back in high school, and except for Alexander DLC and Atilla have purchased and played every TW PC title. I love history, have a history degree, and while by no means perfect have used this series to explore and live some of my favorite periods. With great mods, the replayability has been endless. A Warhammer Total War game? What? I couldn't.

Finally came the 2019 Lunar sale, maybe there was something in the water. Maybe it was the $12 sale price. I poked around the discussion forums and after having some questions answered I went for it. Bought Warhammer 1 and all DLC minus Beastmen and Elves. 

I'm loving it. At work I stand at my  machine and think about it. At night I'm dreaming about it. Released from the constraints of history, and having no real knowledge of Warhammer or its rules, I'm going crazy. And since I'm running fun and  fancy free, I'm loving VANILLA. No mods yet. 

Running an Empire campaign to slowly dip my toes in. Humans, pikes, a war of succession. But I also wanted giant beasties. So I started a campaign as a vampire, and have undead zombies, and a giant overgrown bat beast the size of a house, and I'm loving every minute of it. There are no phalanxes to fuss over, no reform dates to wring my hands over, no "well thats not totally accurate". I can swarm my hordes of zombies or goblins and let the battlefield turn red with blood. 

Get. This. Game.

Overpriced and overrated: I don't have many hours on the game, but what I've seen makes me wish for a refund. The same bugs that have been in the franchise since Total War Rome 1 are still present. Units containing 60 men will stack up against an enemy unit, with only 4 men at the front attacking. Faction balance is the worst in the series, as every faction is completely different (which is kind of a good thing, except for the aforementioned unbalance). I thought religion was a nuisance in previous Total War games. Well, wait until you have to deal with Undead/Chaos corruption. To top off all these issues, the game sits at 60 dollars, with tons of overpriced DLC, some costing as much as $20 to unlock a single faction. Only buy if you have a hard-on for Warhammer, and even then, wait for a sale.
the battles are great but the campaign experience is garbage. Unless you like fighting four enemies at once who raid you constantly.
Pretty fun, but it's no RTW.

What some overly entitled users are failing to mention in their negative reviews (aka, the "too much DLC" babies ) is the sheer amount of content already available in the base game. I bought it at launch and at no point did I feel it was lacking. The factions are pompous or brutal and violent, and all are full of personality. They feel different, the play different, each one challenges the player to innovate unique strategies. each faction has several commanders to choose from with a unique starting retinue - choices for miles and content for days.  Combat is fun and engaging and thoroughly entertaining to just watch - dragons or giants ragdolling infantry men,  or orks on boars mowing down zombie hoards and epic lords dueling in the throng of combat.  The voice acting is spectacular and gives factions/heroes that extra depth and robust presentation they deserve. Everything is completely over the top and I loved every bit of it. 

CA did not withhold content from the base game to scum a few more dollars from us. They earned my money by producing a gigantic and quality fantasy game that's staying true to the source material and they deserve what I've paid.

I haven't played any Total War game nor the tabletop game version of Warhammer. I've been interested in them for a long time though. I like this game's visual design and the interesting lore. This could be a good entry point to the Warhammer universe. But even with a discount as a 2+ year old release, I still find [b]Total War: Warhammer[/b] (and all its DLCs) to be an expensive game with quite a complicated and quirky User Interface. I expect to understand and enjoy a game in under 2 hours so I can decide whether I will keep it or not. The money and the time investment to learn playing is a pain and is just too much for me. I am sorry to say but [b]Total War: Warhammer[/b] did not pass my requirements.

Based on campaign AI which cheats too much to make the game fun to play, I have to warn people to stay away from the single player game. Winning a battle is meaningless, the AI will rebuild instantly. Any effort to weaken the AI is meaningless, it doesn't need money or resources to maintain multiple, massive stacks of the best troops in the game. A single AI province can maintains four or five maximum stacks of the highest teir armies. I have never seen this before in a Total War game.

edit: the game works at least. If it were just about the real time combat on the tactical map, I would recommend it. But I hate everything about the campaign map where the game play is extremely poor and needs to be redesigned. In the single player, you'll spend most of your time on the campaign map where the developers have created an amazing mix of the boring and the frustrating. Essentially, on the map, you make about two or three decisions and then wait for the AI to resolved the other 25 factions. But since the AI doesn't need money and has many stacks of the highest tier units, the AI is having all the fun. Everytime I exit the game, all I can think about is how much I hate it.

edit 2: Played the Wood Elf campaign and it was pretty fun. Although the stacks of high tier, free AI armies continued,I actually had an economy and had some decent unit stacks myself. Because of that, I got to make meaningful decisions and fight some challenging battles with some interesting units.

I suppose whether a campaign is fun or miserable really depends on the faction.
